A lot of comments and review have written before. And I wouldn't be too original if I will say it's good, definitely high-class game. There aren't too much faceless and clone-like weapons. In my humble opinion it's neither too big nor too small amount of weapons in the game. Because you feel each one unique. And I'd say the same about the enemies. There are different types of them, with solid design [spoiler](which is always good to have consistent design approach)[/spoiler].

There's also some plot about what is going on in the game's world. It includes cute and funny cutscenes with nice comic-like art-style. The plot is simple, but kind and does its job well enough.

All in all I do recommend you to try it. It also has a co-op, different classes to play as, which could improve your progress pace. And on the market it's the best offer for now, if you're looking for Rogue-Like shooter.

It's rare that a game compels me to want to 100% it, but Roboquest is one of those rare games. Even after full completion, I still find myself wanting to come back here and there for a quick round or two. The soundtrack is incredible, combat is fluid, and enemies are fun and varied. Devs are communicative and are still updating the game even though it's basically perfect already.

I never leave reviews. Absolutely love this game and would be 5 stars but currently it has constant server issues. For a rogue game, you cant have server issues when you get 2 hours into a nice run and then it drop everyone for no reason. This happens once per day to me, conveniently, when I am in my best run. Doesn't matter who is hosting, one of us always gets network error. Please fix this.
UPDATE: it has been almost 3 weeks and still cant get through a run without disconnect. whats the point in playing. If the bots don't kill you, the game will.
UPDATE UPDATE: Thanks team. I notice some disconnect when i start my 2nd, 3rd run when in the first chapter. But no more disconnect on the main run far in. Totally ok with this as you sort out the next bit. Much happier with disconnect 3 min in VS 1 hour in.

There are very few games that are as addicting and fun as Roboquest in the roguelike/lite category.  The gameplay is very simple but mastefully executed, you simply take out as many robots as possible with your weapon(s) of choice. The variety within the weapons is almost overwhelming, giving you access to drastically different choices almost every run. Despite the crazy variety, each weapon is relatively easy to use, but mastery usually takes some getting used to. This gives the player a variety of choices when it comes to their perferred style of combat, as well as keeping the moment to moment gameplay fresh and exciting. If you like more consistency, you can usually find some variation of your perferred weapon(s) in each playthrough. The upgrades are frequent and helpful, but never make you feel TOO overpowered. The upgrades/items are also very simple and consistent, so no one silly little item can make or break your playthrough, and you won't have to do 3 hours of research to determine the best choice. One thing I can say this game does better than any in it's category is that it feels extremely fair. The gameplay is simply so well crafted that I rarely find myself getting upset with the game, the majority of your deaths will be to your own mistakes and shortcomings. The game is significantly more skill based than a lot of others I've seen in this category and it's incredibly fun and satisfying to watch yourself get better. This game has no annoying gimmicks, a fantastic soundtrack, and gameplay that relies more on skill than anything. I can't stress enough that it's so refreshing to find a game in this category that doesn't rely on you getting certain items or to have good luck to get the most enjoyable experience. Each individual run is just as fun and enjoyable as the last, even the ones where luck isn't necessarily on your side. If the game decides to give you the crappiest, lowest tier weapons and the most useless items, you still have a solid chance to do well since the gameplay is mostly based on your skills with evading enemy fire and making use of the weapons that the game gives you.  On top of all of this, the art style is amazing (although the difference between it and the graphics in game are a bit jarring) and the soundtrack is excellent. I've added quite a few songs from this game into my workout playlist, it's perfect to keep you engaged and moving.

TLDR: Roboquest is an incredibly skill based game that keeps the moment to moment gameplay fresh and exciting. Each playthrough is equally as fun, and you don't have to rely on getting a certain set of items or one lucky item just to have an interesting playthrough. The soundtrack is fantastic, art style is fantastic, and the story is simple and wholesome (at least from what I've seen, there could be some dark twist at the end that I don't know about but I highly doubt it lmao) Realistically if you like FPS games and roguelike/lites, there's no reason to NOT get Roboquest. This is the best game available in the Roguelike/lite category right now IMO and will inevitably set you up for an extremely enjoyable 10/10 experience.

Super TLDR: Very fun addicting shooting game that requires no luck to operate. Every moment of gameplay is fun and each new run is just as fun as the last since no items/upgrades make or break your playthrough. 10/10 highly reccomend.

It's good. Not great. The game can improve in terms of boosts, bonuses, etc. Post upgrades, the wrenches don't add anything to the game. An extra life for an obscene amount of in-game currency would be fair and could allow fun builds to be experimented with. Also, the inability to return to the camp between games is a slight problem. For example, other similar games allow for runs to be picked up at a later stage. With runs lasting from anywhere between 30 to 90 minutes, the time commitment to see it through is excessive.  The movement mechanics and the varied weapons are great, but there is no change to how the levels are. So at the end of the day it's about whether the prospect of beating the game across different difficulties in a time-bound system is a good enough hook for you. Buy the game if it is on sale, but don't be drawn by the multiplayer promise, that needs a lot of work and is not the smooth experience that is promised. Cheers,

One of the best fps games I‚Äôve played in a long time. The gunplay and movement are very fluid and smooth. The game design is excellent, constantly throwing you into the action and everything serves to enrich the gameplay. You are put into a flow state to kill as many enemies as possible. It‚Äôs fun, it‚Äôs rewarding, it‚Äôs stylish- and very satisfying to play.

The game encourages you to try out all of its 6 different classes, 70+ unique weapons, and an insane amount of unique item buffs to create your perfect build and get that faster clear time. There‚Äôs a jet pack, a grappling hook, and a slide jumping mechanic similar to black ops 3. Move fast and kill fast, slaying room after room of enemies and bosses. Everything works towards progressing and making you stronger for the next challenge and the next difficulty and reinforces good decision making when you play.

It‚Äôs fast paced and action packed and will actually improve your aim, tracking, and target acquisition for other fps games you play- you are constantly improving your own gameplay. This game is a master class in first person shooter game design and I recommend any fan of first person shooters to try out this gem.

After seeing the reviews I must say I'm pretty underwhelmed. Moving around and shooting feels good, as it should, but everything else is pretty uninspired. The perks or passive effects you get on level up are some of the most bland and boring stuff I've ever seen on a roguelite. 

The weapons too are pretty much just... Weapons that exist. Nothing new or interesting, really.

Most of the enemies are super obnoxious, mostly with the projectiles that stick to surfaces and take some time before exploding, which are pretty much omnipresent. 

I'm taking my refund while I still can, maybe there's some great stuff later in the game after you unlock some bits of progression, but I'm not paying to find out.

this game is dopamine straight to the johnson tip. i have never felt more alive playing a video game. even after you beat the final boss, there is more to do. even after you beat every difficulty on global s rank under 30 minutes, there is more to do. even when i cant pay my electric bill because i have been on my computer playing this game so much, there is more to do. the devs also have a ton of stuff post launch planned, and while the endgame after a while gets relatively easy to beat consistently, there will be more to do in the future and this game has become something of a comfort game for me. buy it. 

ps, engineer is the best class in the game. just grab cryo mastery and either a cryo weapon or the infused cryo weapons upgrade with scrap pancakes. freeze go brrrrrrr

Looter shooter that starts a new run each time you play. Calling it a rogue-like seems disingenuous because all the levels are set and only things like perks and weapon suffixes are random. 

Co-op is great. Unlike similar co-op games there's never really a time where one player is way more powerful than their teammates. Exp is shared and upgrades are given at the end of each level.

at the first glance, this game seems like any regular shooter game. cartoony style, different types of weapons, borderlands, right? however, WOW THIS GAME IS IMPRESSIVE. it fits the fast-paced context of games such as ultrakill, while also regulating a more laid back venturing experience, similarly to borderlands. i know i have only played this game for 5 hours, but the time i had playing this was unsalvagable. it has multiplayer as well!!!

Great game, the gunplay feels amazing, the soundtrack is competing for top spot on my list (Risk of Rain 2's is hard to beat) and the art direction is lovely.

They really went all out with 1.0, the game feels very complete now, love what they added.

The gameplay is Doom 2016 inspired, meaning your only source of healing during combat is ennemy drops which disappears pretty fast, incentivising an agressive playstyle.
Thing is, I wasn't a big fan of Doom's pacing, too much exploration to do, it breaks the rythm.
Now this game doesn't have that, it has some light exploration of the levels for data logs (lore) but once you get them, the game is 100% adrenaline-fueled fighting, with the occasional safe areas to level up your build and breathe a little.

A must buy for fast-paced FPS / Roguelike fans.

This is an extremely satisfying game. It's rare to find an FPS that I find keeping me coming back for more beyond an initial playthrough. Between the wide variety of possible [i]viable[/i] builds, enjoyable gunplay, diverse cast of enemies, [spoiler]the open layout of Act III,[/spoiler] collecting cards in the Museum, and more, I haven't found a game quite like this before.

One may consider the base of the game simplistic, but it has a level of polish and care rarely seen in games nowadays. I've never played a game where I enjoyed both shotguns (normally my bane) and snipers (hit or miss for me) and could use them in the same build while moving at incredible speed. It's only possible because of the solid foundation of the game.

Truly remarkable. Well done.

I recommend this game in single player, but not co-op. Reviews can only be up or down though.

In single player the game is just what you see in trailer. Dodge shit while using the different classes, items, and weapons with class upgrades per run. A good roguelike FPS that rewards speed and knowledge and runs end quickly after mistakes.

The game does not work well in co-op. The currency used in runs (Power Cells) are dropped by enemies along with health and meta game currency and these drops dissolve within a few seconds after dropping. This mean that you'll need to hug eachother's ass in co-op. Killing enemies in different areas halves the drops each player can pick up. Missing health drops is not the big issue, but missing the currency used per run is. If those pickups were shared I would give a positive review.

Buy on sale for single player if you want good practice for playing competitive shooters with alot of movement, treat the co-op as an afterthought.

Roboquest is an absolute blast to play, offering fast-paced FPS combat and roguelike elements that create a beautiful balletic barrage of bullets and bashes. The music in this game is some of the best in the entire genre, immersing players in its thrilling world. Additionally, the gunplay is smooth and responsive, enhancing the overall gaming experience.
One of the standout features of Roboquest is its satisfying character progression, which is well put together. Players will find themselves motivated to keep progressing as they unlock new abilities and upgrades. The weapon variety in the game is also impressive, with a wide range of weapons to choose from. The inclusion of weapon affixes further adds depth to the gameplay, allowing for strategic decision-making.
The developers have done a commendable job in improving Roboquest over the years. The game has come a long way since its initial release, and the efforts put into fixing its issues are evident. This commitment to improvement is commendable and adds to the overall enjoyment of the game.
However, one aspect that Roboquest falls short in is enemy variety. You will find themselves encountering the same types of enemies repeatedly, which can make the gameplay feel repetitive. Additionally, certain enemy attacks can be annoying, adding frustration to the gameplay experience.
In terms of price and playtime, Roboquest is reasonably priced at $25 and can be completed in around 10-20 hours. This makes it a relatively short yet satisfying experience.
Overall, Roboquest offers an exhilarating gameplay experience with its exceptional music, smooth gunplay, and satisfying character progression. While it still has room for improvement in terms of enemy variety and certain enemy attacks, the game has shown significant growth and is worth checking out for fans of the genre.

Roboquest takes heavy inspiration from both Borderlands and Doom, culminating in what is honestly one of the best action roguelikes I have ever played, enough to rival a giant such as Risk of Rain 2. If you are a fan of shooters, everything in this game will work exactly the way that you think it does and that is no small feat. 

This is an extremely polished, fun and well made game, with the only complaint being that it wasn't long enough (beaten around the 11 hour mark). Though, I believe that they are still in the process of adding content and had their last major content drop in January right before I purchased.

If you are familiar with this kind of genre I would recommend starting on hard.

TLDR, if you like both shooters and roguelikes this is arguably one of the best games on the market for you

Roboquest is tons of fun.  It is fast, intense, and stylish!  The variety of of ways to play the game is more than enough, and there's still more secrets for me to uncover after dozens of hours (and the secrets actually give tangible benefits/new tools to play with!).  The mechanics invite you to be aggressive and precise, while still allowing you to be creative and silly every now and then.  There is also a lot of character to the design of everything, and the hub area is full of charming little decorations. 
  I have very few negative things to say, aside from wanting more variety in the random level-chunks; But the devs have already said they're working on more to add!  It's all good, and only gonna get better.
  I'm writing this review because I've never heard anyone talk about it in my circles, so word-of-mouth, ahoy!  
  Give Roboquest a try.

Fantastic tight and fast paced shooter with ample draw, reward and replay-ability through it's roguelike mechanics.  Fight through randomly assembled linear areas to the next area and pick a door to direct your run.  There is plenty to discover through puzzles and exploration but not enough to take away from the meat and potatoes of this title, which is the action.  A successful run will take less than an hour.  Plenty of time and leaving plenty more for another run with another class or after a different personal objective (unlock that door, try a different perk/weapon build, pursue and achievement or completion on a museum entry, etc.)  The boss fights are all unique and fun.  Every weapon is effective which seems to not be the case for many similar titles.  The sound track is solid and fits the game well.  If you're looking for a game that can hold you for a while but be enjoyed in bursts, this is a terrific fit.

Roboquest is one of my favorite games in my Steam library. I'm not usually a fan of roguelites, especially since so many of them require entirely different sets of gaming skills than my usual FPS games and platform fighters. This game is entirely different. 

Roboquest plays very well. It's fast paced, not unlike Ultrakill or Doom, but definitely slower than both of the games I mentioned. The guns and various other weapons feel amazing, the modifiers for weapons are interesting, the class upgrades are unique, and the general mechanics are very polished. 

When it comes to the visuals, the entire artstyle feels like Borderlands meets comic books, especially within the weapon designs. I really enjoy the visuals cause while they are cartoony, they also aren't overly cartoony. The game feels like a lot of time, effort, and passion was put into it. The music is also really well done. It's intense, fast-paced background music that doesn't immediately jump out but it goes hard. 

This game is really damn good, and one of my favorite recent games. I can't give it anything below a 10/10. I know I make a lot of not-serious reviews, but this is a genuine 10/10.

This game is a fast paced raging bonfire of an FPS. Why do I say that? Because at first, your movements will be chaotic, inconsistent, and erratic. Even though it gets the job done, it is very difficult. But, as you get more classes and find new upgrades, you will find out how to control this raging fire. You will find good upgrade combos, what works for you, and same with the weapons. You find the ones that are effective and the ones that are pretty dog water. Your scrap spilling oil-shed will become melodic, rhythmic, and most importantly, efficient. Soon you will become a deadly force who knows how to start and control this bonfire with ease.
Game is solid as hell and worth full price. I would recommend it to anyone with likes fps or rougelikes.

An incredibly fun and replayable """rougelike""" shooter. The combat and movement are both incredibly satisfying. You always feel in control of your character and when you lose it really is all your fault. The upgrade system allows for some pretty neat builds, which I'm looking forward to trying on the other characters I unlocked.

The controls/graphic setup is super customizable which really helps to make the game feel better to play. 

Really my only main complaints are about the logs/quest progression. Going out of your way to collect logs slows your time down, which basically means you're going to get a lower rank for trying to explore. This makes it harder to do a full run if you're going for logs.  

I'm not a huge fan of the music, but that's a personal preference. 

Overall, this game is packed full on fun content especially for the price it's being offered. Highly recommend picking it up and telling your friends to buy it as well. We need more single player games like this, so support these devs so more can be made!

This is all my humble opinion.

The good parts:
[list]
    [*]Generally polished and bug-free
    [*]High-quality visuals, if bland
[/list]
Issues:
[list]
    [*]Homogeneous: low enemy variety, superficial weapon modifiers, weapons are mostly machine guns, semi-auto rifles or grenade launchers, bosses appear in the same circular arena with a fight that is too easy, goes on for too long an always plays out the same way.
    [*]Low sense of danger: this is mostly due to the way the health bar works. It is too big, and acts more like a currency than the only thing between you and death.
    [*]Some goofy systems of dubious value: weapons have "levels" and modifiers. These amount to stat changes. A higher level weapon will appear later in the run. The result is that optimal play means dropping your current weapon for a new one every room. Since most of the weapons are rather boring, this usually means dropping one of the few fun weapons for some variant of an SMG.
[/list]

Overall:
Generally feels boring and uncreative. Fails to take lessons from good rogue-likes. High production value.

Review guidelines be dammed, Roboquest is pretty awesome. It's not a progressive cover based shooter. It's a perfectly paced shooter with a tonne of secrets, unlocks and randomised elements. If you're a fan of Gunfire: Reborn... I regret to inform you that upon playing Roboquest you'll never play Gunfire again!

The base movement of the game is a lot like Quake rather than Borderlands or Call of Duty. It's super fluent and feels very responsive. As you grow your repertoire of mobility bonuses (jetpacks and grappling hooks included) you'll begin to see the racing line and dare yourself to speedrun on your next playthrough. The weapons are varied enough to feel completely unique. Different playstyles are possible and rewarded. The game favours close range builds in terms of healing potential, because at long range you shouldn't be getting hit.

Mechanically the game was designed by a genius. There is no pistol MK1 or pistol MK2 nonsense. On average every single weapon has the same DPS so choose a weapon you feel comfortable with. Ultimately your build choices will break that rule. The permanent upgrades outside of each run will facilitate you and simply create more opportunities for finding the right combination of abilities and weapons to suit your style.

The level design looks very simple at first glance but your unlocked mobility options completely change how you tackle them. The route you choose from the first level to the last matters. For example (and assuming you have unlocked corresponding secrets) one route gives you a randomised legendary buff whereas another route will give you a free ability choice and a randomised epic weapon. Other routes can potentially shortcut you to the final levels of the game where your skill will decide if you can tackle them while under levelled.

And Max is freaking awesome!

Roboquest is a very solid addition to the FPS roguelike genre; it does pretty much everything you want out of a game like this, and does it well.

Mechanically the game is fantastic. The movement is smooth and responsive, and so is the shooting. The game‚Äôs levels give a lot of room for player‚Äôs creativity, with plenty of good interactable elements, as well as a lot of optional verticality.

The weapons specifically deserve a special mention. Each gun sets itself apart quite nicely, with its own mechanics, shooting pattern and sound design. The selection is quite large, but not so large that it‚Äôs rare to stumble upon a weapon that maybe you really liked from a previous run. It feels perfect, in other words. I suspect there might be a system running in the background keeping track of how much a player uses certain weapons.

The game also excels from a game design point of view. Pretty much all of standard roguelike staples are here, and they‚Äôre well executed: branching paths determining the progression of the run, reroll tokens, a selection of classes with unique identities and their own sets of abilities, as well as plenty of choice when it comes to weapons, builds, perks, etc. The enemy variety is pretty great too, each room having a different combination often presents a unique challenge, as certain enemies will require a specific strategy to tackle.

I would also particularly like to highlight the level-up perk selection, and design choices there. Very often in games of this nature you get presented with a choice of abilities that have a clear winner most of the time. Roboquest has a pretty large and diverse selection of perks that all help facilitate different playstyles, and the selections it presents has often led me to sit there for a minute and ponder which option would be better for my build.

The game also shines aesthetically. The visuals, sound design and music are all top notch. The game has a very bright, vivid, comic-book visual style that is quite striking. It‚Äôs vibrant and colourful, and just a pleasure to look at. If I had to compare it to something, it would probably be Borderlands. The sound design is solid, with weapons having their own unique shooting and reload sounds, as well the audio feedback being very clear, distinct and satisfying. Getting repeated crits in particular pleases my monkey brain greatly. I have to applaud the music, too. A great selection of catchy, pounding, techno bangers that complement the fast-paced action and get you ‚Äúin the zone‚Äù very easily.

The game also has a story. It‚Äôs nothing more than a few stop-motion cutscenes the game plays when reaching certain milestones, as well as numerous text logs that I'll confess I haven't read. It‚Äôs not a slight against the game by any means, but it does feel a bit tacked-on. The best thing I can say about it is it adds a little bit of charm to the game.

All in all, the game is a shining example of the genre, and an easy recommend.

Early Access:
There's a lot to like about Roboquest. The graphics style is fun, there are a wide variety of weapons, the music is great and I love the level themes. However, the gameplay loop is quite shallow. I can only seem to get through a run or two before I feel the need to move on to something else. Perhaps unlocking more in-game content/upgrades will help going forward or perhaps the devs will add some interesting features before exiting early access. For now, it fails to keep my attention but I will continue check in on major updates and hope for the best.

Full Release:
Decided to give Roboquest another go since the game is now out of early access, however, my opinion has not changed much. Still like a lot of qualities of the game but tend to get bored after a run or two. The variety of weapons, split paths and playable robots help make the runs feel unique but its still quite limited compared to other roguelikes or lites which this one is. The maps are the same every time, the power ups gained are too few/limited to excite me. Seems like it makes more sense to constantly switch weapons rather than upgrading which can be frustrating when you find a combination you like. Not to mention that you often select upgrades based on your current weapons. 

Again, this is not a bad game. Its just not holding my attention like other games in the same genre. Just want to give a different perspective besides the overwhelmingly positive reviews.

Just played through my first session of my game so I figured now would be the best time to leave a review.

Entertainment: 37/40
 + It is simply fun to play and exist in this world.

Design: 17/20
 + Gun play is very satisfying.
 + Movement is smooth and controllable.
 + Debuffs inflicted on you are creative and well made.
 + 3d models are very well made.
 - Abilities feel a little wimpy.
 - Class system is not very ambitious.
 - The randomized part of this game is very limited so the runs blend together.
 - Some guns are simply worse than others.

Story: 14/20
 + I love how they were able to give a identifiable character to the player-bot in such a short time without the use of dialogue.
 + The antagonist fills the same role as a Saturday cartoon villain.
 - Not very ambitious or innovative, though I imagine that was intentional.

Presentation: 18/20
 + Love the art style with the comic book presentation.
 + Music is great and only drops while in combat.
 + I love the loading screen between stages; They ooze with style.
 + Vendors each are a unique bot with a cute design.
 - Some player animations are lacking, in particulate sprint and Recon melee.

Total: 86/100
Statement: Would love to read this if it was a comic.

A few weeks ago I wouldn't have recommended this game, but here we are 60 hours later. Don't let the style fool you, this game is challenging. Even on normal you will die even with very powerful perks. My biggest criticism of this game is that the classes don't feel all that different from one another. They all have completely different abilities, but often I find myself implementing exactly the same strategy across classes to great success.

A friend and I picked this one up together, and have been having a great time with this title! It's has a lot of neat weapons and  plenty of build variety, and several characters which offer a lot of variety to your approach each run. There are a few small quests and gadgets you pick up across several runs which massively expand your mobility options and eventually build up to make you incredibly powerful. This may be the root of my only real complaint though.

It's a pretty minor one, which not everyone will take issue with, but early on this game is pretty difficult, and it feels nice to work your way up to the finish on the harder difficulties after building up your arsenal through upgrades, but I felt like my character got a little too powerful too fast. Once you unlock most of the upgrades available, the game becomes significantly easier, the new difficulties felt trivial nearly as soon as we unlocked them. 

I think I would have preferred if it either toned down the upgrades and mobility gadgets a bit (by the end game you can basically keep yourself airborne for however long you please.) or made the extra difficulty's scaling harsher. However I maintain that this is a very minor complaint for an otherwise very fun game, I definitely recommend picking it up!

An almost perfect game.

My one complaint is the difficulty scaling. As someone that's decent at roguelikes, but casual when it comes to FPSes, I was hardstuck at the end of act 2 on normal difficulty and started getting somewhat frustrated. Tried the easy setting and beat the game on the first try. There's nothing wrong with having a "git gut" difficulty but it feels like there should be a setting in between those two. This game has a ton of potential for beautiful skill expression, but I think for a lot of people the settings that exist right now will oscillate between too hard and too easy, making it difficult to play in a way that feels challenging and meaningful. I think this game would really benefit from a more modular difficulty system. Hades showed how to solve this problem elegantly years ago with the Heat system.

TLDR: Doom + 'what borderlands should have been' in terms of mechanics

[Coop only experience]

I would like to begin this review with the only complaint I have about the game: the multiplayer servers are a bit unstable at times. After playing the demo with a friend (the fact that this is possible is great), we purchased the game and wanted to start playing. However, we were unable to connect to each other initially. After restarting our games and retrying, it eventually worked. This issue occurred again on another occasion. Once connected, there are usually no problems, but on a single occasion, we disconnected in the middle of a run, effectively ending it. In a worst-case scenario, this could result in a time loss of 30 - 45 minutes. Since it happened only once within 20 hours, we were not that frustrated.

Despite the issues mentioned above, the game is amazing. It defines itself as a 'fast-paced FPS with Roguelite mechanics', and it truly delivers on all fronts. The gunplay is smooth and highly satisfactory. There are a lot of ways to alter the default behaviour of your weapons, making things even more fun and allowing for multiple builds. Different classes are available, and there are mechanics in place that allow you to permanently strengthen your character, even after failed runs. I was unaware of this game's existence, and it blew my mind when we played the demo.

Lastly, I would like to discuss the game's difficulty. We opted for the hardest difficulty right from the beginning, as that's our usual approach. Beat the first chapter relatively 'easy' and felt good about ourselves. Second chapter delivered a harsh reality check as we got our asses kicked.  After investing several hours in learning the game's mechanics, we finally progressed to chapter three. We felt really good about our builds and were ready to slay. We got absolutely demolished and sent to the grave. 

At the time of review, 20 hours in, we are still struggling in chapter three and have yet to complete a single run. Part of it is because we did not explore enough, part of it is simply because our movement is not good enough yet. The game is hard, it really is. But it is not unfair. I would say it has a high skill ceiling, particularly in terms of movement. But I know for a fact, that if I just 'git gud', I can eventually beat it. And I am loving it. 

Note that you can change the difficulty at any point in time if you wish.

This is a great game that, amazingly, makes a change on the first person shooter roguelike (it's actually more of a roguelite but) genre/subgenre. I've only played a few of them like this, Voidborn, Gunfire Reborn, and Force Reboot but I've so far liked this one the most. I love the artstyle of the game, with it being almost comicbook like. The guns make little "pew" effects and I love it. The playable characters are also fun as fuck. The one with the rocket launcher built in is most definitely my favorite. The game is HARD, that may be because I play on the hardest difficulty but it makes all of my successes so much more worth it. Anyways that's about it. It's a great game and I recommend it to basically anyone who likes FPS games and roguelikes next to Gunfire Reborn, but I usually say this one is kinda better (in my opinion).

Do you like robots? What about explosions? If yes, then this is the perfect game for you!
In all seriousness, this game is a great mix between the gun-fighting of Doom 2016/Doom Eternal, and the Rouge-like elements of Risk of Rain 2, all tied up in a wonderfully executed comic-book art-style. The entire soundtrack is a major plus too, Noisecream did an amazing job with it, you should probably just go listen to some of their work. Also, the story is very simple, and is almost completely optional, great if you want a chilled out game where your only goal is to blow stuff up.
Some advice: [spoiler] You can rocket jump with ANY explosion, including character-specific abilities. [/spoiler]

Fantastic game with movement that feels similar to overwatch which was a positive for me. Biggest negative is lack of content. The entire game is pretty short. There aren't too many different gun types and some are markedly better than others so you find yourself shoehorned into using a small number of weapons. Items are super super useless. I hate the new trend of roguelikes having items that also have drawbacks. For example deal more damage but move slower or shoot faster but reload slower. Like the whole point of a roguelike is getting stronger don't give me negative effects just let me have the buff.

Every other thing I could say negative falls to a lack of content which  has no real bearing on whether the game was good or not. I suggest getting this on sale since $25 for ~20hrs to finish the whole game is below average playtime. Still really fun and would be even better co op.

I used to play GunFire Reborn to satisfy the niche of FPS Roguelites but this has taken its place. Roboquest is the opposite of the slow pacing of GunFire reborn. This game has a bunch of mechanics that encourage you to go as fast as possible as creatively as possible.

You can:
 -Slide to move faster in short bursts
 -Use explosives to rocket jump across levels
 -Slide on rails to get around fast and dodge projectiles
 -Mario stomp on enemies to bounce up on them to keep your momentum 

I love movement mechanics in games and this just satisfies me greatly. 

There is a great variety of weapons to choose from, but I will say that you will quickly recognize that not all of them are created equal. 

I would also shy away from comparisons to "Doom" and "Borderlands", this game is not like either of those games. People compare it to Doom because you move fast and enemies drop orbs when you die, and people compare it to Borderlands because the weapons have funny colors. 

9/10 well worth the purchase.

What an incredibly streamlined, fun game this little Rogue-like is! 

First, huge props to the devs for including a range of difficulty options. One thing I tend to dislike about thee types of games is the time-investment required to even start making minor progress. By being able to lower the difficulty, the player can quickly unlock most of their upgrades, then kick the difficulty back up when they feel more prepared for the challenge. Which makes the game so much more fun, than frustrating. 

Really dig the art and aesthetics in this one. It has a very unique graphic novel/painterly/cell shaded look to it. But it doesn't really remind me of Borderlands at all. The weapon selections , upgrades, classes and their associated synergies are all extremely fun and add so much replayability to the game. Tack on dozens of hidden areas and secrets, and this game really has a nice fun loop to engage in. Highly recommended if you are looking for a nice motion-focused FPS Rogue-like.

I was afraid the game would get repetitive, but 30 hours in it still manages to pull me back in. This game is really good, both in terms of fps AND rougelite elements. The FPS elements are really fun and satisfying, partially because of the visual style and the guns feel like they have actual power to them thanks to the animation and sound details. It's a movement shooter but I'm pretty sure you can play it boots on the ground style as well if that's more your thing, outside of the boss battles at least. Point is it feels good to play.
I feel like a lot rougelites tend to screw up with upgrades and progression by making them boring and one note, simple stat buffs not forcing you to adapt at all, leading to samey runs and quick repetition. Roboquest takes this common mistake out behind the house and shoots it in the back of the head. There is a ton of variety, not only does each character class feel unique to play, a lot of the upgrades you get in your runs are conditional modifiers incentivizing different playstyles and uses of your abilities, meaning even when picking the same class you can have drastically different runs. Picking the hunter class for example you might lean heavily into the damage of your basic ability and use it to snipe threats with spears while you deal with the less threatening enemies, or you might rely on the clone you leave behind, or you might have a run similar to the one I just did, where you use camo and sneak into groups of enemies and trigger explosions around them as they shoot your clone. Even the most basic character can turn his invincibility shield into an AOE damaging fire bubble, or into a short but powerful DPS steroid, or even both if you get lucky with your options and make it far enough, so don't let me catch you not giving the game a shot. Play the demo, if you like it, you'll like the full game.
Long term progression is actually fairly quick for a rougelite but it feels amazing as the stuff you unlock has a heavy effect on gameplay in a good way. You feel substantially more powerful with each new acquired secret. There is also a kind-of-skill tree that helps make your runs more consistent and give you more options through NPCs, so none of the long term progression is as dumb as "Free damage lol".
They don't even drop the ball with difficulty, it gets really tough, especially towards the end, but if you know how to move, aim and which targets to prioritize, you'll succeed. And if you find it too easy still, well, there are 4 harder difficulties on top of hard mode so you'll find your challenge.
Visually the game is just fun. Outside of the little girl being straight from uncanny valley, it's simple, charming and fun, very obviously comic book-inspired, if you shoot a gun you'll see just how fun that style can be. It's also not cluttered, enemies tend to pop out of the environment, especially their red eyes, which are, of course, crit spots. It supports the gameplay really well.
The story is truly one of the stories of all time. It's short, but there are data logs if story's your thing. It's all very cartoony.
Also, not only is the audio design clean as hell, the soundtrack is full of bangers. One of my favourite parts of this game is fighting the second to last boss because their theme makes me wanna smash something. It's insane how good it sounds.

I got surprisingly addicted to this game recently. I had got it years ago in EA, and thought it was OK. The Devs were cool about totally reworking game mechanics and powers so it was fun to check in to see how it changed. Now it's 1.0 and it's definitely really good. It became my "crack game" where I fiend for it every night after work, trying to beat this challenge or get that achievement etc. 

The shooting and movement is the star of this game. As soon as I found the "duck slide" combo I was hooked. It feels SO good whenever you slide under enemy fire. And you can slide backwards, to the side, etc. There's tons more movement abilities to unlock (I wont spoil) and once you have the whole kit it feels really good.

There's tons of weapons and they're all unique and fun to use, some with some pretty niche uses but if you build into them you can unlock their full potential (like thrown tomahawks that technically do "melee" damage).  Weapons are pretty much either "magazine" based (bullets) or "energy" based (they overheat).  So there's a bunch of cool futuristic energy weapons like shotguns with bouncing projectiles, or homing miniguns. There's a rarity system that applies more and more "affixes" (ie modifiers) to the weapons. So you could have something cool like a Shock Rifle that has a chance to burn enemies, that does more crit damage, and has an alt-fire that shoots out a grenade. 

Something that sets this apart from other FPS games is you do not have to worry about ammo! And your offhand gun auto-reloads when you aren't using it. So it incentives just going ham and swapping weapons when one runs out of ammo. 

Killing enemies gets you XP, and you get a class perk choice when levelling up. It also drops some little green bits of health that heal you a bit. If you're good at avoiding damage you are rewarded with heals between pit-stops. This is also a pretty addicting thing in the game, just hoovering up all those yummy pellets. 

There's 6 classes and they're all really fun and with different styles of play even within the same class. I've played a ton of ||Elementalist|| so that's really fun. 

Throughout the run you'll be able to buy items that give you buffs. Simple things like "energy weapons 15% more damage" to cool ones like "Sliding fires grenades in front of you." These and your levelup perks are the meat of making builds. They usually cost "power cells" which you gain killing enemies and doing parkour challenges. And you earn more if you get a high ranking on a level so you are incentived to play well (measured in game by # of enemies killed and how fast you got through the level). 

The enemies are all varying types of robots. Silver spheres with big red crit spots are what theyre all basically based off. But they are able to make them dinstinct enough that even at a glance in the middle of a fight you can recognize what youre going up with, what attacks they do, etc, so you can prioritize threats. 

There's also tons of little secrets and quests you do throughout each of your runs. These are what unlock permanent upgrades and you definitely want to do them all. I had to look some up. 

My main complaint is that it was kinda annoying for the first dozen runs since you have nothing unlocked in your base tree, for giving you better chances at upgraded weapons and stuff. So youre just stuck with a bunch of white weapons with hardly any affixes. So I wish we powered up the base faster. My tip is to do runs  on an easier difficulty, that will give you a ton of Wrenches (the base upgrade currency). That was faster than me trying to get far on Hard which has increased wrench rewards. My other complaint is that the levels are samey, especially the last bunch ||Haven City, District 13, and the last one|| but thats probably just a me issue cause I've been playing this game for 60 some hours. 

Also it has 2p coop so buy it for a friend and have fun!

An FPS roguelike that does everything right. Super addictive, difficult but fair. Enough health is provided between sections and by enemy drops that you don't feel like taking a little damage stupidly is going to be painful for the entire rest of the run (which some roguelikes do, even the otherwise-perfect Hades). You have good opportunities to both constantly swap out weapons, and also to stick with one you really like and keep upgrading. The weapons are fun and satisfying.

If I had one complaint (and maybe it's a gadget you can unlock; I dunno), it's that I wish you could strafe-run. You can unfortunately only strafe at walking speed. This is still fast enough to dodge all non-tracking projectiles, but it feels sluggish in a game that is otherwise very tight and nimble. Obviously, with the somewhat narrow width of most fight areas, and the fact that enemies aren't leading their shots, this was a very calculated design decision; I'm just a sucker for moving fast. It's not going to make me avoid playing it or anything.

This game slaps, and I couldn't believe I was playing an early access title.
Think DOOM meets toned-down ULTRAKILL meets the Roguelike genre.
The skill ceiling in this game is surprisingly high. I'd tell you how high, but there's clouds in the way.
I usually gravitate towards PvP because players provide a level of dynamic challenge which AI struggles to reach. I find myself constantly being forced out of my comfort zone in a positive way by the surprisingly well-designed enemies. I realize now that it's difficult to BEGIN practicing intermediate and advanced aiming techniques in PvP, because this game is pushing me to truly commit my full 360-degree field of view to muscle-memory like I've never done before. Here, if I miss a shot I take a hit instead of getting sent to the killcam. The less-often I miss my first shot or two after flicking to a new target, the longer I get to survive. This is the workout for my aim that AimLabs wishes it was.

I've played a pre-release version of this game and saw with my own eyes how fundamentally it has changed in just about a year. Definitely recommend, especially the multiplayer, it is made well, had no issues at all!

EDIT: Well, there are things worth mentioning

1. Shown stats are a bit obscure. You cannot see the resulting power that perks and items give you. I think the game would benefit a lot from another info tab with the whole player state

2. For some reason the whole game runs fine except the Haven city level. There I encounter huge FPS drops (144 -> 40)

3. Feels like the game wasn't designed for melee builds. Yes, you have perks and melee weapons and abilities, but it sometimes feels like the game wasn't really designed for melee playthroughs. Grappling hooks adds a ton of power for close combat though

EDIT 2: Actually, forget it, I'm now perfecting the achievement list and what I said here was kinda skill issue, melee is fine, but give it some time... and the grappling hook (unlock all 6 crystals and the orange zone in the city)

4. MP works fine but here and there we encountered small desyncs like the other's nickname was randomly replaced with the ID, or our max HP wasn't shown correctly, or shooting angle was wrong, etc

This game is amazing, I cannot stop playing. The gameplay is fun, the weapons feeling is great, the perks are nice... 
The game really starts to shine when you have collected some mobility gadgets. The jetpack, the rollers, the pogo stick and the grappling hook... With them, the term "fast FPS" really takes on its full meaning. And it's FUN.

But most of all, there's something joyful, light-hearted about this game, between the incredible music, Max's (the girl) personality, the cinematics... Playing this game is the absolute opposite of depressing. It's a change of pace from all these games with heavy and doomful moods. And yet it's not too goofy like Saints Row or Borderlands. Perfect balance. 
I love it.

I've been playing shooters on and off for about 2 and a half decades, and this HAS to be one of the best single-player shooter experiences ever. Hard to believe it isn't a much more popular game. Visuals, audio, soundtrack, movement, combat, items, perks, and weapons are all top-notch. I favor a few classes heavily over others, but even the ones I don't use often are still fun. Roboquest is a rogue-lite, but the FPS elements are just as important as the classes and builds. There is room for error in choosing your upgrades if you can make up for it with raw skill. Your choices of perks, items, and weapons nonetheless make a massive difference. The range of options in that respect is wide enough to allow for multiple effective builds within each class. Your choices will be influenced by chance, too, as you'll have a very limited selection each time you choose an item, weapon, or perk. Weapons are sometimes dropped by enemies, and you can upgrade them by simply finding them later in the game or by paying an NPC with power cells (also dropped by enemies) to upgrade one you already have. There are more enemies than I'll ever care to remember, and even the first 3 of the 4 boss fights can feature different bosses with their own unique attacks. Even the boss arenas differ in terms of their mechanics. I have nothing negative to say about any of the boss fights, either. They vary in difficulty, but there isn't one that makes me want to restart my run. Much like the art style, the weapon system is reminiscent of Borderlands. Though the game can be completed in a 30-40 minute run by many players, the replay value is incredible. Playing through numerous times will allow players to progressively collect more and more wrenches, which are used to buy permanent upgrades. Enemies occasionally drop these upon death throughout runs. Additionally, finding secrets and competing challenges is strongly encouraged by rewarding the player with optional, but very helpful gadgets, which are also permanent. If you want to beat the hardest of SEVEN difficulties, you'd better get those gadgets and spend those wrenches first. Each run is divided into levels, but some levels have multiple exits which change the following levels you play through, though the last few are always the same. Exploring multiple paths through the game is necessary to unlock important items. You only get one life per run, and since runs can be more than half an hour, it's best to start on an easier difficulty and work your way up as you replay over and over while unlocking and learning things. Jumping into hard mode with no upgrades is exceptionally unforgiving, but working your way up is easily worth it. You might want to punch your monitor when you choke a run on the last level, but it's hard to deny how amazing Roboquest is. 100 hours in and I just got my first S-rank and completion on the hardest difficulty in the same run. Now it's just a matter of beating my times, trying out different builds, and finding and unlocking what little I haven't already. Seems like a great game for speedrunning, too, if you're inclined to do that.

I love this game. The perk system, different classes and large gun variety all add quite a lot of replayability. Unlocking all the classes and most other things took me about 15 hours, and since then I've been trying to beat the higher difficulties, and I'm still having a great time. The game is just gorgeous, the music is excellent and the combat is top tier.

Great core gameplay, great roguelite implementation, and absolutely great music.

I don't know how or why but the cadence of the music really fits well with the gameplay and sort of makes me play "in-rhythm".

In relation to other games, Deadlink comes to mind, I think this has a better implementation of roguelite elements. The buffs/perks could be felt in gameplay and most if not all the available options really made me play differently and/or influence my future decisions in picking the next perk or gun.

The game has build variety and randomization that is well executed and reminds me of Binding of Isaac. That feeling of trying to make the most of what the RNG gave you but still giving enough options that you're not fully at the mercy of RNG.

I write this review having played only 3 hours of the game, but I am someone who can easily see the "cracks" in roguelite/roguelike games fairly quickly and already determine if it's a game that I would spend more hours in to. This is one of those games that I will boot back up every now and then for just another run for the fun of it.

(on Hard) and the worst part of it all is that your run ends if you don't make it to the end of the level in time.[/spoiler], [spoiler]Doom Gardens is kind of the same, but has a bit more room for mistakes. Prepare accordingly.[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Duke Nuker was a super obnoxious boss as it felt nearly impossible to beat until I unlocked more items.[/spoiler], but neither of those ruined the game for me. They're really easy to avoid if you aren't ready/don't want to deal with them and can be little to no problem if you prepare accordingly and have the right items. [spoiler]The Rift still sucks though.[/spoiler]

Started off absolutely loving it having a blast solo and the movement progression as you unlock gadgets makes the game feel fantastic and not too overwhelming. TONS of weapons to choose from & even with only a few classes at the moment there is multiple ways to play/approach every class. This game is like the Apex Legends of Roguelikes. Think Gunfire but with movement. The gunplay is extremely satisfying and unlike many other games like this, there are actually a lot of really fun guns. Many other games just have a lot of weird and wacky guns, which are more interesting than they're actually fun or viable to use. 

The movement really makes for an incredibly fast paced gameplay flow which feels incredibly satisfying when you really get into it. 

I can't talk too much about the abilities, since there is really only one character I truly enjoy, but the characters are very varied, so I'm sure many people will find something that suits them the best. 

The progression and difficulty is also great, letting you really feel how every new unlock changes the game in in interesting ways. And beating this game for the first time actually took me nearly 20 hours, so you'll be feeling out a lot of the game and getting more familiar with things as you slowly work your way through more of the game.

Iz good, one of the best in the genre, quality wise, the only bad thing about this game is that you can probably get all achievements in under 50 hours. So then you have done most of the things. Luckily doing different builds is also a lot of fun, and the crisp gun-play might also keep you around.

Great roguelite fps. Basically in the most broadest of terms, Doom mixed with borderlands, risk of rain and overwatch. I only really have 2 complaints. 
First, weapons phasing through the ground occasionally when dropping them. Second, Haven city bosses almost forcing you to have a certain amount of damage output when you get to the boss, for example having only one small platform to dodge after everything else is covered in sludge. 
But even then these are both quite minor gripes, the weapon phasing out glitch has only happened to me on 3 occasions, and the haven city boss complaint can always be chalked up to a lack of skill.

Game is absolutely fantastic! Everything I could ask for in a Doom-like Rogue-like shooter!
[list]
[*]The speed of combat is incredibly satisfying and tricky to master.
[*]The different Robo powers really spice up the gameplay to have you try out different approaches to getting through the levels.
[*]Weapon variety also adds a ton to each run as you'll have to work with what you're given, adapting your play to the kinds of weapons you've selected.
[*]Grades/rewards for speed and XP give solid incentive to be as quick and efficient as possible in each level.
[*]World environments change up every other level or so, helping to insure a diverse set of enemies and challenges.
[*]OST is heavy and awesome. Also is dynamic and ramps up when you enter/leave combat which enhances the game's peaks and valleys of action.
[/list]
Game has gone on my favorites list and is one I'll return to regularly over time.

I'm very glad to take Roboquest off of my playlist and onto my favorites, because this is another fantastic contender for best FPS Roguelike, alongside Gunfire Reborn.

That being said, the quality can be a little... everywhere? Gameplay feels great, which is obviously the most important thing, but art can be a little questionable (I'm looking at you, loading screen chipmunk Max). Character designs can feel a little repetitive, but weapon designs look gorgeous. It's confusing to me; but the end product is fantastic. Honestly, a lot of my gripes with the game probably have to do with the fact that this is a fresh team out of college and this is their first video game.

Overall, Roboquest is a great showing from a relatively new game studio. I can't wait for what is next for both Roboquest and this studio!

I'll be honest, this game took a bit to grab me, but I'm so glad I gave it a chance. Sort of a mixture of Overwatch/Borderlands gunplay with a roguelike gameplay loop. Unlocking the different classes is a fun early goal (the engineer is my fave), and the sheer number of weapons in the game is staggering. They have some GREAT homage weapons clearly inspired by other famous firearms, including the bolter from Warhammer 40k, the flak cannon from Unreal Tournament, and Hanzo's bow from Overwatch. The soundtrack is fantastic as well, and the sound design overall is great -- the game does a great job of playing certain sounds when you hit critical spots on enemies. Gunplay feels great, you can double jump and slide. Yeah, it's fun.
This is an incredibly polished game, and a must play for people who like fast paced fps games. Its like a Doom roguelite with a more accessible art style. This is gonna blow up soon, I'm sure.

A short review because I'm still addicted to this game and wanted to sing its praises real quick before I forgot to later. I got this game initially for my partner and I because she is a huge borderlands fan. This game and Gunfire Reborn were the only two that people said online scratched that looter shooter itch. We played Gunfire Reborn quite a bit and found it to be pretty fun, but a few things always irked me personally when we got into a run. The main thing that frustrated me was that attention was always split between the dozens of weapons dropping all over the place, and since you can't hold anything besides what you have equipped the pace of the level would always slow down to a snails pace as everyone had to stop at each arena to look at the weapons. 

Roboquest in comparison has a timer, with small rewards tied to how fast you go on each stage. It's not enough to frustrate if you can't quite meet the S rank, but it does give that little reward for you to take risks and keep runs quick. The game balances that with many spaces designed as hubs where the timer pauses and you can spend some time really figuring out your build. Almost all of your weapons and upgrades are here in these little safe places. This means when you need to level up, pick a weapon and/or item, you're doing it in one place and can know if you'll have what you need to make that synergy work. It seems to make those decisions happen faster while preserving this flow between different combat encounters in a level. If not for all that, I don't think most players would grind on railings and rocket jump as much, and that would be really tragic.

If that doesn't interest you, I'll have you know, even non-explosive weaponry can get the rocket jump ability and fairly early on you can reliably acquire an orange quality shovel with the ability. Beating enemies to death with a unique shovel before rocket jumping away makes you feel like a superhero. And its just a tiny slice of this game.

If I was to "elevator pitch" Roboquest, it'd be "Borderlands meets DOOM, wrapped in a roguelike". It combines the cartoon/comic-book aesthetic of Borderlands as well as its RPG mechanics and "out there" weaponry with unique firing modes and alt-fires with DOOM's more finetuned action combat, where being quick on your feet and quick to defeat enemies are what win the day.

The roguelike aspect mainly comes from what weapons show up in your runs, or what perks you get as you level up. The stages themselves do not change, allowing you to refine your playthrough with each death, as well as keep track of each sidequest and secret to come back to it later without much concern. It's easy to fumble the tightrope of action fps gameplay with rpg mechanics; very often you end up unloading untold amounts of ammunition into enemies while they can cleave a third of your health with a single stray, but Roboquest does a far better job than most in balancing them.

Very fun game, with some really neat ideas. Very replayable, especially when you realise that you need to collect things from later levels to unlock things in early levels. Also, learning to 'stack' your uprgrades and weapon choices as you progress each run through is really fun.
What a gem! It's a game you can simply hop on and off at any time you want after having a blast!

What a wonderful, wonderful gem of a game. 

Roboquest is an FPS-meets-Roguelike, with just a dash of the good parts of Borderland's and Destiny's random weapon generation.

Tight, fast paced movement - especially with everything unlocked - makes the game a moment to moment joy. You're rewarded for getting inclose with headbonks, the ability to bounce off an enemy's head and do extra damage. Add in a wonderful array of guns, all of whom feel wonderful to shoot by base, and excellent class design - six of them, all with reasons why you'd want to play them, and it's just a joy.

My one big criticism is the game does use a meta progression system, which i'm not a fan of. Thankfully, as these things go it's not that grindy to get everything unlocked, and the exploration aspects are rewarding. Still, it's a sour point for me - your mileage may vary. 

It's also tough as hell - Even experienced FPS vets like myself will benefit from dropping the difficulty initially, and working your way up. But once you get rolling... oh my! 

Huge fun. If you like single player FPSes, and you enjoy repeatability, you owe it to yourself to play this.

Roboquest is a wierd title that should not work in theory. A looter-shooter rogue lite with cooldown abilities sounds like a nightmare but for some reason this exact combination fixes all the problems i have with both looter-shooters and with rogue likes/lites. 

The biggest problem a looter-shooter has is the fact that, if you dont find a good weapon, enemies usually sponge up and it becomes a drag to play. The biggest problem of the rogue like/lite games is usually that starting from point zero is pretty boring, especially if you did it for a few times.

So why does Roboquest have neither of these problems? Because the rogue lite nature of the game allows it to give you way more powerful guns than a looter shooter, since farming isnt really a thing. And the rogue lite problem of starting at point zero? Also not a problem since the core combat is a fast paced almost arena shooter like experience where even the movement is fun. The last part that i usually would have a problem with are cooldown abilities, but since the cd is pretty low on most of them it feels like a nessasity to have something that does reliable damage without being overpowered where weapons wouldnt matter anymore.

Thats of course just the surface of the game, with unlockable classes and and a ton-load of weapons with different affixes to find, as well as the super fun passives you get on level up which can completely change how you play the game. The time a run usually takes feels pretty solid as well, with usually 30mins to an hour its a perfect game to jump in, have fun for a while and then do something else.

Right now the game feels like a hidden gem, and with the right support from the devs it has the potential to become a cult classic, highliy recommended
One of the most fun roguelites I've played. Can't wait to see whats next

Truly a wonderful game.

Dead Cells + Borderlands. Bunch of weapons with randomised affixes to give them boosts. Strong mobility with slides, bhopping and rocket jumping. A decent selection of class types, all with two unique abilities and their own pools of perks to improve and evolve them.

Average runtime for me so far has been 25-30 minutes to beat the final boss on standard difficulty. So it's not so long you get frustrated from dying, but not so short that your progression feels useless during a run.

Only real issue is that weapon scaling feels too low near the last few levels. Class abilities start to FAR out do any damage you can do with a weapon, even with 'optimised' affixes. Ranger's Javelin, Elementalist's Trinity and Comet and Commando's Shorty do so much damage that any regular weapon pales in comparison. So maybe an increase in how much of a damage increase weapons get for every level could be neat.

I enjoy this game. A solid shooter with roguelike elements. 

What I enjoyed:
Full key rebinding for ESDF players like myself. 
Performance is good on my rig with 4 year old equipment.

Very nice to weave around the arena shooting robots and destroying them.
Finding secrets is fun and something to look forward to, that also makes your future runs more interesting as it opens up more options for acquiring gear and different paths you can take, like Dead Cells.
The soundtrack is very nice. I already like electronic music, and the Cyberpunk/Dark Electro/EBM/DnB music adds to the frantic nature of combat.
Adding on to that, the combat does have moments where I feel stressed due to the difficulty and relieved when I escape the combat encounter alive. 
Switching weapons is fun as your non-equipped weapon reloads automatically while you have the other weapon out. This means that you spend more time shooting and dealing damage instead of reloading and getting caught.
The weapons themselves have interesting designs and feel very nice to shoot. Though not all the weapons are "lips out" good, there are some that are. 

What I don't like:
Shooting enemies doesn't really have feedback besides flashing white and your gun's effects. 
Enemies don't really react to most gunshots as in there isn't any sort of visual damage or sparking effects. Sure there is an ice overlay when you do enough cryo damage or burn damage, but nothing for normal shots unless you stagger them with a big weapon.
Ragdolls and bits happen for big enemies, but smaller/normal sized ones just disappear and in a puff when they die.
Once you crest the progression hill into the "Endgame" it feels a little same-y from run to run. This is where I will compare the game to the only other Roguelike FPS I have: Gunfire Reborn.
I do have 341 hours in-game (steam hours include afk and menu time) on GFR and while the game has its problems, I would say GFR is a Roguelike FPS while Roboquest is an FPS Roguelike.
While Roboquest has better shooting and movement mechanics, GFR leans way more (maybe too much) into the roguelike elements that allow your runs to be consistently OP broken screen melting strong. There are more opportunities in GFR to have weird, strong, and playstyle defining interactions between weapons and your character. Roboquest leans a lot more on your personal aiming skill to make your run. Granted, there are some broken classes like Engineer with broken elemental interactions but they do not feel the same level of OPness as certain combos in GFR.
Part of this is due to weapon affixes in RQ as they don't have crazy affixes that drastically change the weapon and how it interacts with other parts of your run. Extra firerate, reload speed, less movement speed penalty for heavy weapons, etc means that run-to-run the SMG will feel the same as it did 5 runs ago because the affixes do not change a lot.

I still enjoyed my time with this game and plan to keep playing in the future. RQ has a lot of potential and I do recommend for players who love shooting games with a little bit of roguelike sprinkling in them.

EDIT: Some of my cons were my own inexperience with the game. There is an enemy stagger mechanic, but only with certain weapon types and affixes. There is more depth to perk synergy than I previously thought, and it can affect your build and weapon choice as well. 1.1 update was a welcome addition to the game. I still highly recommend this game if you enjoy this genre.

It gets my adrenaline pumping every time. Big recommend.

In short: think Gunfire Reborn, but with its own identity and just as good.

Excellent handling, fast and enjoyable combat.
I don't get other reviews that say there isn't enough perk variety - depending on the level-up choices runs with the same class can be wildly different.

Difficulty curves can feel a bit steep and iffy at times, especially when you are starting out and lack workshop (think: permanent) upgrades - there's a big jump in difficulty when you first enter the Fields map and some later bosses feel a tad too hard compared to the map they are in - but that might only be a me thing. Also, getting gadgets unlocked will help massively with movement which in turn helps to avoid damage.

Furthermore, it's a bit hard to increase things like movement speed or armor by getting items and most of the corrupted items seem to always be a bad idea to get.

But when these and the feeling there should just be "more" are my only gripes, it means I really enjoyed it.

+ Very fun and smooth shooter roguelike with good quality-of-life features.
- The characters and music are a little generic and par for the course,
+ but the game has enough charm to keep you interested, especially with the little robots.
+ After 5 hours I feel like I still have a lot of guns to see, and only unlocked half of the characters.

Try the demo, and if you like it, then the full game will resume you right where you left off (even if you uninstall the demo beforehand). This game is genuinely pretty groundbreaking in what it does and how well it does it.

I bought it for 25% off at 18.74 USD

EDIT: at around 15 hours I finally found my first legendary weapon. This game's loot economy is honestly great. I hated it in Borderlands 3 when they gave you a legendary 20 minutes into the game for checking a vending machine, and then by the midgame your inventory is exclusively legendaries and it muddies the waters and robs the player of excitement. As Syndrome once said, "If everyone's super, no one is." And if all of my loot is legendary, then none of it is.

I also got to the final boss (and died), and the game's difficulty really ramps up towards the end (rightfully so). It feels great to play on hard mode, I strongly recommend it if you can handle it. The game really fits the bill for chaotic mouse+keyboard movement shooter fun. It also lets you snipe or shoot a bow or crossbow from afar.

I will say the player characters are pretty unbalanced. The invincibility character and ranger have such better surviveability and I can't get far with any other characters.

Gotta be my favourite release of 2023, and you know there were some amazing games that year! 

The music is PHENOMENAL, Noisecream really made an OST of exclusively bangers. Definitely listen to their work both from roboquest and from their back catalogue! Can't recommend it enough. Favourite track is probably "Entropy". 

The movement and gunplay is fantastic, I find myself entering a "flow state" very easily regardless of what weapon or build I have at the time. The abilities, weapons, movement and especially the headbonking mechanic (think bouncing off a goomba) all meld together to where I feel like I don't have to even think about how I traverse or what target I prioritise, my brain and body just somehow know. Sound design on the guns and abilities is also great, meaning I can focus a lot on the action and know when abilities have recharged, when I killed an enemy with a critical hit, etc. If I could ask for anything more on the sound design, it'd just be a more distinct sound for your main ability so when it recharges it cuts through the rest of the audio to make sure you can hear it well, sometimes I can't hear the sound effect all that well and forget my ability is up. 

The visuals are great! I love the comic book style, the silhouettes are great for an action game, the onomatopoeia is a FANTASTIC touch, and animations are great all around! I prefer more stylized games to realism, so roboquest is exactly the kind of commitment to a striking style that I want in a game. 

Runs take about 35-50 minutes, 25 if you're really blazing through, which I found to be perfect! Although I am hoping there will be an update with some kind of post-final boss extension (a la voidling in risk of rain 2) so I can really test a build against an unreasonably hard challenge if it just blasted through the game. I find there's few builds in this game that allow me to effortlessly clean house, but it would be cool to have a fight tough enough to see how far they can really get pushed. 

And on the topic of builds, I love the perk system in this game! There's a few basic stat boost perks, and then you can collect up to 4 main perks, each having 2 sub perks. Most of the time I found that choosing my 4 main perks and maxing out on sub perks before picking up stat boosts was the way to go, but I'm starting to experiment with leaving some sub perks behind to focus on stat buffs. Hopefully either new skills are introduced or more synergies will be added later, excited to see how they develop :)

Overall Roboquest is absolutely a buy, deluxe edition and all, it's the most fun I've had with a roguelike since Risk of Rain 2! Lovely devs, super well thought out gameplay loop, pretty pictures, banger music, and coop is cross platform and pretty great! Seriously consider buying at any price, support these devs! They're putting something amazing into the indie scene and I'm very happy to be a customer of theirs :)

I played and enjoyed this game all the way through early access. I've been patiently waiting for them to get over the hump and release fully, but despite the game being loads of fun to play, the optimization is abysmal.

The amount of power required to run the game is insane for what it is. The game is only about 4.35gb and it requires easily double what it takes to run a game like Call of Duty. That's not a good look fellas. You're an indie studio, the vast majority of players are running sub-optimal machines. When the game crashes, it doesn't just crash the game, it crashes the whole bloody computer. Full shutdown. If you're running anything less than a 4000 series GPU and an i9, steer clear of this one. I've also got about 48gb of RAM and still getting issues. I've tried several times to share my feedback over on the discord, but either the Devs don't care, or they can't deign to respond to lowly customers. Either way, be sure you have a lights out PC or make sure they've updated since this review to alleviate this issue.

Seems the crashes have resolved, but when I returned to try again, I got stuck in the environment on the first run. I've posted the issues to the discord and attempted to explain issues before, but each time I get verbally assaulted by other users who are more than happy to curse out people highlighting faults in favor of patting the devs on the back and driving honest feedback from their community. What a time to be alive. Don't waste your time.

As an avid gamer of Roguelite games, this was an amazingly fun play. The game is like a cross between "Borderlands" gun styles, "Gunfire Reborn" amped up version of map procedures, and parkour like "Warframe".

You will certainly find yourself screaming "Parkour! Parkour!" as you hop around from grind rails to cliffsides and cities.

The combat scales from brainlessly easy to impossibly difficult without strategies. There are some really fun combinations to build out for each of the classes whos abilities empower certain functionalities.

Barely any upgrades through out the run that get to stack resulting in whacky/funny interactions. Just a dps check. Who cares what element you are or how often you proc miserable bonus perks, when it is just crit chance + crit damage check.

Maps are lame-ish. WHile it says they are randomly generated, that is basically Warframe's approach with segments of maps, premade chunks to connect to each other. They all feel the same, and end game stages basically the same. City, corrupted city, moon arenas. Considering that the run is 20-35 minutes depending on the wish to skip some xp along the way, that is half an hour restarting same room 40 times to then nuke it with bullet sponge bosses sprinkled along the way.

Purple-corrupted rooms and bosses change drastically after unlocking jetpack and grappling hook. Suddenly, most of the damage can be avoided by simply pressing E on a wall.

>>>

Doing new run seems like forcing myself to try clunky approaches with weapons/perks just for the sake of it. I am not upset when the run ended, since fun ended. I am happy when the run ended, since I get to turn that off.

Also, for some weird reasons it doesn't save the runs mid-progress? Not sure if that's just my problem, but that is just weird.
