An absolute surprise hit for me. I accidentally stumbled upon this gem and didn't regret it. The movement and gunplay in RoboQuest feel so extremely good and are so satisfying, the game would even be fun without the roguelite structure around it - I could spend hours playing this as a single-room arcade high-score-hunting game. This is what makes the game really work; the moment-to-moment gameplay is just so fluid and smooth.

The roguelite elements definitely build on and add to it. Don't expect crazy builds like in Isaac - the weapons and perks you'll find are quite tame. There are definitely synergies, but the build meta never extends a lot beyond "I picked a good perk for explosives, so I'll stick to an explosive weapon and other explosives-related perks". This also means that your chances of success don't depend that much on your build, but more on learning the enemies and environments, which I really appreciate. Beating an area for the first time makes you feel like you're really getting the hang of it, rather than just having gotten lucky with RNG.

Be aware that - as far as my experience goes - you can't save mid-run. The game doesn't make this very clear, but quitting and restarting the game places you back at the hub area. Runs take between 15-45min, so it's good to plan in enough time to finish a session.

I can really recommend this game to everyone who likes fast-paced, movement-heavy arcade shooters.

Roboquest falls into a fairly recent sub-genre of roguelites that's been gaining a lot of traction, especially among the boomer shooter crowd (people that live and breathe games like Doom 2016 / Eternal, ULTRAKILL, DUSK, etc).

I believe the genre term that's catching on is 'roguelite arena shooter'. It combines the room-clearing stage progression of roguelites like Hades and Gungeon with the fast-paced FPS kicks of games like the ones I mentioned above. So imagine if Hades were a first person shooter, or ULTRAKILL was a roguelite. That's what Roboquest is going for. If you've played and loved games like Deadlink or Voidborn then you know it's a very compelling combination, and Roboquest hits the target dead center.

The main ingredients are all here. Weapons feel great to use, the many types and affixes make trying new stuff attractive and important, the different classes all feel unique and effective in their own ways, the movement and gunplay is top notch. It's hitting all of the expected parts in spades. You can headbonk enemies like Mario, rocket jump like Quake, and grind on rails for speed boosts like it's a Tony Hawk Pro Skater game.

But I think what I really like about this particular game is how meta progression is done. There is - of course - the currency-based meta progression; you accrue 'wrenches' during runs that you can spend between runs to acquire various upgrades like increased levels and rarities of drops, better offering from the NPCs in safe rooms, starting the run with extra powerups - the typical offerings. This makes every run feel impactful in *some* way, even if you do terribly or don't dabble in any of the other things I'm about to get into.

But there are multiple OTHER layers of meta progression, and all of the ones outside of the wrenches require you to complete certain objectives in the runs themselves. The game immediately makes it clear that there are multiple routes and side stages you can try to clear (that are usually a lot harder). Across and between these stages you can uncover various secrets that culminate in extra permanent ingame boosts for your character to make future runs easier and more varied. And these secrets take many forms, from unlocking doors to open up permanent reward rooms / extra routes, simple collectibles you pick up to get a permanent reward after so many finds, to clearing entire sub-routes to acquire a unique ability, or fulfilling quests for various NPCs so they help you out in the future.

It's rather comprehensive, and a very fun extra layer of gameplay that I don't think has been so well done in other games of its type. Some of the 'puzzles' are fairly straightforward and simple to clear for their goodies, but others require some thought, or thorough exploration of the game's many stages to figure out the solution. I love it, and want to do them all.

This game is everything I have wanted in a game for a while. Roguelike/lite with cell-shaded graphics (I adore this style thanks to Borderlands). I have wanted to see a FPS roguelike/lite for a long time and now I have it. The fast-paced gameplay reminds me a lot of many boomer shooters like Doom, Ultrakill, Dusk, etc. This inclusion of explosions being able to propel you also gives a very boomer shooter feel and I love it. The weapons themselves have a very Overwatch/Borderlands vibe to them and they just feel amazing for someone who has played both of those games extensively. The change in the form of the lowered crosshair felt weird at first yet after a few runs in my mind has completely changed. The crosshair is a change but now I hit shots that I think I wouldn't hit without that. There is so much I could say about this game but I want to leave some of these things for the other players to discover for themselves. I got Roboquest on sale but I would 100% pay full price for it. If you like Roguelikes/lites, FPS games, boomer shooters, or just games in general, you should play Roboquest. P.S. I have yet to try multiplayer as no friends have Roboquest but I imagine that it is just as good if not better when looking at the rest of the game.

My buddy and I have weekends a couple times a year where we meet up and play video games for an entire weekend. Despite our love for video games, especially shooter types, we are constantly disappointed in video games.  We bought the game for the weekend and we were blown away. We put 30 hours into the game in 1 weekend, most games we get about half that in a weekend. We were non stop playing, as soon as we would lose, we'd start back up again, trying to figure out what we needed to do to get further than last time. This game is amazing, it's entertaining the entire time you're playing. We were blown away by the amount of quality of life things in the game. We were blown away that perks like the jet pack were one of the best jet packs I've used in a game. The guns are all so fun. The enemies make sense. The bosses are a healthy challenge. Over and over we were blown away.

The only thing worth noting is there are a lot of secrets in the game. They put something in front of you but it's not obvious what you're supposed to do with it. YOU HAVE TO DO THE SECRETS. If you can't figure out why you just can't get any further, focus on this. Instead of having to look them up on google or youtube the game should help you, but it just leaves you hanging. Search All Secrets Roboquest on Youtube and you'll get what you need to feel like you're actually progressing.

The list of media this game pulls its inspiration from is as thick as a sludge, and I'm happy to say that Roboquest- despite the shovelware basic name- outpreforms and outdoes ALL of them in niche little categories. Except borderlands, Roboquest outdoes borderlands 3 a million times over.
This game is everything I have wanted out of the looter shooter and movement shooter genre forever. With a lower movement skill ceiling not requiring constant practice, and a roguelite gameplay loop to give the player that time anyways it never feels like I'm wasting my time with my actions. Every gun has a lot of impact, every class feels fun and different, it's absolutely wonderful.
I think the only thing possibly holding Roboquest back is the caps (movement speed and armor have relatively low caps, highest difficulty is hard, abilities have relatively tame scaling). Truth be told, this game needs to embrace being broken in half. Higher difficulties, higher caps, difficulty-ramping items and modifiers along, just make shit go wild. Add nukes!
Regardless, still the most fun I have ever had with this genre, 100% worth it, try the demo NOW, your progress will carry over if you get the full game.

Roboquest is an awesome game.

It captures the high-speed gameplay and fun gimmicks of movement shooters while also offering a wide variety of guns to play around with. Your character's progression within a run offers a healthy splash of variety too; I generally don't feel pigeonholed into specific strategies but I'm often tempted to try something different or new. Sometimes because a strategy seems strong, but most often just because I'm excited to see how it'll play out. The game's core - movement and gunplay - is rock solid and it makes exploring every facet of gameplay a joy.

The demo's a great way to test the core mechanics out and check the netplay with your pal. Play through a couple of zones and try out a boss fight! It's worth noting that the game's much more expansive than the demo (a full playthrough can take around an hour or so) and features significantly more weapon and enemy(!) variety.

I had some concern after a string of demo playthroughs that the game might grow stale, but there's plenty to discover in the full game, don't worry!

So, with all of that said, I recommend this game without reservation. Try out the demo and see if this particular flavor of FPS appeals to you. If it does, throw on some headphones, grab a friend, get ready - it's going to be a wild ride.

Editing my review now that the game has exited beta:

Roboquest is an almost perfect blend of masterclass gunplay, movement, level design, and all around fast paced action. If you are a considerable fan of DOOM movement/combat and you like the art direction and design of Borderlands, you will find yourself unable to put this game down. In fact, it almost feels like a disservice by comparing this game to others, because this indie game pushes it's boundaries and the genre as a whole to it's utmost limit. It is truly in a realm of its own.

In short: Buy this game. It is worth your hard-earned time.

I've tried to get into RoboQuest several times, both via the demo and now purchasing the full game, to see what all the "Overwhelmingly Positive" fuss is about, and I simply CANNOT understand it.

This game is boring! Boring!!! You stand, and you shoot, and that's literally it! I can feel my eyelids getting heavy playing this game; it requires no interesting movement, planning, or strategy whatsoever. You camp one weapon, click your left mouse button 20 or 30 times, and then proceed to the next zone. Weapons feel (and sound) like they're made of tin cans, enemy design is painfully generic, and environmental design is completely forgettable. RQ feels cheap, stiff, and lacking in personality. And no, adding some "pow" text when you shoot a gun doesn't count as personality when the maps are the equivalent of dollar-store Borderlands levels from 2009.

Compared to Deadlink, the action, mobility, and weapon impact of RQ are laughable. Compared to Gunfire Reborn, buildcraft and weapon generation are hilariously shallow. RoboQuest is worse than these games --and I'm not exaggerating-- in EVERY respect. I genuinely cannot think of a reason why you would play RQ over either of those two titles. RQ does nothing better and everything worse. 

If you want to play a roguelite FPS, I urge you to play one of those games instead. If you want highly mobile, hair-trigger, DOOM-style adrenaline, play Deadlink. If you want deep buildcraft, character action, and Borderlands-style looting, play Gunfire Reborn. RQ isn't worth your money. I don't even think it's worth your time -- I wouldn't play this game even if it were free. It's that dull! 

I am refunding this game right now. Buyer beware!

This is my first review:

I started playing this in early access and now it having a full on release I an extremely happy with the process/development to this point.

Roboquest really plays with its variety of multiple genres but gives us viability that even allows you to play it as a boom shooter, arena, or a typical run n gun some sense, with its enemies constantly blazing your with ammo like a bullet hell. Roboquest is a punishing game with everything you do being calculated after multiple runs to even its multiplayer expanding on creating in sync teamwork towards advancing to the next level, sometimes its level design is a lil bit overcrowded or lack of even walls to go behind it still allows you and your fellow friend to work together in stopping the robots of this world. The music is bumpy and the color is cute, playing on an overwatch/borderlands aesthetic. I would say that this game isn't meant for everyone but if you do pick up this game itll be a worth while.

Fast-paced but fair combat, upgrades that make you feel powerful, well balanced difficulties, amazing gunplay, secrets, unlocks, a great soundtrack, and loads more. Just about everything this game does is done perfectly.
if you like darksouls and FPS shooters and speed running this game is for you.
It's like Hades, Dead Cells, Rouge Legacy 2, etc.  but a FPS and gun collector like borderlands.  Great movement, great game play loop, great game.

The game has a ton of unlockables and mini quests to keep encouraging that "one more run" mentality. This game is best experienced with a friend. You both unlock paths together. You get your own weapon choices, so you're never fighting over a rare weapon. The classes feel unique. The guns feel like they hit. 

Is this game revolutionary? No. Much like valheim, this game simply ties together established, fun mechanics in a great package.

Very fun. Environments are beautiful, varied and recognizable, with secrets to encourage exploring. Guns feel great and varied, and you're encouraged to constantly be swapping them. Nice sense of progression.

I will say the bosses do get a bit ridiculous. I'm playing on Hard (hardest difficulty) so take that into account. Starting off it's just circling some idiot robot who will never hit you. Then suddenly it's like, oh the floor is lava and the boss is on a giant looping rail and laying mines on the rail so you have to dodge the mines + lasers while also shooting the boss. Or it's a giant brawler guy who runs up to you to try and punch you, then IMMEDIATELY after missing a punch, launches a stun grenade in your face, followed up by punching you again and nuking half your health bar. Or it's a big guy on a giant wall rail climbing up a tower while the floor is rising lava, so you have to climb the tower with it while also dodging fire. And if you don't kill him fast enough then you only get a tiny tiny platform to work with. Good luck doing that one without any of the jump/jetpack upgrades.

Overall, it's fun, but can be slightly frustrating to consistently lose to the final boss because it's just not practical to dodge all the crap it throws at you.

Edit: Oh yeah, there's currently not any way to save your current run. So if your game crashes or you need to exit the game mid-run, back to the start for you. But they're supposedly working on it. Just note that I've had about 6-7 crashes in my ~20 hours of playtime.

another example as to why gamers need to stop consuming triple A schlock and take the time to find GOOD games. everything about this game is masterful, most of which (to me) being the music. 

HOLY HELL THE MUSIC. tracks go unbelievably hard and ive added a majority of them to my library, they match the environments theyre placed in perfectly, and (maybe its just my schizo brain) have beats that consistently line up with gunshots and gameplay like its metal hellsinger without the player putting in effort. 

The inspiration in gameplay cannot be narrowed down to even a single genre, as there are clear bits of borderlands, ultrakill, hades, overwatch, furi, and many many more titles. This is not a bad thing in the slightest as the devs use this inspiration how it should be, as inspiration for their own unique concepts. Gameplay is fast but not as fast as others you may be used to, and the rougelike systems (while maybe taking a bit to start to roll out) are very in depth and can allow for some very different builds with the class system. There are so many different guns that come with so many different perks and attachments that may seem overbearing but are actually very accessible if you just use your eyeballs. 

For a 25 dollar game there is a ton of replayability even outside of a normal run (which if in-depth enough can come out to almost an hour per full run) with power crystals, a basecamp to upgrade, secrets to find in literally every area, challenge rifts, and a ton of more content to come if you look at the roadmap on their discord. (im excited for this damn game, its so cool.) Plus, its got coop. Yeah its only two players, but ITS GOT CROSSPLAY COOP. Get this game. 

Story, while simple and maybe a little childish, is still fun to watch through the beautifully done cutscenes that take place in this surprisingly stunning world. The little girl companion makes for a good figure to see the world through (since you play as a cold hunk of steel) and can honestly be pretty motivating with her mid-run checkpoint dialogue during a tense run if you arent a cold dead asshole. A plot revolving around an evil AI in 2023 may be a little contrived but i dont think it would drop the game any points at all. Turn your brain off to the stylish robot mayhem in the cutscenes and enjoy, we both know you arent here for a super in depth narrative. 

I've barely scratched the surface of this gem but the quality and polish is insane. I can't wait to see what RyseUp has in store for Roboquest down the road!

Positive: 
- Fluid, satisfying and fast-paced gameplay
- Fantastic variety in weapons, classes and playstyles
- Great replayability
- Good amount of different levels with plenty of variety
- Great audio and visual design
- Abundance of upgrades, secrets and collectables with well-paced progression
- Charming NPC design

Negative:

- Story is basic and fairly forgettable
- Random generation within individual levels is fine but not great
- Inability to save midrun (the developers have mentioned in an announcement that this will be addressed in an upcoming update)

A really nice roguelite. I may even like it more than Risk of Rain 2, and i sinked quite a few hours in RoF2. Game strikes good balance between being (relatively) hard on standard difficulty, but giving the Player a senso of progression. As with most roguelites - it's difficult to separate progression in terms of skill vs progression resulting from unlocked (persistent) classes, skills & upgrades. No matter - IT JUST WORKS.

Movement is swift & very responsive. If You hit a rock or a ledge - 99% it's just Your fault and You will get better. Gunplay is amazing - most guns feel different but satisfactory. What's important - the variety supports different builds & playstyles. One can go for critical dmg with sniper rifles, AOE mayhem with explosives, or any shades in between.

Skill classes are well thought through, with (most if not all) having either upgrade paths or good synergies with other skills and different weapon types (& playstyles).

The only thing some people may find jarring is music. Not that it's bad - but not everyone may enjoy this genre (check gameplays on YT). 

Overall - fantastic game - worth picking not only during Steam sale periods!

A breath of fresh air in the genre of roguelite shooters. Though the content is not particularly long (around 15 hours) the quality is quite high in every aspect of the game.

Okay, after playing 9hrs of this game, I can kinda gauge how I feel about this game.

Let me get this out of the way, its a [b]good game no doubt[/b]. Game mechanic wise, gameplay, its there. Story, errrr.... dont know much about it or dont care about it enough.

Now, why do I give it a negative review but said its a good game. My problem of the game lies with its locked progression. To put it simply, [b] a lot of perks ( like jet pack and etc ) + character classes are locked behind very difficult hidden secrets [/b] to the point that either you have to look through a Youtube guide or do at least 60hrs runs to unlock it. And because you are trying to unlock the perks and classes, you either spend 60hrs+ on it OR you put it under the easiest settings and just run through the game multiple times ( which dampens the entire mood of the game because you are just speedrunning everything to get everything ). You might be asking "Just do a 60hrs run then and unlock it slowly?". Yes, you are right, but also what's the point of doing multiple runs with not having the full experience of the perks & classes. Why do I have to play "said hidden class character" after 60hrs in because for some reason, its locked behind some hidden secret stuffs. 

The other problem I have with the game is that the music is uhh boring. Thats more or less it. Listening to it after the 10th time, I just mute the audio because it isnt that good. It's not Persona 5 level good, its not Hades level good. It's just average, and average is bad for a game you have to play 10+ hrs in. Yes, everyone has their own taste and preference but you have to make a music universally good though and this isnt. 

Basically, to sum it up, [b] I'm missing out the full experience of the game because some important stuffs are hidden therefore I am forced to brute force it by playing it on the easiest settings by watching Youtube guide which ruin my experience of the game because I expected a difficult game as its a roguelite game but I'm playing on the easiest to unlock everything first. And the music sux [/b].

[b]My idea on how to reworked this[/b]

Make all the guns slowly unlocked by a leveling system. That way, players are more keen to play more and more to unlocked more potential weapons. Then add some in game bonus where if you want a particular weapon, you can "buy" it. [b]THIS IS NOT A MICRO-TRANSACTION IDEA[/b]. This idea is to give players to pick weapons they prefer and also allows players to quickly complete the entire weapon catalog. 

The perks and classes should honestly be an achievement thing, i.e beat this boss to unlock this perks and classes, not HIDDEN behind some hidden room that you need to run 5 times to get what you need. 

Also pls have a guide map as to which room leads to which bosses and stuffs. I think the crystal idea is okay but you need some sort of map to indicate which rooms leads to which crystal and stuffs. Kinda wasteful to create a mini boss, only to fight it once or twice because its not the easiest way to reach that mini boss. You want to create areas that gives the player a reason to reach there like how Dead Cells does it ( for example in Dead Cells, picking poison swamp area to get better areas later or village area to play safer ). 

Atm now, I just dont have any motivation to play the game. Still trying to unlock some stuffs....

Edit: Just writing my thoughts on how to simplified version of my complain. 

Imagine playing Hades. The choice given to you is that you can use [b]any God booms during any run[/b], which is great because you get to experiment stuffs. The other choice roguelite games can do is progression through achievement, i.e you get let say, Medusa boom, win the run, get Hercules boom, then win and get Athena and so-on. Robo-Quest does it like this: Do you want to play Athena? Welp you cant because you have to go to room H which only can get by doing room A to C in a hidden behind wall in room C to get you to room G which only opens up if you have room B key which if you found out the password key in room F. If you dont find this [i] inconvenient [/i]. you have the patience of a tortoise

"Take an existing genre and make it a roguelite" is a risky proposition these days, where not every developer knows how to design a run-based game that has the tight gameplay of its inspiration *and* is balanced well for difficulty. Roboquest leans more towards the Hades end of being theoretically possible without upgrades, but you'll probably need them to get through in your first 10 hours of play.

Even though I kept hitting a roadblock in the second major area though, I was really hooked on this one. It's all the kineticism of Doom Eternal where you're just burning through enemies while managing major threats on the battlefield. It even has a similar mechanic that motivates you to be close to enemies when you take them out.

While it limits you to only 2 weapons at a given time, it still has the variety of Doom-inspired weaponry to keep runs feeling fresh. Every class has distinct builds that can make you feel crazy powerful by the end of a run if you set up the right synergies. In all the time I spent trying to clear this game on the Hard difficulty, I never felt like a build was *so* good that I basically cheated the game. It's still wicked fast-paced and extremely punishing.

The story and presentation is refreshingly humble. There's just enough there to be charming, but it knows you wanna get to rip-and-tearing ASAP so it never gets in your way. And holy hell, the music kicks ass. It gets progressively more intense as you progress forward, to the point of Roller Mobster levels of BPM by the end.

This is one of the best modern roguelites out there, and sits right next to Cobalt Core for being one of the best in 2023. Big recommend on this one if you love movement shooters like Doom Eternal or Ultrakill. Doubly so if you love rocket-jumping.

This game makes amazing first impressions and the many variations of robots to destroy keep you on edge. No robot is the same and they each have distinct abilities that actually pose a threat! You never once ever feel bored or have a walk in the park, its constant jumping, running, dashing, shielding and shooting. 

Game play: So many weapons with their variations and leveling up system it keeps everything fresh and you don't ever feel like you're too overpowered or the enemy is.

Level design: it is very pleasing and everything makes sense. The intended way of moving with Sprint, Air strafing, Rail riding, bunny hopping, the map all fits well and theres no moment where you feel that you hit an invisible wall or a small ledge.

Difficulty: Hard is exactly what it is stated as-HARD. The enemies are constantly firing at you, flying up and down, more aggressive but thats just how we experienced players love it. Dying over and over is a bit frustrating BUT we love that too as it brings satisfaction when we beat the level. Every time you play, new guns and new perks are randomly selected so if you found an "OP" setup, SIKE! Time to learn how to use with what you got!

Overall: 9/10

Where to even really start with this game. I had no clue it was even a thing until I went flipping through demos for something new to play, and then *bam* I get flashbanged by not only a game with a demo (already rare for a quality product) but a demo that had me hooked immediately with the basic gameplay loop.

Roboquest is *fun*. Fun for fun's sake. Take Doom, slap it over Isaac, make everything a rattletrap, and you're in business. The whole vibe is mildly plain, but it serves the gameplay perfectly. I don't need to be distracted by shiny chrome and junk while my entire goal is 'Shoot the bad things what might be trying to unalive you'. I just need bumpin' music and enough flash to keep me intrigued.

The fact that the game encourages speed once you've gotten good at it is nice, but the fact that it doesn't *demand* speed is even better. I'll always look more favorably on a game that encourages a style instead of demanding. It enables more people to approach that game. In this case, you lose out on upgrade materials..that you already eventually gain the ability to get multiple of, have handed to you on level up, and drop more and more commonly. Thanks to that you can decide whether to explore for rewards like data logs or even whole alternate routes through a stage.

Gunplay's brisk and snappy too. There are a few stinkers among the gun list, but there's enough dakka to satisfy an Ork between some of the MGs and the like, while there are enough scoped options to satisfy the snipers. Explosives, grenades, kunai and bows for the precision sorts. Shotguns for those that love mixing it up. And tons of affixes, alt fires, and more to boot. Passive upgrades can be sorta eh so far, but the core systems are strong enough that for once, passives (apart from leveling ones, gimme a moment for those) aren't as make or break as they are in some other games.

Classes and leveling though, oh boy. I still have to grab the last class, but three out of the four I've unlocked so far have been addicting. Engineer pulling floating sentry bots out that it can repair with the tap of a button, the Guardian's added impact and tank ability, and the Commando's sheer level of 'Fuck you' if you pick the right upgrades are all great. Nothing particularly feels lacking, but knowing how you're going to build is key when picking level up upgrades. Aaaaat least until you start getting access to perk rerolls, which comes fairly quickly *as well*.

The bottom line is honestly that I'd stack this up with the other high-end roguelites out there, and it's absolutely something worth looking at if you're in the middle of the Venn diagram of 'likes doom' and 'likes roguelites'.

Roboquest is absolutely fantastic. There are very few games on the market that are in such a genre being an action roguelike FPS; but RyseUp have nailed it. 

The overall gameplay loop is pretty simple: collect/find weapons, raise your score through completing levels and killing enemies/bosses fast while synergizing your upgrades/perks to slay the final boss. 

Moment to moment combat is fast, punchy and extremely satisfying. Each weapon is unique in how they play; from rifles, shotguns, melee weapons, explosive launchers - you name it and it's probably here. These weapons also have random affixes that drastically change the strength and variety of each weapon you pick up. I think the best thing about this game is that most, if not all weapons feel exhilarating to use; combined with the satisfying sound and visual effects make combat extremely addictive. 

Enemy variety is solid - your typical more generic enemies in the game such as turrets and soldiers are present here but I didn't find any enemies that are a huge standout. Even the bosses, while are enjoyable to fight, are somewhat generic apart from the odd couple such as the robotic caterpillar that requires you to grind along a metal track. With this, the level variety is good too; with even some secret areas that I have less experience with - but in general, there is some choice in which path you can take at varying levels of difficulty and versatility. 

Roboquest really values how fast you can complete a run; which I personally think is a positive and a negative. It maintains the flow of the game but It forces you to kill as many enemies as possible while also knowing the fastest ways to get across a level and as such, the game punishes you (score-wise) for taking your time. It also has a meta-progression system that allows you to permanently upgrade your future runs that give you more opportunities to improve and more exciting weapons to drop.

The soundtrack is also incredible and suits the game perfectly - maybe the best soundtrack of the year. 

Overall, Roboquest is a game you shouldn't skip. Each run feels quite different to the last; with it's plethora of weapons, secrets, upgrades, perks, and classes (6 of them) constantly providing  rewarding and thrilling roguelike combat.

EDIT: I feel like I need to write a review for 1.0 so here we go.

Honestly, I was a little conflicted about the 1.0 update when it first came out. Not because of the reset in progress in fact I liked that because it gave me a reason to keep grinding. I will state all the good things about the game first. New class is really fun to build and can be quite powerful. The first time I beat the game I used Elementalist. Weapon mastery is great! It now gives me an actual reason to try out all the weapons, and I have found I like a lot more of the weapons then I at first thought! Movement is slick tight and buttery smooth. Most weapons feel wonderful to use. Classes are also better balanced and I have found myself using classes I never even tried during EA. Achievements are all achievable with a little time.
AND THE MUSIC ABSOLUTELY ROCKS!!

Now onto the less good.
Weapon reload times need to be like twice as long. currently I can get away with using one weapon and I don't really like that since I would prefer a faster paced game play. Punishing reloads would help and encourage switching weapons. levels do get a little repetitive after a while so some changes need to be made there. needs to be a a few more rougelike elements to help the games longevity. 

My Wishlist: Ideas for the Devs
Reload changes: Let‚Äôs extend those reload times. Make us sweat a little. Encourage weapon switching. 
Endless Mode: A mode where wrenches unlock endless runs. 
idk what else. its a solid game that you should give a shot. download the demo so you can try it out without buying it! comment below any suggestions you have.

I've been playing video games since the 90's, and so many action games succeed in spite of lackluster combat instead of because of it. This game is different.

It's incredible hard to create satisfying and addictive second-to-second combat, but the developers of this game have done that. I couldn't really point to what makes the combat so thrilling, but it it IS exactly that. The last time I enjoyed combat this much was probably the Titanfall series, may it rest in peace. 

Does the game have flaws? Sure, all games do. I'm not deep enough in to see all the wrinkles. I haven't had a chance to try the co-op yet, though I have already begun harassing my friends to buy this game. I had to purchase it after playing several hours of the surprisingly generous demo. 

Video games don't pass the time for my jaded, divorced-dad ass like they once did. When a game like this manages to yank me out of the shadow realm and make me experience joy, I gotta give props where they are due.

If you just wanna have some fun, like you're a kid watching Brendan Fraser's "The Mummy" for the first time, get this game.

It's another polished and exciting co-op roguelite to add to your library. Fans of Hades, the Risk of Rain series, and PvE shooters in general will have a lot of fun with this one. It personally scratches the same itch Killing Floor does, though the gameplay is much different.

Run through the levels taking out baddies with or without a friend, picking up new weapons and upgrades along the way. Plenty of secrets to look for as well, and pretty much all of them significantly improve your capabilities throughout the runs. You start with a basic double jump as your only additional mobility, but by the end I had many other options to dodge enemy fire & traverse the levels.

There's quite a variety in the weapons you find and the different weapons actually play differently rather than simply being 'the fire/ice/lightning shotgun/SMG/pistol', something a lot of other games with elemental weapons seem to suffer from. The 6 classes offer 12 different abilities to make use of, and the upgrades you attain each run allow for even further specialization. For example, the engineer has drones & an explosive blaster. You can upgrade the drones to summon more at once, equip them with different sidearms, apply different elemental debuffs, or you could upgrade your blaster into a shotgun or long-range sniping tool, or mix both by making your drones focus on the target you last hit with the blaster for increased damage. While I'm not a fan of every class, in general the variety of upgrades feels great and not once did I get the impression a specific upgrade is required or far better than the others.

While it's probably technically possible to beat the game on your first attempt, there are some fairly artificial blockers in place. Some of the later bosses have mechanics during their fight that act as a strict timer; if you can't kill the boss in time, you die no matter what. They basically act as DPS checks, and without the proper upgrades to your run it's pretty nearly impossible to pass them. Doesn't feel great to lose a run to a DPS check, but unless you're a whiz at the game (or playing on a lower difficulty where it likely doesn't matter) you probably won't hit this kind of wall before you've upgraded enough to pass it.

Overall a great purchase, on or off sale, and better with a friend. Would be nice if more than 2-player co-op was possible but I understand why it isn't from the context of gameplay balance.

This is an amazing game. Its the first fps roguelite I've played, and now its got me scrounging the steam store for more. Amazing replay-ability, brilliant art, satisfying weapons, and fun combat. I highly recommend this game to all fans of roguelites or fps games, and especially to fans of both genres.

Also, the co-op mode is definitely a part of the game you need to try. It adds a whole new layer to each run with the ability to revive your teammate (so runs don't instantly die upon player death), as well as the necessity to share dropped weapons and argue about which path to take. So buy this game, and get a friend to do the same!

Nah for real this is a 5 outta 5 experience. Think Doom's combat/level design but every run you're designing a Borderlands character for randomized levels. This game is great, there's decent class variety, weapon variance, and enemy variety. The mechanics are fantastic, both in the movement of your character and the extensive list of weapons. There's a decent bit of grind if you're a completionist/achievement hunter - but nothing too crazy, and the gameplay is enjoyable and varied enough for the long hours needed. The OST is fantastic, I always catch myself saying "this is a good song" to 99.99% of the songs when they come on - almost instinctively. There are a few annoyances here and there, and it takes a bit before things really start to come together, but overall Roboquest is an easy recommendation to FPS or Roguelite enjoyers.

This game gets it. It's a simple, fun, roguelite without mechanical bloat. It's got a lighthearted design and story but with really good high energy music you feel like you're playing robot Doom. And like doom the overall mechanics are pretty simple while allowing for a good amount of customization with a generous amount of classes that all do actually feel unique. It's just a solid game with a lot of offer.

This game has a ton of charm in it's visuals even considering it's sticking to a robotic theme, and after a bit of time the gameplay becomes clean as can be. It also has a new option to change up your crosshair position to give you a better view to what's above you; it seemed iffy at first but it's honestly a perfect fit for the pacing of the gunplay and enemy placements.

It deserves a lot more popularity than it currently has, and with future updates and a fair share of tweaking/cleanup this oughta be one of the most addictive Rougelike/FPS 's in a long time coming.

This game is good, really really good.  It combines the tight fast paced FPS of something like Ultra Kill and Prodeus, with a True Dead cells/Hades roguelite  framework that makes you want to keep on playing and welcome dying so you can upgrade and progress .  Gunfire reborn is in a similar vein to this one, however, Roboquest blow its away in pretty much every area I can think of and most importantly the "hook" of just wanting to keep playing, enemies are interesting, skilled and intelligent, weapons, items, classes, perks all are deep and rewarding and game play is buttery smooth and fast. 

The graphics are excellent and the game runs very vast and smooth. In almost three hours I haven't encountered a single bug, glitch or hiccup.  This game is amazing polished for Early Access, and seemingly so far their is a wealth of content. 

I highly recommend this one if you enjoy FPS's and Roguelites, best combination of the two Genre's I have found thus far. I really hope the DEV does well enough to keep expanding and working on this one, it is a True Gem IMHO.

This has been my go to game for the last couple months...it has that certain I can always play and do something different and advance a little each time feel...I really hope they keep on and expand this one.

Gravely underappreciated game. Robotquest is a delightful roguelike I've played through Early Access. The devs have tried to keep a open line of communication and can deliver a super enjoyable fast paced experience though suffers from unbalance between characters and weapons within runs. There's many secrets and things to unlock in interesting ways and some more repetitive but all gives a large arsenal or kit to use.

The start of the game is hard but once you get a feel for whats up, you swiftly start to move through levels faster and faster while starting to understand the basic enemies. The game maintains the learning through gameplay till about stage 3 or 4 where you really start to meet elemental or "elite" enemies. This is where it probably gets the most frustrating for most who play as the status effects range from weakening you, slowing you and to the worst: being hacked where you have to tap a key three times to get out. A great idea but in execution, leaves you to take forced damage on top of the already large amount of things that can be on screen at once. And a LOT of stuff can be on screen at once especially in the final boss fight which is like every infuriating attack at once.

A lot of the end game kind of feels like how stun is; forced damage to stop the crazy fast robot. All of which can be avoided through one single class, making the others feeling super squishy which is a shame given how diverse the classes can be.

I think after some balancing and maybe more community feedback, it could reach it's best but for now, its pretty good. 7.5-8/10 Worth picking up if fps and roguelikes are your thing

The closest thing I could compare this game to is Borderlands 2 with massive inspiration from the most recent DOOM, without the hours you'd need to level a character, make a build, and complete 2 playthroughs just to get to Ultimate VH mode. This game really pushes you to be in the forefront of the slaughter rather than far away, as health drops disappear quite quickly on Standard+.

The enemy priority system is glorious. You'll quickly realize that many enemies can't land a bead on you as long as you keep moving, but other enemies mess up your ability to move in ways that aren't inherently frustrating. Enemies with laser attacks that aim ahead of you, snipers that can near-guaranteed land a shot on you if they finish their charge, and enemies that litter the ground with explosives that prove dangerous to land or walk into (but you can shoot them to make them disappear immediately).

Easily already my top underrated game of 2024 so far.
Imagine if PS2 era Insomniac developed Doom Eternal.
Anything that calls a melee move a "bonk" gets an A+ in my book.

Roboquest has the potential to be one of the greatest FPS roguelites in existence. This game includes well executed features that will please fans of  both FPSs and roguelites. 

FPS elements include satisfying movement (featuring rail sliding, double jumping, head stomping) and interesting level design with rewarding secrets to discover. Each playable character has unique abilities that shape the way the game is played. Some of these abilities include a toggle-able invulnerability shield that recharges over time, a stealth ability, or drones that assist you and inherit some of your traits. Your robot character receives a new trait with every level-up and can dramatically alter your play style. As fun as the FPS game-play already is, it is enhanced by the roguelite features.

Loot includes weapons with randomized traits with varying levels of rarity. Guns (or crossbows, throwing knives, flamethrowers, chainsaws, etc.) may include additional abilities or attributes (for example a rocket launcher can come equipped with an under-barrel shotgun or hit scan projectiles that immediately reach their target).

The only area where this game is lacking is the story. It's not very captivating and does not include any animations or voice over. The music can be a bit lacking in some areas as well. If those sorts of things are important to you then this may not be the game for you. However, if you are a person that values game play over all, and you enjoy FPS and roguelite games, Roboquest is for you.

an incredibly addictive rogue-lite. good gunplay, fun classes, & tons of unlockable content. There's build diversity with interesting weaponry and class augments you unlock during runs. If you have played gunfire and enjoyed it - you'll definitely enjoy this as well.

A very fun fast-paced rogue-like game. I saw my friend playing this briefly and quickly decided that I liked the style and thought it looked fun. Before I watched them play anymore of it, I decided to buy it for myself.

I played this on the max difficulty (Hard) to ensure I got as much time as I could out of this game before beating it, since I quickly knew I would want to 100% it. It is rogue-like progression where you are meant to fail and upgrade after each run before trying again. There are different paths to take with different collectibles and secrets for further upgrades. The story is somewhat simple (so if you are looking for an involved story, sorry this won't fulfill that), but it was still fun to piece together tidbits from the data-logs about a timeline regarding humanity's future. The soundtrack slaps and has a different song for each path of certain levels you are on. The bosses and puzzles were challenging enough to feel rewarding, but not too challenging to where it caused frustration. The many different types of weapon play styles and class play styles to choose from was refreshing, because I could try different approaches to every run (or just for fun). The stylistic choice regarding the art with cell-shading gave it a lot of character, and it suited the robot designs and environment art very well (although the character Max looked a little wonky in-game). I loved that the cinematic portions were in the style of animated comics as well. I enjoyed that the base camp upgraded along the way - while also letting me keep track of my achievements and stuff that I found.

I do kind of wish some of the bosses had harder modes, maybe with extra affixes or ng+ type run modes, to create a longer endgame and sense of chaos for different runs. That way I would have a reason to continue playing after 100%ing it, but perhaps they may do that in a sequel? One can hope. There were a couple of moments where it felt repetitive, but that comes with the territory of most rogue-likes.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game, especially if you are a fan of rogue-likes and just want a good old gauntlet-type game that doesn't take itself TOO seriously (but seriously enough to still be fun and have variety). I'm getting close to 100%ing it on the Hard difficulty, and once I do it'll probably be around 40 through 50 hours of game time - which I think is worth the cost. If you are a fan of Hades but want something simpler and more chill just to relax with yourself (or a friend since you can play as a group of 2 total), this could be a decent fit.

P.S. This kind of felt like a BETTER version of what Overwatch PvE was originally promised as, but as a rogue-like.

*** (EDIT: Turns out there is a NG+ mode actually, that you unlock after beating it <(UwU)> (although it seems to just be a ramp up in difficulty rather than additional affixes so far). ***

Back on my Roguelike grind again, but on a game I didn't think I'd be playing that much. I love DOOM (old and new), and I sure as hell LOVE roguelikes, so I had to give it a shot.

Roboquest is a fast-paced FPS Roguelike developed by RyseUp Studios and published by Starbreeze Publishing.

Graphics: 9/10

Lovely cell-shaded Borderlands-like graphics with a lovely variety of landscapes. Such well done visuals and designs., I love it.

Gameplay: 9/10

I expected this to be another boring clone of Gunfire Reborn, but much to my surprise, it feels, dare I say better than Gunfire Reborn. It's a fast-paced looter shooter roguelike where every movement feels so smooth, mechanics are lovely, and the gadgets make the game feel even better than before. With a vast array of weapons, healthy selection of upgrades, gadgets and an addicting game loop, this kept me on for longer than I initially thought. One of the reasons this isn't a 10 out of 10 is cause it doesn't have as much content as Gunfire, but it definitely feels MUCH better. It lacks other modes, but you can play by yourself or with friends A.K.A Brobots. Another point taker is that it doesn't have support for up to 4 players online, which sucks cause I feel like having 4 players is essential to a fun, replayable Roguelike experience if you're bringing multiple people on board. But I understand.

For people waiting for the game to go on sale, forget it. The game is horrendously optimized and has a history of crashing on high end pcs (including my own). The devs in the discord are completely unhelpful and would rather keep pushing useless content than actually fixing any of the problems that have been arising from their player base. The bug reporting channels are often overlooked by devs and major software bugs are brushed past. On top of this, there is a major issue when it comes to the online feature. A mass of people which, once again, includes myself, cannot use the online features at all,  since your account needs to be connected to Epic Games. "Just connect to Epic" you'll most likely think, but this could not be further from naive. Connecting to epic does nothing and you're doomed to sit staring at a wheel that promises a connection. To reiterate my before point, I have been asking for a solution from the devs for two weeks straight, every, single, day, in the discord. The only response I'm able to get is childish, similarly to the way a child would say, "oopsies, I will for sure look into that", then discard the issue. I'm not the only one facing these problems, the discord is riddled with people on all different platforms with bugs that honestly should have been resolved in play testing before release. Once again, hardly any interaction from the devs.

As for the small amount of game play, the only fun part of the game is flying around rocket jumping; combat is too easy, even on the New Game ++++ game mode. The secrets are nothing but obvious and the map is anything but procedural, so get used to playing the same path down to the pixel every run. Achievement hunting bears no satisfaction due to there being only about 5 reasonably difficult tasks to seek. Upgrading your base camp has no additional effects other than looks. The first few runs of the game are blissful, but then all you need is the same few weapons to instantly win the game. The raw stats feel practically useless because the only "items" to boost you are the special little cards that %90 of the time, are based for weapon use. 

To summarize: 
The game is unplayable from bugs, boring game play loop, ignorant devs, online doesn't work, and my computer is now a nuclear reactor. Waste of $25

This is the first game that has spurred me to write a review. This game is fantastic. 

in my opinion, for a roguelite/roguelike to be successful, it MUST have the following:

-Excellent core gameplay. 
-Interesting weapon and modifier variety.
-Secrets and alternate paths.

If these fundamentals are accomplished, then the resulting experience is fun and engaging with enough unknowns and unlockables to keep the player coming back and wanting more. Roboquest, in my opinion, meets all of these characteristics in spades. AND MORE. 

Gameplay:
The movement in this game is absolutely godly. It is incredibly responsive and high-speed. Weapons are snappy and responsive and enemy encounters are loosely "room-by-room" and must be handled differently based on the enemy types. Killing an enemy drops some healing orbs, so you are given incentive to stay close to the action, which is incredibly fun and rewarding. Maps have a respectable amount of verticality (which is mostly optional, but it is there), and with the variety of long range weapons provided, I believe those gravitating towards sniping and long range fights would find their playstyle reasonably supported here. If you enjoy FPS games that challenge your awareness and reward your aim, Roboquest will definitely satisfy you in this regard. 

Build variety:
I have only ever played on Hard mode and above. Over my time with the game, I have been surprised by how many different guns I have found success with, compared to always wanting the same gun every time because it is overpowered. Shotguns, rifles, knives, mortars - the game has a ton of different weapons, and they all (in my experience) can be relevant if approached the right way, and if the player enjoys them. Each class has its own unique abilities and perks for these abilities, so there is variety here as well. These are standard roguelite qualities, and Roboquest meets them all satisfactorily. There are a LOT OF GUNS. 

I haven't spent a lot of time on the different classes yet, but so far for me, Commando feels the best. I can't speak to the class variety and balance, but if others found issues here, then based on my other impressions of this game so far, I would trust the devs to balance them over time. 

Gameplay Loop:
The path to the final boss has many twists and turns. From the starting area (which is the same for every run, as far as I know), the player soon reaches an intersection where they can choose from 3 different paths. Each path leads to a different environment, which each have their own forks and alternate paths. With my 21 hours in the game, I still haven't found every available path/location. Based on your current goals, you will be choosing one route over another; there is no "best" route, and this contributes to the variety and player choice fulfillment of the core game. 

Balance/Difficulty:
This game is very fair; to me, the difficulty and game mechanics give a lot of respect to the player. When I die, it isn't because of an unfair mechanic or something I couldn't see coming. The encounters in this game escalate with several status effects, lasers, enemy behaviors, and hazards that keep the player on their toes. It is no cake walk, and it reaches a peak that I can only describe as "adderall crackhead insanity" and I love it. As difficulty has increased, I have not found "more difficulty" equaling health-sponge enemies or enemies randomly one-shotting me, as it does in other games. The game has tons of enemy types and behaviors that it cranks up proportionately, resulting in increased difficulty that in no way compromises the awesome core experience. The game is cute and cartoon-y, but the developers know what they're doing. This game can be brutally hard if you want it to be, and that difficulty is fun as heck. Difficulty and balance are further elaborated on in the Aesthetics section of this review where I talk about enemy appearances.

Secrets/Long-Term Progression:
Aside from the smaller upgrades the player can make between runs, there are also upgrades that provide a new core capability to the player. I have not unlocked all of these yet, but so far, these further complement the gameplay and evolve it without making it too easy or breaking it. The methods in which one unlocks new paths and new run modifiers are varied and obscure. For example, there are gates that require a code to open them, and I still haven't figured out how to unlock them (I haven't looked these things up as I enjoy figuring them out). For one of them, I had to bring a guy some swim trunks. These puzzles and secrets respect the player's intelligence and provide incentive to look around their environment and think creatively. They aren't spoonfed to the player by the developers and found with minimal effort.

When I beat the final boss for the first time, I was pleasantly surprised to find that it was not the end (but it did end the run). I still have much more to unlock and discover. This moment solidified Roboquest as a great game to me, since leading up to the final boss, I was concerned if I'd want to keep playing once I had beaten it. I still definitely do. 

Aesthetics/OST:
It is criminal that this game's OST is confined to a section that is often overlooked. It is incredible. I don't listen to EDM often, and this soundtrack SLAPS. Each environment, and there are many, has its own soundtrack (I'm pretty sure). Some locations have house music, some have drum n bass, some are raw dirty electro. These tracks are specific to their maps, so on top of each environment having its own unique identity, it also has its own musical vibe. It's DOPE.

I've seen some criticize the appearance of enemies in this game, as they are all robots. There aren't different enemy factions or anything - it's just robots. I personally do not mind this, and find it almost necessary for the core experience the devs have created here. 

When I see any enemy at a glance, I know exactly what it is and what it does, and this is CRUCIAL. Again, this game is very fair and you do not die to BS. When I reach the next group of enemies, I can immediately begin making decisions on what enemies I want to kill first, and which ones to watch out for. Does an enemy shield other enemies? Does it stun me? Snare me? Cloak and assassinate me? Spawn bombs or other smaller enemies? Mess with my vision? A game like this can easily become an onslaught of random damage lasers, balls, debuffs, and bullets, with no rhyme or reason, but Roboquest does not. I can clearly assess a room which enables me to run into groups of enemies without getting obliterated. This is all because the game provides information and has designed its enemies to make this possible. A case could be made that there could still be more enemy appearance variety, but I'm not invested in that debate. For what it is, the enemy appearances facilitate and deepen this awesome experience crafted by the developers. One enemy type is a stationary tower that shields all nearby enemies. Any shield on an enemy has a little spike on it which clearly points in the direction of the tower so you can find it and destroy it. Little details like this, to me, show the care and savviness of the developers. 

Story:
I haven't paid much attention to the story. Like most games of this genre, story isn't a requirement. But what I have picked up is still cute and enjoyable. For a roguelite, I'd say it's more than serviceable, which is all it needs to be. 

Overall:
Is Roboquest the new sliced bread or the best roguelite ever made? I don't know, but it is an EXCELLENT game. It checks all my boxes and then some, and has tons of personality that sets it apart both visually and gameplay-wise. I can only assume that the devs know what they're doing, because every element of this game is crafted with a lot of care and dialed in. For $25, it's a phenomenal deal.

Challenging, sometimes incredible difficult but a whole lot of fun to play until you get knocked out and jump straight back in just so you can enjoy it again, and again, and again. And maybe I‚Äôll finish a run in 20,30 or 100h in. If you enjoy fps and roguelikes then get this game and thank me later xD

Feels like an upgraded version of Gunfire Reborn with added vertical movement through double|triple jumps, rocket jumping and increased speed + amazing soundtracks. 

What's good:
- [b]aggression is rewarded.[/b]  Health pickups on melee kills, on-hit healing from bosses
- [b]movement is fast[/b]. Achieved through near constant different speed buffs in a battle + head-stomping + rocket jumping and lots more. Don't let the enclosed environment fool you, there is plenty of space to zoom around. 
- [b]the soundtrack[/b] that sets the stage: hasty and energetic electro+metal-ish with pauses in between stages to take a breather
-[b]build variety[/b]: want melee smacking? They got it covered. Want to make a shoot for 9k damage? Sure thing. Wanna be a caster? Why not, here are upgrades to make your abilities recover faster. Do you like to cover things with lead? Check out infinite ammo upgrade and make it rain. Like bombing things? Make it bigger and hit harder!
- some thought was put into [b]boss fights[/b] (various environments, attacks and more)

Some features: 
- 10+ weapons to choose from with different mechanics + 3 different elemental weapons. I was glad to see that it is possible to kill fire with fire. Only the elemental effect is removed 
- 6 different classes of different play-style

The only bad thing is the "goofy ahh" plot of the game which leans to actual toddlers. Though the time is not spent in endless dialogues.

Really fun pick up and play roguelike shooter. It's like a combination of Overwatch and Borderlands with a bit of base building using resources you collected during your runs. Roboquest has that 'just one more run' feeling towards it and it's hard to put  down.

Pros:

+ Gunplay feels really good and there's a wide selection of guns from everything to machine guns, 3 round burst rifles, grenade launchers, to weirder more experimental weapons

+ The soundtrack is amazing. While games like Doom Eternal used its blaring metal soundtrack to keep the pace going and get you into the rhythm of the fast paced gunplay Roboquest does this with its bumping electronic and rock soundtrack.

+ Each class feels viable and has a different playstyle. If you want to play a tanky class with a shield you can do that. If you want to play a fast paced ninja class using invisibility and critical hits there's a class for that. If you want to be an engineer who builds turrets and spams grenades there's a class for that. It keeps variety fresh between runs.

+ You can make some stupidly broken but fun builds if you get the right guns and perks during a run. During one of my guns I got a SMG with a large magazine and a high fire rate that also fired a shotgun blast every 5 bullets. During that same run I also got a perk that gave me unlimited ammo and increased my fire rate when I popped my shield which allowed me to melt anything in front of me including bosses when it was active.

Cons:

- Movement feels fine but there's a lack of momentum and verticality while in the air and sliding. This makes pulling off some tricks like moving around arenas and grinding on rails not feel as smoothly as they should.

- Combat favors CQC and highly aggressive burst damage builds due to how chip damage and health pickups work. When you kill an enemy they drop health orbs that can be picked up for a short time until they disappear. This means if you're sitting back with a sniper or long ranged weapon you're going to be missing out on a lot of health pickups during a run.

- Near some of the ending levels enemies get quite annoyingly bullet spongey and tiny making them hard to hit

- Minor complaint, but there's no way to save your current run if you need to step away for whatever reason. It would be nice to be able to close the game and continue the run without having to restart especially in a genre that's designed for pick up and play short bursts of gameplay.

Roboquest is great if you're looking to scratch that FPS/Roguelike itch. Highly recommend.

What a gem. Tried the demo, loved the game and decided to just buy the full game and oh boy was it worth it. Its just so much fun to find hidden stuff and I love the soundtrack. Smooth gameplay too.

Demo tells you all you need to know about how smooth this plays. Try it. 6 hours in engaging with the meta progression system through many runs, I'm still loving the bullet hell. There's so many little things that make me want to root for this game. The tutorial gauges your skill and recommends a good difficulty, something I didn't even realize until discussion with a friend. There's grind rails. I haven't had a good grind rail since Rachet & Clank. The guns all feel right to fire with kick and impact and crisp sounds, with variety for my dumbass rushing into every room with shotguns and my buddy preferring sniping and long range. Enemy variety is also encouraging the use of different weapons, high level play needing to switch between the two guns you can hold while they "pocket reload". Aggressive auto aim on controller helps me have a good time despite hand problems preventing Mouse and Keyboard use. It's a fast fun game that nails it.
The meta progression had me worried about repetition. This is a roguelite and that means repeating level 1 a lot. Even on Hard, the first two levels are just warmup baby tier difficulty and it makes speedrunning them fast, but indeed stale. The music bops per level stay fresh surprisingly despite that. The soundtrack is fantastic. The small but perfect way it triggers when opening up a level gets me every time. It even shuts up if you loiter in the beginning area as to not repeat the beginning over and over. There's tons of little things like that I appreciate. I'm just now discovering some of the secrets and end game challenges and look forward to completing everything in it.
Something from Gunfire Reborn I was also worried about is getting overpowered and ruining the balance. Don't know how far Meta progression will trivialize the game, but so far learning the actual game and how to dodge its enemies' fire has been what's most important along with how to build a character to synergize with whatever weapon or skills are active. This game is balanced and you can get far on skill alone, but the average player is definitely not getting to the end prematurely on Hard. There's a mechanic to add more elite enemies to the map which is toggle-able, so I look forward to making it as hard as possible to match whatever unlocks players receive. And then turning it off when I just want to chill.

Not a fan of Roguelik/lite games at all. Besides Hades and now this.

The gunplay is solid, movement is as quick as it needs to be, and every encounter is one where you need to stay on your toes. 

The enemy design and levels are simple but extremely serviceability, you know where to go and what target is a priority right away. I appreciate when a game doesn't waste on extra fluff that gets in the way of readability.

The music just gets stuck in my head, and the story is actually quite interesting and is something you can engage with or ignore to get back to the run. 

A great variety of weapons and affixes that can change up play, along with several "classes" with their own abilities and upgrades during a run.

Highly addicting, energetic game.

The shooting plays a bit like DOOM, minus the blood, gore and satanic imagery. You're rewarded for getting up close and personal with the enemies when you kill them and the movement is smooth and dynamic.

It's built well and each run is unique and random to keep that constant replayability. Also multiple characters and unique perks/upgrades keeps the experience fresh. 

The game is definitely a good introduction to the FPS genre for younger gamers, with the option to up the difficulty sets a skill ceiling high enough for even the most experienced players to have a great time.
Fun game, went in blind on hard until I hit a wall with final boss and finding items. Really enjoyed the fast pace and different styles to push. Hope to see more in the future!

In fact, that playstyle gets actively punished by the game, so the only way to progress is to actually learn. Great singleplayer game made even better with friends

Runs well, plays well, just all around a good time. A couple things -

1) This game is as much of a platformer as it is a shooter. A big part of what makes it unique but a lot of platforming is sort of forced on you which not everyone will like.

2) Meta progression is not like other roguelikes where your character gets stronger. You unlock items and perks to hopefully get better items during a run but your character itself doesn't really get any stronger.

3) Don't hesitate to turn down the difficulty while you're unlocking stuff if playing solo. The game gets much more fun and doable at higher difficulties once you've unlocked certain items.

- Really fun roguelike FPS
- Really responsive combat (very rare that you'll get BS damage out of nowhere)
- A ton of unlockable stuff and secrets
- Cute lil robots to pick
- Great bosses

I feel like a mix of Borderlands and Gunfire Reborn to me. You don't have to walk a ton between each stages, you're just straight in the action as soon as you go through a door. The only negative I'd have is that you're rewarded for finishing a level as quick as possible, but you don't have to go at sonic speed either so it's not too bad. Health regeneration can be a problem sometimes on hard difficulty, but it's not that bad once you've unlocked a few things.

Is Roboquest fun? Yes. Would I recommend it? Maybe. 
Overall every part of the core game-play is incredible. The guns are expertly designed, game looks amazing, the abilities pair well together and feel great on their own, the movement feels amazing, the enemies and bosses are properly challenging, and the list goes on. Roboquest is not without its problem though. First, the crouch mechanic feels out of place because the game incentives you not to use it. Roboquest rewards you for playing quickly and aggressively with a time bonus, so slowing down to patiently snipe enemies while crouched behind cover digs into your time bonus. Second, there are dedicated skills that give you better stats for crouching. These skills reward you for playing worse as you either have to crouch in the open which breaks your flow or you have to play more slowly which cuts into your time reward. Third, the exploration feels out of place. The game heavily rewards you for exploring every nook and cranny, but exploring can take quite a bit of time and is done best with one class which has a teleport ability that makes it easier to reach high places. The time bonus punishing you for taking any detours and the game rewarding you for taking detours ultimately feels like the game is contradicting what it's tell you as a player to do. This is eased by the easier game modes, the easiest of them making it very enjoyable to explore. Despite that, I wish the game focused more on exploration in the early game and included the time bonus as an end game or post game feature. None of these flaws make the core game-play experience worse, but they do make it feel less polished than it could be.
TLDR: Highly recommend to rouge lite fans, minor flaws take the game from a 9/10 to a 7.5/10.

Some of my favorite games over the past year and a half have been describable as "X plus Y plus Z," and Roboquest joins this noble category. With the aesthetics and weapons generation system of Borderlands, the pace and combat style of Doom 2016, and the item progression system of Risk of Rain, Risk Of Borderdoom is an extremely fun, very replayeable shoot'-em-up. 

Though the story doesn't do anything new, it doesn't need to - it's only there to provide some obligatory context for why you're rampaging through an endless horde of seething killer robots. The game's movement system is fluid, smooth, and responsive; the guns are extremely meaty and satisfying; the gunplay is demanding but rewarding, and there's a decent variety of classes. A wide variety of guns, an acceptable number of levels, and an array of unlockable content and side-paths give you plenty of reasons to keep coming back to the already-rock-solid gameplay loop. For the price tag, you really can't go wrong here. 

My only real complaint is that some of the arenas from the Fields onwards feel way too cramped for the number of enemies the game throws at you.

One of the best roguelites, and generally best designed games ever. 
here's some of the pros:

- you don't outright get power with upgrades. You mostly get quality of life, nicer weapons and some new classes that are all balanced pretty much at the same level. You get farther in the game primarily by getting better at it. 
- Collectibles are incredibly well handled. They are well hidden and are always satisfying to find. After you get to about the halfway mark, you get an item that can greatly help you find them. Each collectible Gives you more upgrade materials. 
- Gadgets are fun! You can get a jetpack! 
- Good, original weapons. In one run I had a shotgun, whose projectiles both pierced enemies and bounced off walls. Every shot sent 20 pellets flying around the room. I was doing more damage with collateral than my actual aimed shots. You can rocket jump with a lot of explosive weapons! The modifiers greatly impact how weapons play. For example I had a rocket launcher that had the hit scan modifier (meaning that instead of throwing a projectile it just instantly hits wherever you aim.) that modifier removed range restrictions. I was playing a sniper with explosive ammo. Felt insane. 
- Has 2 player support! It feels so much better with a buddy who you can talk with, have some fun with and who can revive you when you're down. It's well balanced around multiplayer as well, as long you progress alongside each other. 

Do not use a guide, it's better experienced if you explore yourself. 

The only cons so far: 
- some of the bosses are a bit annoying. One of them was timed, which became a dps check. we barely managed to do enough and it felt like the worst fight. 
- The shovel needs to be used by both. Most other collectibles work just fine for both players, but the shovel needs to be handed around, so you need to find a weapon that's lying around and swap it through. Tiny bit annoying. 

Totally worth the price! Hard recommend.

this game suffers from a fairly suffocating game-play loop, what i mean by that is on paper it sounds like a lot of fun and it is for a few runs, but after a while, you can sum up a majority of runs to "oh OK. guess that's it then." you don't feel like your improving at a noticeable rate, your unlocking things and that helps you progress easier, and in general i've never been so baffled to see my skill feel capped, and this is entirely pushing "skill issue" aside, obviously playing better rewards you, however with how somewhat limited your survival options are in this game (normally not an issue but it is noticeable in a game like this) you end up wanting more mobility options or ways to restore your scratch hp (a secondary hp bar over your main hp bar that ISNT hp, but is easily able to become your main hp, I explain it poorly here though, try the demo) now that's not to say i want the game to be easier, I fully understand why I lose a lot of runs to a random projectile (namely i don't move well enough to naturally dodge everything, meaning when i don't see something fly at me i end up getting hit)
but that's exactly why the game feels like a chore, i die in the same place every game, everything before it is S rank andd then I reach that one part i struggle with and die less than a quarter way... again. "oh OK. guess that's it then." even a form of "training" mode (or a wave survival) would do wonders for the natural process of this game, maybe select an arena like oasis or ruins and just play with a changing environment and generated enemies, that way you can get into a groove and understand the enemies better, besides that? I want more control over the rng of the game OTHER than more rerolls and more options, give me the ability to at least partially hand pick traits on a weapon, or at least let me pick a weapon of my choosing to use more often like the kunai.

Possibly the best RougeLite ive played, as well as being a VERY solid FPS game. The gameplay is robust, yet fluid, the movement is a mix of quake and titanfall, the artystyle is exteramly polished. Gameplay loop is fun, and takes time to master, no 2 runs are the same. Class diversity is prominent and well done, each robot feels unique in its playstyle and there is enough variety for a good amount of replayability. Enemy designs are unique and become second nature when you're in game, making it easy to diagnose what ones require your immediate attention during your run. 

Overall this game has been a great surprise, i picked it up on a gamble, as im mainly a multiplayer FPS player, but iver REALLY enjoyed my time with RoboQuest, Highly recommended.

PLAY THIS GAME. It's like Borderlands (before it went downhill), DOOM, and Quake (?) all had a baby, and you get to play as a big buff cute robot.

The movement is nice. There's a big focus on your kit using your movement to assist in generating high damage, AND to bounce around and avoid enemy projectiles.

The guns control like a dream. There are some stinkers (looking at most of the laser projectile based ones), but they are all usable.

The bosses are challenging, but mostly fair. There are some that are uber punishing to new players, like a boss that will give you an instant game-over if you don't pull a lever on the boss's back.

The upgrade system is really nice, but if you played the beta, you probably already have a maxed out basecamp.

Overall, VERY nice movement roguelike shooter, AND it has co-op! I'd say it's a perfect game if it had larger co-op lobby sizes.

I cannot believe I forgot to sing this game's praises 'till now.

If you want a fast-paced, movement-driven, roguelite shooter, give it a try (There's a demo. For Free. An ancient concept rarely seen nowadays, but the one getting me to play the Early Access and now the full game. Download it now.)

It might not have thousands of areas to play through, but learing the best methods to clear the types of rooms and corridors you encounter in each area is a lot of fun. Almost all weapons are usable without a problem and well balanced. All available Classes can wield all weapon types to great effect and give their own spin on gameplay.

Invisibility paired with decoys that make enemies vulnerable and kill them with no further input of yours? Let the world explode... multiple times thanks to instant resets of abilites? Ignore all guns and pick up a good ol' rusty shovel that still manages to fire rockets and ricochet into several targets? Gotcha. 

I love this game. Played it a lot in EA and at least play a round daily since full release. 

I cannot recommend it tho if your alloted gaming time is less than an hour, as there is no way to save your game mid run. If it's just some stuff at home that keeps ya occupied and you can leave it running in the background, then all's good. If ya gotta dip and shut down your PC tho... keep away.
