This was one of the most fun gaming experiences I've had this year. The shooting is snappy, the movement, though not as extreme as something like Ultrakill's, feels fluent, dodging is encouraged since the enemies only shoot projectiles and the game just feels incredibly good to play. It's kind of like Overwatch/Borderlands with roguelite gameplay loop and better movement. There's a bunch of weapons and you can pretty much experiment and build around your own playstyle freely, which I really like. The RNG when it comes to weapons and items is fairly consistent. The different classes feel similar, but are different enough to justify their existence. I havan't given the multiplayer a try yet because none of my friends have the game, but I'm definitely going to recommend it to them as it seems it would be fun co-op, though it's only up to 2 players. The only problem I encountered was that minimizing the window sometimes made me unable to jump and I had to restart my run, which was really annoying.

content wise, there are many things (not too many) to unlock, all in the form of secrets, varied quests, challenges, different routes... once unlocked, they give you permanent upgrades that really change the way you play the game (notably the movement)
once that's done, you can go up in difficulty and try to get a S-rank run/unlock all steam achievements, so replayability++

graphisms look good, cartoon style (so not too performance greedy, that's good as well)

as for the gameplay, 4 things :
- movement : feels good and if used well, can give you a **real** advantage ;; you can upgrade it
(it's my favourite thing about this game, but it can also get very frustrating when you upgrade your speed and get stuck in edges)
- learning foes' patterns/maps (obviously)
- character upgrading : it's really possible to adapt your character to your playstyle, or the other way around ;; runs can be very different, though a few dozen hours are enough to explore all the possibilities
- weapons : they are varied and fit different playstyles, so again, you can adapt your bot to something that suits you but you'll see them all in a few dozen hours

Titanfall and Borderlands made a roguelike baby.  That's really all there is to it.  Visual aesthetic definitely going for a cartoon or comic book and is generally good, readability is very important in a game of this pace and they do a great job of that, I almost never mistake an enemy for something else or vice versa, though I honestly don't really care for the sound effects text appearing on the screen.  Music is absolutely bumping and keeps you in the game really well.  Meta-progression so far seems good, unlocking new classes, permanent upgrades and equipment.

One problem though is that like many roguelikes, Roboquest does not have any way to save a run in progress, at least not that I've found.  This can actually be a problem for this game because getting past chapter 3 (of 4 or maybe more chapters, I've not beaten the game yet) took well over an hour, so full runs are pretty long by roguelike standards, and without any way to save and come back you have to do it all in one sitting.  A simple checkpoint or save system on the safezones in the levels or beginning of a level would definitely go a long way.

That aside, this game is a blast and really pushes your movement FPS skills

Very solid game, I don't have much to add in terms of a review. The demo gives you a pretty solid introductory into the game and its mechanics, as well as letting you keep your progress for the full game which is a nice bonus. Single-player and co-op is pretty solid, personally in terms of progressing through the game to unlock stuff I preferred playing solo because if your brobot goes down losing half of your current health is quite hard to recover from and snowballs out of control pretty fast. The only thing I wish it had would be workshop support or a modding scene as it can give more content for those who have completed everything,

I think the only thing in particular I really don't like about this game is a problem shared by both Gunfire Reborn and Risk of Rain 2: The final boss feels like an entirely different game. Your build up until it can be steam rolling through groups of enemies then suddenly you hit Iris and you're doing nothing because you didn't spec for single target damage. In theory you could argue this means you have to build around dealing with both but in reality, Iris is the only ever stumbling block for me which tends to lead me down the same routes and away from explosives which are pretty much always going to be weak vs Iris.

What I think is a shame is that during the run, the goliaths present a generally excellent middleground where you're in arenas that test both single and multi target damage while Iris is just a giant DPS wall check. Clearly it'd requite a lot of fundamental changing to the fight to make it more balanced but I would really love to see this addressed because it's quite infuriating that both the other games I mentioned feel like they share this problem.

I also think the movement options in the game with all the gadgets unlocked is a bit over the top. Yes you can disable them of course, but are you going to? Probably not. You're probably going to opt to fly around endlessly without touching the floor which is fun but at some point feels like you're not all that mentally engaged with the environment.

Finally, I think the game would do with some more build variety. There's a lot of weapons and items but too often they're just "do more damage" in however roundabout way. More purple items with significant up and downsides to encourage genuinely different play styles would go a long way to mix things up. Even though I think it's an issue I would still say the game walks the fine line between making the player change their ideas on the fly and enabling you to go in with a plan. With a roguelike I think it's important that you can have a plan but you're still forced to adapt with what items you get. If you're just going to make all the decisions in the spawn room and then wait for the items to inevitably pop up the player is likely to just do the same thing constantly. It's really hard to get this right and I'd say Roboquest is at least 80% of the way there, maybe leaning too far into being too easy to pick the same things every time as you unlock more shops (ESPECIALLY once you get semi-free rerolls)

Really those are my only notable issues with the game despite it filling out a few paragraphs. It feels amazing to play, the graphics are fantastically readable and clear, soundtrack is excellent. Definitely worth the asking price.

Roboquest focuses hard on the fundamentals: Snappy aim, fluent movement and level traversal (running safely around many enemies in a small room) and player skill above all else. In theory you could have an entire run where you avoid all damage, due to enemies shooting with telegraphed attacks and projectiles that can all be dodged.

I highly recommend you try the demo, see if it's for you at all, and apparently it keeps all your progress if you end up buying the game. If you like it, just buy the game and refund it if you lose interest.

Great music, great gameplay, great overall. The mechanics flow so good in this game that if you know what you're doing and the limits of your character/build, you'll feel like an unstoppable beast. Once you start to unlock some of the core mechanics of the game (mostly in the form of basecamp upgrades and gadgets), the game starts to quickly become more exciting. This plus the satisfyingly pseudo-random nature of the game is good enough for me to bust out tons of hours into this. I've completed the game and unlocked most things, but I can see myself coming back to this just to warm up my aim. 

My only criticism to this game is that it's too easy to take away a lot of the "random" elements (and the game is a bit easy itself once you unlock everything, though this is probably intentional). For example you can eventually upgrade the gun upgrader guy to reroll most lower rarity guns for free. This enables you to basically perfect an early-game weapon quite easily especially if you're willing to restart until you start with a good blue gun. It may not carry you to Victory but it'll at least get you to the final few maps which is where it becomes insanely easy to find a powerful weapon.

I would give this game an 8/10, with it easily being my current favorite FPS rogue-lite.

This is a fantastic movement shooter that you're gonna want to play just because the mechanics are *so good*. Genuinely fun to use almost every weapon in the game, and once you unlock all of your movement methods, you'll spend all of your time moving around in the air. They also provide many levels of difficulty, so nearly anyone can play this game. The graphics have a nice comic-y look, and while I wasn't really invested in the story, the whole game has nicely consistent quality and feel to it. I highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys FPS games and/or rogue-lites.

Update:
TLDR: If dozens of hours of gameplay are your idea of money well spent, I'd skip this game. If you're okay spending $25 on a short game (=<20hrs), then I'd recommend this game.

Update context:
I'm on "Guardian 3" difficulty, which is essentially "reincarnation levels" if you play Gunfire, except there's only 4 Guardian levels currently.
Initially, I said there's a large variety of builds. But, now that I'm at the end game... I see there aren't. You can't play any 'ol build and expect to win with all S's (this game's ranking system for biomes completed). I've beat Gunfire Reborn's Reincarnation Level 9, solo, but I'm stuck on G3 here. I'm not having fun anymore, trying to beat all 4 Guardian difficulty levels in RoboQuest. I think the time I already invested in the game was worth $25, but I don't foresee myself playing this game much longer. 


Original review:
Borderlands meets Gunfire Reborn meets Doom. Do note: Roboquest doesn't strike me as a very deep game, though. My "thumbs up" review is because I'm happy to spend $25 on a game that isn't very deep, but is really fun for the 10-20hrs I do put into it.

It's more FPS-focused than Gunfire, I'd say. BUT.. you can definitely make OP builds. I saw another review mention how it's just FPS-focused and you can't really build much variety. But you can! Each class seems to have at least 3-4 different routes you can take.

Movement felt clunky at first, and I was instantly afraid I wouldn't like the game. But, once I got the hang of it, movement actually feels pretty good. You can slide and sprint, and you have a double-jump right from the start. There's also a fun rail system that adds to mobility; chaining rail slides and jumps+slides is fun.

I like how many things there are to unlock via exploration and collection and discoveries. There's lots of doors you can't get past, but they'll keep unlocking as you find the "keys" needed. Each door adds something to the game and/or run.

I'm not sure about replay-ability, I only just now got to the final boss for the first time (I've got ~4hrs of play time not on record, so about 12hrs for me to unlock progression to even reach the final boss).


Overall, I think this is worth $25. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes any of the 3 games I mentioned. The dev/s did a great job.

Roboquest is like if Doom 2016 and Borderlands had a roguelite baby.

Lots of secrets/routes, great weapon variety, fantastic class variety, satisfying gameplay, speedy movement, mechanical depth, secrets and alternate routes through the game - Roboquest has it all. You have a sprint, a slide, grinding on rails for extra speed, jumping on enemies' heads for melee damage while shooting other enemies or reloading. Enemies stagger after taking enough damage or Impact. You've got Borderlands-esque weapons with random effects/affixes of different qualities. You've got elemental damage systems. You've got some classes with rocket jumps, some with melee attacks, one that summons minions, etc etc. And, of course, items to grant you more buffs.

I played in Early Access until I had beaten everything that was available at the time, and have come back to it recently for the full release. I was surprised at how stellar the felt in Early Access, and the game has managed to pleasantly surprised me again somehow coming back to it now. 

Probably my only gripe is that when you haven't picked up a weapon yet, you can't see how big the magazine size is from the stats pop up, only that it's a mag type weapon vs an energy type weapon. Unless I'm missing something. That is probably the worst thing about the game for me, and it's pretty minor.

Roboquest is probably a 9/10 game for me personally at the moment, and could probably grow into a 10/10 as I play it more and discover the rest of the game. Co-op is a blast, but most of my time has just been spent in single player.

I love Roboquest and I've got 10 good things to say about it for each bad thing, however, the game has a ludicrous, ridiculous, absurd, surreal problem that, until fixed, will maintain this review as negative: The graphics implode if you play on a 1080p monitor. For as long as your monitor's resolution is the "standard" 1920x1080, things will look blurry and awful and there is nothing you can do about it AFAIK.

It's a Roguelite shooter similar to Gunfire Reborn or Immortal Redneck.
You run, jump, slide and kill anything that comes across your road. 
You gain xp and choose passive perks at each new level. 

There are five classes to choose and like Immortal Redneck, the player has the opportunity to power up their base, run after run, in order to make the next journey easier.

Unlike in EA, enemies now drop weapons regularly.

The major flaw of RoboQuest is you can't manually save your progress which is really annoying. The game auto-save whenever you're back in your basecamp but that's all.

Another flaw are the musics. It's some cheap and generic wannabe 90' techno and tiresome drum and bass. They give headaches in ten minutes.

But apart for that, RoboQuest is a pretty good game.
The gunplay is good, the movements and mechanics are precise. 
And a special point for the bosses encouters. They're very well designed.

Roboquest is quite possibly the best roguelike shooter out there. To be fair, there aren't many games in this sub-genre, but Roboquest already surpasses the outstanding Gunfire Reborn by miles. The controls are extremely responsive and at no point (unless you're playing co-op) do you ever feel like you've been unfairly hit by an enemy. There are many secrets to unlock and many mechanics to figure out. The variety of weapons is outstanding, many weapons can be extremely useful depending on their stats. The 6 robots to play have many different upgrade options and are very different to play.

The only thing that slightly spoiled my enjoyment of the game was an obviously buggy achievement. This will be important for some achievement hunters. I don't think this is a spoiler at all, but if you really don't want to know anything about the game, don't read any further:

There is an achievement called 'Master Gambler' and I can absolutely promise you, this achievement definitely does not work the way it should mathematically. You have a 25% chance if you pick up a specific item that you will get "an effect" and the achievement that comes with it. However, I have specifically picked up the item (without exaggerating) about 70 - 80 times and got it when I almost given up hope. 

A friend with whom I played most of the game received "the effect" of the item once after 47 hours of play, although he almost always selected the item once he had completed it. I reported the bug, but have not received any feedback to date. For all future players, I can only hope that the developers will address this issue. 
It's a shame that an otherwise flawless game has a bug like this that has never been fixed after all this time.

My biggest criticism of the game is that a lot of the truly necessary movement abilities are locked behind a decent amount of progression (jetpack, grappling hook, double jump, super jump all need to be unlocked), and the game will feel very punishing without them.

Not just one of my favorite FPS games but one of my favorite games, period.

There are some criticisms I have with the game that are so minor that they're laughable but still take this down a notch:

- NPCs with bug-eyed stares
- Pixellated explosions after boss battles that don't align with the comic book art style
- Word bubbles don't have solid borders like comics do
- Randomly appearing UI panel in the entrance of the final stage
- Lo-res textures (even when playing on Ultra)
- Not sure why title is stylized as "Roboquest" and not "Robo Quest" or "ROBO QUEST"

But even with those small gripes, it's a 9/10.

Roboquest has a satisfyingly fast movement system, and an interesting array of weaponry. Unfortunately it's let down its grey health system, its unadventurous classes, and a lack of interesting interactions between players in co-op.

In a game like Deadlink or Doom Eternal, the risk of diving into a pack of enemies is offset by the potential reward. In Deadlink in particular, HP is split between shields, which are easily replenished, and health, which is more difficult to regain. Roboquest uses a grey health mechanic instead, with recently lost HP being easier to recover. Unfortunately this means it's almost never worth risking health. With a shield/HP mechanic, you can take more risks when your shields are full, and play more defensively when your shields are gone. In Roboquest play becomes more and more cautious as your health reserves deplete.

The class abilities lack impact. The engineer class, for instance, gets two drones that deal damage to random enemies, and can absorb fire, but you have no control over them. This means they are effectively a passive increase in damage and HP. You also get a rocket you can chain inbetween weapon reloads. Contrast this to other engineer classes in games like Deadlink or Deep Rock Galactic. In those, the engineer deploys a static turret, and thus has to think about positioning. There's often a way to take direct control of the turret, and both Deadlink and Deep Rock have additional abilities to supplement the turret.

Finally, we have a lack of interaction between players in co-op. There are *some* abilities that you can get through random drops, such as a deployable forceshield, that encourage cooperative play - but most of the time you're playing independently. Even reviving downed players often isn't worth it, as they'll revive automatically anyway and it costs half your HP to do so.

In a world saturated with gaming titles, it's easy for some exceptional gems to slip through the cracks, and Robo Quest is undoubtedly one of them. Often overshadowed by bigger franchises, this indie marvel deserves a spotlight for its captivating gameplay, engaging mechanics, and a delightful blend of old-school charm and modern design.

Graphics and Art Style:
Robo Quest may not boast AAA graphics, but what it lacks in hyper-realism, it compensates with a vibrant and retro-inspired aesthetic. The pixel art is not just nostalgic; it's a deliberate choice that enhances the game's overall character. The visuals are clean, crisp, and effectively convey the game's futuristic world without unnecessary frills.

Gameplay Mechanics:
At the core of Robo Quest lies its addictive and finely tuned gameplay. This roguelike first-person shooter seamlessly combines the best of classic shooters with modern mechanics. The controls are intuitive, and the fluid movement makes navigating through the various levels a joy. What sets Robo Quest apart is its emphasis on skill-based combat, requiring players to master their arsenal and adapt to the ever-evolving challenges of procedurally generated levels.

Character Development and Customization:
One of the standout features of Robo Quest is its extensive character development and customization options. Players can choose from a diverse cast of characters, each with unique abilities and playstyles. The game's upgrade system allows for meaningful progression, ensuring that each run feels like a step toward becoming a powerhouse. The variety of weapons and equipment adds depth to the experience, encouraging experimentation to find the perfect loadout.

Replayability:
The roguelike nature of Robo Quest ensures that no two playthroughs are the same. The procedurally generated levels keep the experience fresh, while the plethora of character builds and weapon combinations add immense replay value. The desire to uncover hidden secrets and discover optimal strategies fuels the urge to dive back into the game repeatedly.

Community Engagement and Developer Support:
Despite its relatively modest following, the Robo Quest community is passionate and dedicated. The developers' commitment to regularly updating the game with new content, addressing player feedback, and fostering an active community is commendable. It's clear that the creators are invested in the game's success and the satisfaction of their player base.

Conclusion:
Robo Quest may be a hidden gem, but its brilliance shines through for those willing to give it a chance. The combination of engaging gameplay, nostalgic aesthetics, and a commitment to player satisfaction makes it a standout title in the crowded gaming landscape. If you're a fan of roguelike shooters or simply appreciate a well-crafted indie game, Robo Quest deserves a spot in your library. Don't let this overlooked gem pass you by.

Roboquest is great and awesome as a 2-player co-op experience. Buy this game now! It's most similar to Gunfire Reborn if you've played that game but with enough differences to make it a truly unique experience that stands out on it's own.

It blends exploration and meta-progression with Roguelike in a new way that's fresh and interesting.

The combat is so good too. The weapons each have their own unique strengths and playstyles that make them fun. The 6 classes all have several builds that let you play them in unique ways. Many roguelikes try to achieve this level of gameplay variance and this game does so effortlessly. The combat fundamentals of movement and shooting are outstanding quality too. Once you make it further in the game and unlock more core abilities it just gets even more fun.

The level design is brilliant. The limited budget/focus on story and cutscenes fits the game and still makes an impact with very limited scenes and dialog. The art style is unique and serves the game well.

The only way I could think to improve this game is to give me more! More cool stages. More cool bosses. More classes etc. At about 30 hours we've completed the game a few time and while it's still fun to play it feels like we've seen it all.

The only minor gripe I'd have is to rethink the last boss. [Spoiler]It's easy to cheese past a majority of the mechanics using the grappling hook. This is required if you're using a melee build. I think maybe the last boss needs some platforms to stand on that give unique mechanics or something for melee. In fact, once you get the grappling hook / jetpack you can cheese the bosses quite a bit in general. [/spoiler]

The release definitely rounded out this game to be worth the purchase. Previous to release it was only really fun with a friend but now both singleplayer and co-op have an appeal, but definitely play with a friend if possible

In roguelike games, choices should matter and in Roboquest it feels way too forgiving and easy to switch builds within a moments notice. I dont think that your run should be "ruined" because of one or two choices, but every act you have the opportunity to just try a different build(and it feels encouraged to do so because weapons have a star system aka level, you should be using higher stared weapons). Level up upgrades are pretty close to perfect with this last update, I think that is the most fun part to choose from. Core passive bonus's are very lackluster with the passive bonus's given I also think all passive core bonus's should stack, or they should have random affix's similar to the levelup upgrades. Roboquest as a kind of session based borderlands game is great. As a roguelike FPS it is missing a lot, and feels like it is having an identity crisis.

This is by no means a bad game, but the overwhelmingly positive reviews are a little puzzling to me. Personally, I really struggled to stay engaged after a few hours and decided to ultimately move on. The actual shooting and movement is smooth and enjoyable, but there are a lot of problems around that core gameplay. Aesthetically, the art design and environments have a nice, clean look, but the style can be generic at times and the arenas themselves are often really small and blend together quickly. But most importantly, I think this game suffers from the same issue a lot of FPS rougelites do - because your equipment isn't determined in advance, every weapon has to work "good enough" in every situation, and as a result encounters just start to blend together and you rarely get into a situation where you feel any pressure to branch out. 

In classic FPS games like Doom or Dusk, the level designer can depend on you having a particular weapon at a particular time, and that means enemy types and locations can be designed in ways that force you to rely on your entire arsenal. But here, it felt like I could approach any arena with any weapon, and as a result I basically just played the game the same way every time. I found myself regularly switching weapons or using abilities not because the situation actually required me to, but because I wanted to force myself to get some variety. And ironically, the game really reinforces this by throwing *so many* new weapons at you every moment, which just makes it more obvious how similar the combat loop actually is each time. I realize this is sorta baked in to the basic structure of the game, but I still wish they'd taken some more steps to push players towards creative engagement in ways that differentiate different equipment more. As it stands, runs are enjoyable but they quickly start to feel the same unless you really go out of your way to seek out novelty. I think there are a lot of people who don't mind doing that, but for me, it really got in the way of me enjoying things.

The combat is so smooth its like Doom and Risk of Rain 2 combined. Which is as high of a compliment that I can possibly give! I love the nods to other games that a lot of the weapons seem based off of.

UPDATED REVIEW:
They really done it. They went above and beyond my expectation with this game. I've been playing it in and out since the early access, but now with the actual release of the game, all that potential I was talking about has been unleashed. Updating this review as I unlocked all achievements for the game.

Things I LIKE:
- The game has a lot of fun weapons. I love all the robots (classes), they provide different ways of playing the game, even with the same robot, you have more than one possible way of playing around it.
- The exploration feels very satisfying. The puzzles are also a nice touch to some of the unlocks and they don't feel over-welcomed.
- I love how they made the gadgets a toggle and ALL usable, instead of having to pick in only 2 or 3.
- The movement feels soooooo smooth. Sliding, double (or triple) jumping, grappling hook, jet pack, hero landing, all of it feels natural.
- The game feels harder compared to the Early Access, but in a good way. It is challenging, but never felt unfair.
- The net-code is amazing. Been playing with a friend and we are having a blast. Only had issues of disconnection once, but that was probably our own ISP fault, and not the game. Haven't tried playing with someone from another country, but with a close friend, it is flawless.
- The OST is really good, always keeping you hyped for the stages and boss fights.
- The game performance is also one of the highlights here. I don't think I've ever dropped frames in this game or had a stutter, it simply WORKS.


Thins I DISLIKE or would like to see changes:
- Going for museum completion feels a little boring. You just keep on spamming runs until you finally find the items you're missing. The cards with the artists are really helpful for weapons and mobs (Thank you!), but the Bazaar takes a while to complete.
- The achievement for using the Bonk Hammer on Diggy Mole should specify that you need to use ONLY the hammer to kill the boss. Doing only the final hit won't count.
- I have a small issue with the auto-run option, where sometimes it will go back to only walking. I still haven't figured what triggers it. It's a minor annoyance that doesn't make the game any worse, but still present sometimes.


I'd say this game is definitely worth a purchase if you are into roguelikes and FPS games, specially ones with more movement options. The game does feel hard at the begin, even at the Standard difficulty, but not unfair, and as you unlock more movement options, things becomes easier and even more satisfying to pull off. In the end, it's an addicting formula of movement and satisfying gunplay.

------------------------------------

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW:
So far the game is REALLY fun. The gameplay after a few minutes already feels really natural and responsive. Of course since it's early access, there's not much content. Once you've completed the game, you pretty much have to complete it again on a harder difficulty.

I'm really looking forward for how the developers will treat and update this game, it sure has A LOT of potential.

The movement, the combat, both immensely satisfying, with the music only compounding the adrenaline. Even with this few hours in the game, I'm having a lot of fun, I will see how it holds up long term. But from what I've seen so far, this is definitely something else. Highly recommend.

1.7k peak players is unacceptable for a game this good. Roboquest is a really well tuned example of a fps-roguelike. Flying through levels with blast jumping, riding, the grappling hook, and the movement abilities of each class, or absolutely melting bosses and hordes of minions with the momentum-focused combat aren't the best I've ever experienced in an action-roguelike, but it's still pretty damn good. Having an ost made by Noisecream and visual aesthetics evocative of Borderlands' sobel lighting system are cherries on top to fucking losers like me who like writing steam reviews.
While I wish Roboquest had features like 4-player co-op, higher difficulty options, or modding support, to deny that what is here is worth the price tag would be stupid on my part. I've said this for other games, but if you're not gonna buy it for full price you should at least keep an eye out for when it goes on sale, which seems pretty frequent.

I played this game pretty early in its early access and I think the game overall has become worse since then despite its development time. Previously upgrades were found in items that boosted a colored stat that would boost damage and if I recall correctly give addition effects at certain amounts. Now, seemingly from the success of gunfire reborn, that system was completely removed in favor of a system like the scrolls. I think that change was for the worse as it removed what made roboquests guns and upgrades unique while adding very uninteresting passive. I played a run in the current version where I got a passive upgrade that made it so when I used my primary ability there was a 10% chance for my movement controls to be inverted in a movement shooter. In the early versions I thought a large number of the enemies bullets were too difficult to dodge and I think that is still the case, especially in zone 3 with the roaming target bosses.

This game is a lot of fun but not as long as most Roguelites are. I have unlocked almost everything in the game (only need like 2 more things) and then I've got all the goodies. Thankfully I got it on sale but full price its about $2 per hour of gameplay. What you get though is a decently polished indie experience. There isnt really anything fancy about the cutscenes but the game has its jokes and its quirks and it makes it feel like a kind of joyful adventure. 

This ties into my next point about the music, and dont get me wrong the music is good... but... the clearly doom inspired metal vibe for combat etc is just too cliche for me when its combined with the extreme juxtaposition of the rest of the soundtrack, like it was put there for you to stop and go OMG THEY DID WHAT DOOM DID... but after hearing so many indie games do this it just falls flat for me.  Like I said though, the music isn't bad, its just not really inspired, unique and lacks a connection to the actual gameplay.

Ultimately pick this up on a sale if you want a fairly short roguelite, its a decent game to play solo or with a friend.

Probably the best movement-shooter I have played, and the combination of the weapons-, items- and perks-systems is plenty fun, though I think it still has a lot of untapped potential when it comes to the movement-aspect of the game.

Some of my gripes with the movement:
The grappling hook currently feels like a hook shot from zelda, which is boring to me. IMO it would feel way better if it functioned more like Loader's grappling hook in risk of rain 2, for example. So letting you swing from it and click a button to let go. Right now using it pulls you straight to it's grapple-point, killing your momentum. So using it actually feels bad. Luckily you can ignore it entirely :)
The rail-grinding feels janky and unrewarding, the way it locks to a speed and bases the direction you grind purely on the direction you faced when landing, NOT your momentum when landing, so grinding feels choppy the way it changes your monentum instantly.
I think not giving the player so many jumps and a free jetpack all the time, and then fixing rails and the grappling hook, + maybe a wall running mechanic(?) would be crazy fun. Though this would probably lead to a huge balance being necessary, because combat now is balanced around you being able to fly over and kite enemies/projectiles extremely efficiently. Or it would make the game a lot harder. (which I am also not opposed to)

Though the game is still crazy good. You should play it.

Hands down the best fps roguelite on the market as of 2023

It. Kicks. Ass.

Very new-Doom inspired roguelite. Dozens of base weapons with random modifiers - the Typhoon Minigun will always be an energy weapon with slowdown while firing and homing projectiles, but in some runs it might deal fire damage and in others the projectiles might bounce. Items aren't randomized and give minor perks. Might give ice weapons bonus critical damage, or shock nearby enemies, or give a triple jump. There's also corrupted items with a downside - so, 12% damage resist but 12% less movespeed. You can see what an item does before you pick it up, so there's less of a barrier to entry than something like Risk of Rain.
Unlike most roguelites you also level up at a baseline. There's six classes each with two abilities, and most level-up skills are unique between classes, or shared with one other class. Sometimes this will interact with an ability - making a thrown spear also mark enemies for bonus damage - and other times it'll impact base gameplay - infusing all weapons with elemental damage of a certain type. Also unlike most roguelites there isn't really a "god run". You'll never get items and weapons so good that you can just AFK through combat or blindly shoot a wall and let splash damage clear everything for you. You'll always have to dodge attacks and aim to some extent.
You get ranked not just on difficulty but on speed and kill percentage. This'll give you more powercells (currency) to use during a run, and also gives bragging rights for a full S-rank max difficulty run. That's a large part of the replayability for this game, though - experimentation with builds for better times on higher difficulties. The random generation alone unfortunately isn't robust enough for that to give as much variety. You'll recognize the overall layouts very fast, even if the specifics are a little different. Another issue: the game has a lot of meta-progression. Not, like, Binding of Isaac where you're checking off 500 completion marks, but closer to Hades where you get a *lot* of direct upgrades as you do more and more runs. It doesn't take that long to actually unlock everything (I had basically all meta-progression in under 15 hours), but it means you're probably never beating this game on Hard on your first run. And the higher difficulties especially just outright assume you have basically everything unlocked for you to even put up a fight.
Still, there's a good amount of really good game here, especially if you're a big Doom or Ultrakill fan. Just don't expect quite that level of perfection.

A highly addictive DOOM-inspired FPS Roguelite. This game is the closest we have to a procedurally generated boomer shooter, despite several design decisions that steer it away from being a "purebred" one; mainly, you can only have two weapons, and the maps are often narrower than the usual arena.

Despite that, the game has a well-executed focus on mobility and its RPG elements, which play to the roguelite elements perfectly, creating a very original experience. Add a heavy and powerful soundtrack that plays constantly through the levels, and the whole experience feels almost hypnotic; I did NOT notice I played this for 24 hours, I can tell you that much.

This is the best FPS roguelite I ever played, and it came really close to being a GOTY contender. Here is hoping for a bolder and more ambitious Roboquest 2, as well as a strong recommendation that you buy this game regardless of your usual predilections, as this is an easy game to sit down and play for several hours.

I want to say that this is a good game, but one that I wouldn't recommend. I don't have a ton of playtime, but from what I have seen, the gameplay is fantastic, but feels shallow. Each gun is fun to use and the movement is great, but I never felt like any of the 'roguelite' choices I made had any effect. The upgrades are miniscule effects like 15% damage to flying enemies or 15% bonus melee damage or random things like that which were ultimately inconsequential. 

I also felt like the gameplay, while great on the surface, never really changed. They did add more enemies on the full release, but it's still the same stuff overall and you will be replaying many of the zones over and over again. This repetition wouldn't be a problem if the upgrade system lead to unique builds or the weapons lead to very distinct playstyles, but it's mostly just run and gun. 

A game that I think is similar but performs better in my opinion as a roguelike is Gunfire Reborn. The characters in Gunfire to me feel vastly different and actually have different playstyles and builds that make meaningful effects on the gameplay so even replaying the same floors over and over again can feel fresh.

[h1]Summary:[/h1]
One of the best FPS games to release in 2023, high intensity fun throughout a diverse set of levels, with a huge amount of secrets to find.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Starts slow, ramps to literal insanity
- Music is fantastic, best soundtrack of the year
- Game replay is enormous, and consistently fun.
- Character build diversity is crazy
- Gunplay feels great, even with the less meta guns

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- The game doesn't really start until you have all the gadgets / base built
- No pace marker for S rank levels

[h1]Overall:[/h1]
A fantastic blend of Risk of Rain 2, Borderlands, and Doom in high octane action, Absolutely worth the money.

[h2]Score: 9/10[/h2]

If you've enjoyed games like Gunfire Reborn, Risk of Rain 2, and Crab Champions (rouge-like shooters), this is right up your alley. Give it a shot.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Satisfying guns - feel/look/hit reg
- Fast movement with slides, double jumps, etc. 
- Variety of robots/classes to choose from
- Different upgrade build paths per robot
- Fun puzzles to solve
- Fun unlocks to get
- Gotta go fast maps
- Good learning curve
- Enjoyable simple story
- Well designed maps

[b]Thoughts[/b]
- Only 2 player co-op. Really wish there would be up to 4.
- Early feel of needing a grapple tied into the movement system was later resolved with getting better and gadget unlocks.
- Needs a run save option
- Needs a run history option
- No reconnect option in co-op disconnects
- Some weapons/builds/paths feel much stronger, so further balancing required
- Game rewards good aim -> crit build on all classes -> bit repetitive
- Looking forward to more/future content updates
- No infinite run mode at the moment

A fun game very similar to Gunfire Reborn. It a lot more polished, however. The primary difference is in the levels and balance:
[list]
[*]You get new abilities/passives less often, which can feel a bit limiting when you're looking forward to making a synchronizing build.
[*] It looks like enemy damage and health doesn't simply infinitely scale like it does in Gunfire. 
[*] Levels are a lot more detailed and feel more dynamic and vertical. The branching paths to different areas, each with their own requirements to progress to them, allows for even more exploration and progression. The lore of the game is hidden behind exploring the level to find hidden data pods, which also help towards meta-progression.
[*] Co-op doesn't feel as unbalanced based on different levels of progression (the meta-progression revolves more around giving you more options to take instead of flat buffs. Though there are still flat buffs within it, the buffs, so far as I've played, are a lot less minor, giving you utility over flat damage increases). In addition, the netcode doesn't seem to be delay-based, as you often find with co-op shooters.
[/list]
The price may feel steep, especially in comparison to Gunfire, but I think it is, in the end, worth it!

Roboquest was a really unexpected discovery for me.
While I've seen the early trailers and it looked pretty interesting, I was almost expecting it to fall flat and be just "one more fps roguelike"

But the variety of classes and their respective skills, guns, perks and challenges have kept me going.
The progression system also felt very well integrated, helping you get closer and closer to the end each time.

I just beat the final boss 20 hours into the game, and there is still some things I want to try and explore, including all the little side-challenges.

The unique tracks per each area that ramp up as you get closer to the buss to culminate in an epic finale is also worth pointing out. Bought the soundtrack later too as a result, as I really didn't expect it to be as good as it was.

Overall - if you like fps roguelikes (roguelites?) this one is definitely worth checking out. Fun, fast-paced, with a good variety of things to try and builds to discover. Hope there will be DLCs or other updates, because I'd love to play more of this!

TLDR; good game, Buy Roboquest if you'd like a decent first-person rough-like (and don't want gunfire cuz furry)

The shooting mechanics and "game feel," are truly incredible and if you liked doom or ultrakill you'll probably have a good time here.

I will say the main rough-like mechanics are a little underwhelming. It has similar weapon mechanics to dead-cells and a problem both games share, is that it's more temping to use a weapon you're used to, which leads to less run variety. Same goes for the level up perks, except unlike the weapons, which are all mostly viable, some of the perks can be down right useless it seems. 

Progression is also kinda strange in my opinion. The exploration is decently fun. I had a good time searching for a bunch of secerct areas and unlocking the elementalist (the games "seceret" character). I do have a dislike for rough-likes that almost require pre-run upgrades to get by. Don't get me wrong, if you're skilled enough you could beat the final boss on any difficulty without even touching the workbench, but upgrades are required for obtaining better weapons early game and late game as well as a major contributor to run variety. I can see a decent amount of people getting bored on the first few hours due to this and not waiting for it to "get good."

Praise to the glorious sound track and visuals too.

I do think this game has potential, especially judging by the devs. They made slight changes to the progression system from the early assess version to the 1.0 version and decided that it'd be a great idea to reset everyone's progression. Needless to say "gamers had upsetty." And despite stating a reason (they said they wanted everyone to experience the "new" progression system) they gave everyone effected the option to get there stuff back. To me this displays a they have good/basic understanding of how to please the player base and gives me optimism for them to listen to us players in the future.

(Also if ur a pc nut DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. I have a pretty decent graphics card and I keep getting studders. This leads me to believe the game isn't very well optimized and my hope is this will get addressed)

In short; a really solid movement shooter rogue-lite.

Roboquest could best be best described as a mix between Gunfire Reborn and Doom Eternal, borrowing the combat pace from the latter (as well as a few movement mechanics from the likes of Titanfall 2 which really rounds out your options from A to B) and the run building and randomised highly variable upgrades and weapons from the former. 

Having 100%-ed the game and all achievements at the time of writing, the amount of content may not be on par with either of the aforementioned games, however the movement and shooting mechanics are so polished and engaging that it's easy to find yourself picking the game up again to scratch the itch that only it can. 

Pair this with the excellent soundtrack produced by noisecream (featuring drum and bass, hard high bpm electronic and even some metal thrown in for good measure) and the experience comes together to completely justify the price of picking it up.

Final score is a solid robo out of quest.

Gameplay is super fun. Builds are fun to make and design throughout the runs. Many different areas, paths, and enemies. Gives room for verticality, and exploration. Nice graphics and music. Overall a romp! Great time with a buddy. 8.5/10.
Great co-op shooter. Very Relaxing to play after a long day at work.

Steam desperately needs a "Mixed" option for a game like this. On the one hand, Roboquest's moment-to-moment gameplay is very satisfying and has very solid gunplay and weapon variety. But on the other, it's also utterly shallow and there's a lot that hasn't improved since Early Access.

Considering the game has Overwhelmingly Positive reviews, I'm going to have to focus on the biggest negatives, since any positives I can list are dead air and reiteration of what's been said a thousand times.

- The weapon variety is good, but several of the weapons really need some help. Kaboom Grenade not detonating on contact with an enemy is genuinely baffling; I can't tell if it's a bug or not.

- The game is chock-full of so many boring, impactless upgrades. I know stacking 5 +% damage modifiers is going to have some compounding results, but it doesn't change how utterly BORING it all is. There's nothing like Gunfire's modifiers that really alter how certain weapons behave (like changing some weapons to a two-shot that either refunds the first bullet on kill, or gets a huge damage boost with the last shot); the best you can hope for is an alt-fire that basically just acts like a really dummy-simple weapon stapled to your main one.

- The gadget unlocks are horrendous now. It used to be that you unlocked gadgets by upgrading the basecamp, which gave you incentive to keep playing and always gave you something tangible to work towards; even if you lost a lot of runs early on, the wrenches still ultimately contributed towards new gadgets, so you'd eventually get them all just by playing. Now, you have to actively seek them out through "side-quests", though calling them "quests" is seriously disingenuous. There's no story to them, there's no journey, there's no substance. You bring a thing to an NPC, they give you a gadget; it's awful.

I could spend the rest of this review slagging off this new unlocking method...so I will. One of the NPCs requires you to show him a specific weapon (randomly determined, but doesn't change run-to-run). This game has enough guns that getting it to show up might take a half-dozen tries or more, then you have to actually bring it to him, and he's a few stages deep, so if it's a weapon you hate using, you'll be playing with one hand tied behind your back. So you finally manage to bring it to him, and...not only does he give you nothing, but he has the gall to ask you to bring him another weapon (once again, randomly determined). Since you can't do ANY backtracking at all or looping, you have to just restart the whole run to try to bring this idiot another weapon.

So another half-dozen or more runs, you get the weapon and bring it to him, and you know what happens? Not only do you not get a gadget, but HE WANTS YOU TO BRING HIM ANOTHER WEAPON. This a-hole wants you to show him THREE WEAPONS in total. DEAR GOD, I wanted so badly to be able to just kill him and take his gadget off his body. This is holding a significant gameplay aspect (a gadget, AKA a permanent run modifier) hostage behind a godawful RNG grind.

This is unbelievably bad design, and this is just for ONE gadget. Good luck getting all of the gadgets without a guide open at all times.

So, if you're wondering, yes, I am in fact giving the game a thumbs down almost entirely off of the back of the gadget unlocks. The early access method of unlocking them as your base was upgraded was FINE, this was a completely unnecessary change made purely for the sake of change. Trash this entire "quest" non-system and go back to the early access method, and this review immediately swings to a thumbs up.

It's a movement shooter rogue-like, which pulls of the formula really well. Sure there are ways to survive for a while with relying on power ups, or tanking damage, but the truly "broken" stuff is achieved with mechanical skill backing up different combos, which feels really good to pull off. And there seems to be enough control in difficulty levels to make stuff accessible for people just getting into FPS games, to some more experienced, with harder difficulties being unlocked from completing the game.

This is THE roguelite FPS experience. A vast array of weapons with a multitude of random affixes with the kind of variety that should suit just about any playstyle you have. An impressive roster of bots to unlock and choose from each with their own skill trees and special abilities that also run the gamut of playstyles. Secrets and collectibles abound. Unlockable higher difficulties. One of the most addictive co-op experiences I've had in recent memory. Stat upgrades that actually feel impactful when you get 15% more. Permanent upgrades as you discover more of the world and loop back again to take a different route the next time. It is also among the most mechanically smooth and responsive movement tech games this year. It's so, so good.

You could be harnessing the power of the elements, riding a legendary rocket-powered shovel into combat. Or, you could be commanding a swarm of drones like angry bees. Or, you could even be goading the enemy to attack your holographic decoy while you set up the perfect position to snipe, or even be the deadliest blade in the land with dash attacks, going face to face off the kick. There are many antics and items that can be discovered and combined for a unique flavor of chaos each and every time. And if you ask, "can I stack these two bonuses?" the answer is *yes*, and you will want every advantage you can get before the final boss fight.

But you don't need to take my word for it. Get the demo. If you also find yourself loving this game, don't skip the soundtrack, it's amazing. (And grab some paper to make a map; the one from the Museum can't be accessed during an in-progress run, and not all doors to the next sections are marked.)

Just a great game to play after work to relax--even better if you have a buddy to run with.  I will also mention to parents that this is a great game for kids who want a "shooter" without mature content.  You are a robot fighting other robots and the art-style is fun.

+ Robot play styles are unique enough to make builds interesting

The game has some great gunplay, movement and audio but lacks in the areas that make you want to keep playing after the initial exciement. (My playtime is wrong, not sure why steam just decided not to track it, I had 3 hours before refunding)

There is very little content actually here and the levels repeat often, far more often than a game like Risk of Rain 2 (another roguelite). 

The balancing also seems to have gotten way off since I last played it, now being even more difficult fairly early on meaning that if you dont end up RNG rolling the best meta weapons early on you might as well just restart cause the run is doomed to fail. Even the positive reviews are mentioning how many of the weapons are straight up useless.

RNG is this games other problem. Going back to Risk of Rain, they have RNG rolls too but because they're frequent a bad one doesn't hit too hard. If you get a bad one here you feel it for a while and sometimes can't recover at all because of the aforementioned sometimes useless weapons.

Overall its not a bad game, but considering they just raised the price for the 1.0 release, it has to be compared to other games at that price point and it doesn't hold up to them IMO. It relies on RNG but lacks balanced RNG choices and lacks a variety of levels ensuring repetitiveness fairly quickly.

I frankly don't understand the positive reviews, it deserves some for sure but not 90%+
it makes a little more sense when you realise most of them have very few hours on the game. Over half of the reviews didn't even play past 6-7 hours. You'll get more time than that out of Deep Rock, Risk of Rain, etc. for a similar price.

[h2]TL;DR: Digital speed. It has a free demo. It is on Xbox Game Pass. Try it, love it, buy it.[/h2]

The only roguelite I‚Äôve ever really enjoyed has been Vampire Survivors, which I‚Äôve often seen referred to as ‚Äòdigital crack‚Äô.

Well, if VS is digital crack, then Roboquest is digital speed.

Roboquest mixes frenzied run ‚Äòn‚Äô gun gameplay with extremely enjoyable movement and a deep selection of weapons and upgrades available for obsessively tweaking the perfect build.

The wide variety of guns ensures you can always try something else if you‚Äôre bored of a weapon, although I have my favorites (scout sniper <3). The pocket reload mechanic, time-graded levels, and Doom Eternal-esque health pickup system favor fast-paced gameplay, which goes hand in hand with the frenetic movement system.

Sliding, slide jumping, double jumping, rails (think Sunset Overdrive), and a gamut of unlockable movement items make movement a dream in this game. I haven‚Äôt enjoyed traversing a game world this much since playing Ghostrunner, whose gameplay focuses entirely on its parkour. Not to mention how fun it is to headbonk (goomba stomp) robots.

What ties this addictive loop together are the roguelite meta-progression and the upgrade system, the latter of which also levels the playing field when it comes to gameplay. The game heavily favors skilled twitch shooting with its critical system and fast-paced nature, but you can‚Äôt breeze through the game on aiming skills alone. You need to craft a well-thought-out build if you want to beat the game on higher difficulties with S-tier time, but at the same time, the game allows you to experiment with unorthodox builds and weapons (e.g. [spoiler][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WAvqn1Lvn7U]shovel only[/url][/spoiler]). Still, the game requires more skill and engagement than a game like Vampire Survivors, where at a certain point in your build you just watch numbers go up while hitting WASD randomly (which, to be fair, is also very dopamine producing, hence ‚Äòdigital crack‚Äô).

I‚Äôve played other roguelite shooters like Risk of Rain 2, but they did not draw me in as much as Roboquest has. I‚Äôve just started the game, and instead of focusing on beating it with my favorite build (Ranger/crit/ricochet OP) I‚Äôve been distracted by finding secrets, trying out different builds and weapons, seeing what cool builds other players have beat the game with, and of course, slide jumping through levels like a [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SNvDUO42Hys]robotic phoon[/url].

I do wish some parts of the progression weren‚Äôt gated behind secrets, because I feel like if I haven‚Äôt found them at a certain point, I‚Äôm handicapping myself. Other than that, I purchased it on release and the game has run great, I‚Äôve experienced no bugs, the [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t2AUlcq1huA]soundtrack is awesome[/url], and I find the cartoony cel-shaded art style very endearing (the little 2D animated cutscenes that play with each new level are very cool too). Mix this with the addictive nature of both the gameplay and the ‚Äòone more run‚Äô roguelite meta-progression, and you have a gem on your hands. Can‚Äôt wait to eventually beat it on Guardian IV, and I‚Äôm hoping there‚Äôs DLC, a sequel, or any form of Roboquest content announced in the future, although this game will keep me very busy in the meantime.

Oh, and there‚Äôs coop too so you can even play with your brobots!

First things first: Not only is the music awesome, but the way it's implemented is extremely cool as well! When you are in a transitional area of a level (there will be a lot of these moments where you are taking a break from the fighting to level up, heal, and purchase new items), the soundtrack loops unobtrusively in a low energy part of the song. But the moment you step out those doors and all the enemies turn to look at you, the song immediately has a high energy drop to instantly make you feel like the DOOM Slayer again. Seriously, look up a gameplay video so you can see what I'm talking about, it's very satisfying!

Beyond that, the game oozes style. The visual design is sort of reminiscent of Borderlands games, with inking around character models, bold comic-book-y color palettes, and a scrap-punk aesthetic. The gunplay and movement feel really tight and responsive. I've only played kbm, so I'm not sure what controller support is like, but I'm guessing it probably plays better with mouse-like aim. The enemy variety feels really good.

I only have two critique, and they're pretty minor. First, balance. There are several perk options for each class that are fun, versatile, and powerful, making it easy to want to take them when offered. Unfortunately, there are also a number of perk options that I'll only ever take once just to fill out the catalogue. It's to be expected that not every option in a roguelike is going to be equally good, or equally good in all scenarios, but I do hope that the devs will make some small tweaks here and there so certain classes feel more consistently fun (Elementalist probably being the most affected by this).

Second is that there's no way to see what build components are available to your character in the middle of a run. If you've ever played Enter the Gungeon, think of the Ammonomicon being available in the pause menu. I would really like to see the devs add a way to check what perks, items, and weapons are available to you without having to alt-tab out to the wiki in your web browser.

Overall I definitely recommend this game. Maybe 8-9/10?

I do not recommend the game, but with a caveat - I don't recommend the game unless it's on sale. It's a good game but very, VERY shallow. 

Despite the, odd, "overwhelmingly positive" reviews, the game doesn't have much to offer but the same ol' thing over and over and over again with very little in the way of changing playstyle. The best weapons are the best weapons, even if those weapons are low tier, they're still better than most high tier of any other weapon. Don't get that weapon? Lol. Sorry? 

The "upgrades" from the basecamp (the thing that makes this a roguelite) are basically useless. Sure, they add a little help but not a whole lot. Many of the "upgrades" are to increase the chance that you'll get, for example, higher level or higher tier weapons, but despite putting "wrenches" into those, they don't seem to work all that well. I remember the 2nd upgrade to the 'increase weapon rarity' was followed by 3 whites, 1 green, none of which were the good weapons. 

This game appears to really center around achievement hounds who just want to "beat" or "finish" everything. For example, you can get a battle buddy that is absolutely useless. But, it's there. For no real reason. You can trade out a weapon slot (you only get 2) for it but, yeah, it really isn't good. Go ahead, level him up .... use up those power cells. It still sucks but, you did it! Yay you. 

The game play really is solid, though. The graphics are pretty killer. But, the mechanics of the game leave much to be desired and you'll end up just doing the same levels over and over and over and over and over again just to "get that thing that sucks." 

If I were you, I wouldn't spend more than $14.99 on the game. It's not worth $25, imo. There's just not enough there. I've played 14 hours and actually reached the boss level in my first two hours of play time because I just happened to get the right drops on the right class with the right weapon. It's basically the only way you can win. Skill won't get you there. "choices" won't really get you there either. You can't make a good build from things that drop by changing your strategy - it's just not a thing in this game. 

You have to RNG the right weapons, the right level perks w/the right gadgets. If you don't, you won't get very far. When you do, you'll get to the boss and you'll get snagged in multiple ridiculous hacks (that take control of you) or "stunned" over and over again. Instead of the enemies being "harder," they just throw cheesy "difficulty" tactics at you and "yay you" if you happen to have a build that will overcome it. 

Skill isn't the winner or loser in this game - RNG is. Don't get me wrong, I don't hate the game. But, they really need to fix this stuff. I shouldn't rely on certain weapons with every playthrough. But, that's the way it is.

It aged awesomely and came a long way. Its fun, soundtrack slaps and its one of the most smooth running FPS ive ever encountered. There are a ton of easter eggs and secrets to keep you busy and exploring, the guns and gunfire feel amazing. I do have two problems with it. Firstly - the size and amount of enemy projectiles. Honestly, enemy shots (regular, not bosses, bosses are ok) that take up half your screen and are almost impossible to dodge sometimes (and they do ton of damage) do get annoying. Secondly - recovery orbs do not stay long enough, so the game promotes aggressive gameplay, making you jump into danger more and more to recover health as you fight, and considering the first problem, that isnt always fun. Also also it means that playing as a sniper is heavely disencouraged, meaning you have almost no way to quickly recover health. I still recommend this game, its awesome, but its on the harder spectrum of games and the visuals are deceiving. It is NOT meant for a casual passtime.

It's appalling how little attention this game has gotten. This game has a ton of depth, an incredibly satisfying combat system, and a lot of replayability. There are 6 characters in the game as of this review, and each one has its own upgrades that noticeably change the way you play the game. 

For example, Guardian, the starter class, has 2 abilities: Bastion and Bash. Bastion is a bubble shield on yourself that lasts for 3 seconds, making you immune to all damage. Bash is a melee attack. Right off the bat, these two abilities synergize well, since bastion protects you while you use bash in the enemies' faces. You can also use the shield as a panic button for when you mess up and need the invulnerability. Just two upgrades can change these from a defensive option and low health enemy control, into a DPS machine. One upgrade changes bash to bonk, where you get a hammer. The second upgrade, flex handle, increases your swing speed by 50% when you use bastion. Now, instead of being second rate damage compared to your guns, you can throw on bastion and go rip and tear through everything for those 3 seconds. Want more duration on bastion? There's an upgrade for that. Want more armor to tank hits better? There's an upgrade for that. Hell, you could forgo that damage build entirely, and instead spec into using bash as a support tool. Linebreaker increases your guns' damage by a whopping 50% after hitting bash.

I could go on for every other class if I had the time, and if you had the patience. This game absolutely provides the feeling of POWER that makes rogue-likes work. The art style is also very nice. It's good in multiplayer too.

All the classes have the same role of dealing damage, (except elementalist, who is currently OP as hell) but the developers have really outdone themselves giving each one its own flavor. It never feels stale to switch between characters, because they all play so differently.

9.5/10 game, my only complaint is the lack of sound cues for enemies about to shoot you. It can get pretty hard to tell what's going on in later levels. That's probably just a skill issue on my end, though.

Handles somewhere between DOOM 2016 and DOOM Eternal with a bit more variety in some areas and a bit less in others for an overall highly satisfying gameplay loop. Lots of different weapons that actually function differently, plus plenty of affixes, alt-fires, and perks for variety. The graphics are clean and the game as a whole is very well-optimized, even with ragdoll corpses by the dozens onscreen, and the sound design and music are nearly perfect. If you want a 3D roguelite FPS with movement shooter flavor, Roboquest rocks.

Coop roguelite shooter with lots of content, reminds me of Borderlands a bit.

+ The guns are super nice, lots of variation, playstyles, upgrades. This is what makes the game fun, every run is different because you can create the build that you want.
+ There are no ammo pickups, instead you swap to your secondary weapon and your ammo regenerates automatically. It's genius for this type of game as it keeps the action going and makes you want to use both guns.
+ Characters have some unique abilities and their own upgrades to further diversify your playstyle.
+ Plenty of bosses, elites, different routes.
+ Love the cartoony art style.
+ Map design is nice, the difference between floors keeps gameplay fresh. Enemies are all on the same level but there is some verticality and jump pads for tactical advantage.
+ They included the Flak Cannon from Unreal Tournament! <3
+ Higher difficulties are fun and challenging
- The earlier floors do get a bit repetitive after a few playthroughs, but you'll blast through them pretty quickly after a few upgrades.

Roboquest is a really fun shooter with fast action, great guns, lots of content to unlock. High replay value where each run will take about half an hour. It does get a bit repetitive if you die early on, but I keep coming back for more.

I don't usually write reviews, but for some reason I wanted to this time.
So, it's a roguelite FPS that plays pretty good, feels smooth and has some challenge (too much at some places imo) to it. But there's a couple of things that could've been a lot better.

The first is a roguelite aspect. Like, it's there, it's decent, but it's a bit shallow. What I mean is that you don't get any new guns and while in the beginning it feels nice to get new guns every time, you quickly realize that you've seen all of them and won't unlock anything new (unlike something like Gunfire Reborn).

The second is plot. It is there, but it's not really coherent. It's like devs wanted to do a decent story, but for some reason decided not to flesh it out in the end.

Other than those 2 things the game's pretty much perfect and I'd give it like 8\10, but no patches or dev blogs for like 3 weeks is kind of concerning.

The review that said the demo told me everything I needed to know was very correct. You can even experience the co-op in the demo. Game asked to be nominated for best soundtrack, but I think it should be up for most innovated game play. Everything about the game is very enjoyable from the shooting, classes, augments/traits, to the story. I was very surprised at how interesting the story is. I really was not expecting the Act 3 twist. The only down side is the co-op is limited to two players. HOWEVER, after playing the game, it is completely balanced for only 2 brobots. You would need to completely redo all of the levels and monsters to have more people and at that point it is not the same game. Just share time with different friends and swap up the runs. A great $20 spend, which was 40 cause I bought is as well for a friend. I would do it again.

I loved Risk of Rain but I felt like some characters were too squishy and were strong against some enemies and completely weak against others. 
This game I have liked 3 of the 5 characters (I only have 4 unlocked). Being able to upgrade your abilities and not just your weapons make picking your character mean that much more. Weapons are a little weird as I personally feel there are really only a few I think are good but they are all viable. Once you pick an ability upgrade you will then get upgrades for that ability and you can just make that 1 ability crazy good or upgrade all your abilities or just your character.
There are 2 in game currencies. Powercells are used during your run to unlock abilities or buy/upgrade guns. The second are wrenches which are used in your camp to upgrade vendors and their options they have or add the possibility for them to pop up more, basically making your runs have the possibility for more or stronger upgrades.

TLDR:
Good character selection
Ability upgrades are fun/unique and open the possibility of crazy builds
Most guns are okay with only a few I find great
10/10 sound track
Boss fights are heart racing
Awesome game! Very impressed by how fluid this game is. Combat is golden! 10/10 would play again..........and again :D

Roboquest is one of my FAVORITE Indie games to ever come-out. Not because of the endless amounts BUILDS you can get and rouge-lite mechanics of it, not because of the PRISTINE GIGANTIC WEAPON arsenal that have well made models and animations the game boosts (which honestly looks better then most Triple AAA games to come out), not because of the EYE CATCHING ART-STYLE that bleeds with passion and design. Best FPS roguelike i've played. Very fun movement mechanics (including grappling hooks and rocket jumping), fun build diversity for each class. Impactful weapons and items you pick up during the runs and the corruption zones add a very much-needed risk/reward aspect that was missing from EA.

Very solid gameplay and exploration elements run to run. Well thought out mechanics have you diving into the chaos to pick up health orbs, all while using the game's fluid movement mechanics to make yourself as difficult to hit as possible. All while trying to keep up the pace to quickly clear a level for time bonuses. 

My only real critique for the game is that the level up options feel a bit limited. There's a lot of fluff that's not particularly interesting. Overall I think I'd probably have preferred the game if almost all the 'universal' upgrades were cut out like +10% weapon damage or +15% fire rate or +10% elemental damage. The characters would feel a lot more distinct and interesting if there was a greater emphasis on their unique class upgrades, rather than the level up perks being so filled with a lot of boring 'small stat boost' perks that don't really feel like they change the way I play compared to modifying the way my abilities or kit works.

This game is a hash of various concepts that coalesce into something marvelous. The atmosphere is lighter than it's contemporaries, but the rhythm is as intense.

Each of the classes take a piece of the sandbox and amplifies its potential. There's a plethora of micro-objectives, most of which don't do much, but interspersed are small items and narrative devices that gets you trading boxer briefs for a hamburger.

I am told the action is Doom-like, I can't vouch, but I can imagine. The gun skill randomization feels like a faster more awesome version of Borderlands. The build decisions are more akin to the essence of rogue-likes, where you pick up these traits or upgrades to trait that make a build sing.

There's so much hidden and interesting content, I am really enjoying this.

You're a robot in a world full of bad robots. Grab your arsenal and blast all the bad robots in sight. Roboquest is what happens when DOOM, Borderlands, a comic book, and a booming soundtrack are combined as one. The end result is a spectacular fast-paced FPS rougelite. Roboquest may not be the first of its kind, but it is certainly one of the most polished.

Roboquest is a very strange experience, and I wish I could give it a "Mixed" score. It has some of the crispiest gunplay and movement you can find in a roguelite, but it feels terrible to actually play the game as a roguelite. Let me explain.

Many of the upgrades you can receive for each different class mid-run are incredibly shallow and basic. 
"Increase fire-rate by 15%"
"Increase *insert primary ability/secondary ability here* damage by 20%"
"Increase Elemental damage by 10%"
"Increase critical damage by 10%"

Some of them are more class-centric and allow you to do things like spawn an extra drone, gain reload and movement speed after your teleport, or gain an extra charge on your missile ability, but you never really feel the impact of them beyond niche situations. You also have no options to banish or remove certain upgrades, and it takes ages to unlock the base camp upgrades that give you a pitiful amount of reroll tokens (2). If you want more, you need to get them from passive items you pick up during the run. 

The actual meta-progression is laughably bad, as it's just increasing the likelihood that you'll have access to a shop or weapon "upgrade" station during certain points in your run. I sure do love grinding meta currency for hours just to buy an upgrade that only affects the CHANCE to spawn a shop. 

You also have upgrades that increase the rarity of the weapons that come out of chests during those same sections that the shops have a chance to spawn in, but they seemingly do fuck all because you'll have a maxed out base camp (the name for the main hub area where you purchase upgrades and select a class) and still have half of your initial starting weapon choices be the lowest possible tier. 

The rarity of the weapons is indicative of how many "affixes" the weapon has rolled on it, so a white weapon has no affixes, while each higher rarity gains an extra affix. Unfortunately, these affixes are just as boring as the level-up upgrades with such gripping options as:
"15% chance to shoot twice"
"20% more crit chance"
"Deals *insert elemental type here* damage"
"15% increased magazine size"
"25% chance for a bigger explosion"
and more!

Enemies will shit out guns of varying rarities, though even with the upgrade to increase the rarity drop it's VERY often just greens and blues, so you'll never find yourself getting excited. A majority of the time you just fly past it because there's almost nothing it could have rolled to make it worth swapping out for. 

The stages are all incredibly similar in layout and design until you get to some of the final levels, and you'll probably find yourself forgetting where you are if you don't pay close attention. The actual aesthetic of the game is great, but it doesn't feel like the art design for the stages ever really went beyond its initial stage. 

A lot of the moment-to-moment combat ends up feeling repetitive and same-y between runs, as even changing classes just doesn't do enough to help distinguish the actual gameplay from the others. It's not that there aren't any differences, as I would be lying if I said that. It's just that the differences aren't pronounced enough to really make it feel like you're playing a whole new class. Your approach to combat isn't likely to change much even when you're using different weapons and classes. 

Ultimately, I want to recommend Roboquest, but I just can't at the moment. You have better options for movement shooters. You have better options for roguelites. You have better options for co-op. It's the kind of game I find myself leaving play sessions feeling frustrated rather than happy. Roboquest is a game that I feel like I WANT to enjoy, but I can't seem to find that same spark and excitement that I get from similar titles. 

I never get the feeling of a god run, nor do I get the feeling that I'm getting shafted by RNG because everything you acquire during a run is so surface level in its functionality and presentation. It feels like a lot of the mechanics that are meant to encourage replayability and potential for unique and different runs just don't do enough or even exist at all.
