Roboquest is a game I've been looking forward to since early on in its development and its Early Access period, and it's a game I'd say delivers extremely well on its promises. With nearly 30 hours into the game, I have had an extremely good time and yet there's still more to do.

Now, Roboquest promises to deliver a lot of things, such as fast-paced movement, various builds (whether its weapons or upgrades), several classes, persistent upgrades (roguelite elements) and so much more.
[list]
[*][b]Fast-paced movement[/b] is something Roboquest delivers extremely well on, with several launch pads in every level, as well as [i]powerful[/i] launch pads in more predetermined spots. This alone already lets you build up quite a lot of movement speed, before you factor in upgrades that increase your movement speed, rocket-jumping, as well as other upgrades and buffs that I'll keep a mystery for you to figure out!

[*][b]Various builds[/b] are part of the core gameplay loop in Roboquest and alongside upgrades it makes every run feel different. The upgrade system works great too, it features both perks and upgrades, where you first pick a perk and then unlock upgrades for said perk or you can also just pick from perks that are generally available. As for weapons you have affixes that go between several rarities, as well as the chance of having an alternative fire with some examples being a rocket-jump, a barrier or a marking shot.

[*][b]Several classes[/b] are another major core piece of Roboquest and there's a different preference and playstyle to each class, although when starting you will most likely only have Guardian, but unlocking a few others should be an easy task. Instead of describing any of them, I'd recommend you to give each class a few tries, with different builds/perks and see how it feels, as one perk was part of what made me start to enjoy Commando a lot more and then I loosely built my preferences around that. 

[*][b]Persistent upgrades[/b] is the roguelite element in Roboquest and it mostly exists within your basecamp, where you have several tiers of permanent upgrades that unlocks the next tier after you've bought enough upgrades. You also have gadgets which will make a huge difference, both in terms of gameplay, as well as your sustainability, as these are unlocked progressively. Think of them as side-quests, some are unlocked through simple brief tasks, while others take a few runs to complete, but once you unlock them they will automatically be equipped (in the run, not after the run).
[/list]
Roboquest still has so much more to offer though - for example the co-op, but I have yet to try it so I can't speak on whether it's good or not unfortunately. One thing I can speak on however, is the soundtrack and out of everything in this whole game, despite how great it is, I have to admit that I still can't get enough of the soundtrack. It's the one, but also the [b]only[/b], time I went ahead and bought the soundtrack too, and they knocked it out of the park.

With all that being said, it's such a solid game that regardless of what you're looking for, I can almost guarantee you that as long as you enjoy a fast-paced roguelite shooter, Roboquest delivers and gives you such a great time, but also kicks your ass simultaneously.

I don't like rogulike games because of their unfair difficulty. I wanted to give Roboquest a shot because of the game's graphics. The art style is very nice, and I'm glad I gave this game a shot. It's definitely one of the best roguelike games I've ever played. The gameplay is fast-paced and addictive. The game is pretty fair when it comes to difficulty, and it lets you select the difficulty you want. There aren't any enemies that one-shot you or bottomless pits that cause you to game over. There are different classes, and each class has its own upgrades. The build variety is great, and it lets you experiement with different perks. There are side quests to complete, secret routes to discover, a basecamp that you can upgrade and gadgets to unlock. Roboquest is packed with lots of content that offers lots of playtime. Overall, Roboquest is a great game with eye-pleasing visuals. Even if you don't like the genre, make sure you try it. I'm sure you will like it.

FPS-rougelite what we deserved for. Movement and shooting feels nice (mostly like nu-DOOM but without their flaws), decent OST, various enemies. If you like FPS genre at least give it a chance, try out demo, and i bet you like it.

I figured this was going to be another Gunfire Reborn, but there is a surprising depth to this game that I didn't expect. I appreciate how many secrets there are to unlock and how the game allows you to discover them organically rather than prompting you and leading you to them.

One of the few games this year that had me taking notes on the side to make sure I caught everything. It's worth some time.

Roboquest has that slightly cellshaded aesthetics that made games like Borderlands popular a little while back. However, it leans a bit more into the cartoon aesthetics, with your guns have onomatopoeia sound effects in comic book text like "CLANK" and "BANG" when you reload or fire the weapon. 

Gameplay wise, all the classes feel great. Theres a lot of different perks to grab at random with their own subupgrades to pick from, so you have a lot of replayability even on the same class.

This game appears to draw a little inspiration from games like Risk of Rain, as you can spend currency to unlock items that boost the current run, albeit with said items being more powerful than in ROR since they do not stack.

The guns are pretty fun. Good mixture for anything your into, whether it's generic SMG or Assault rifles, massive explosive launchers, bows, snipers, whatever. Little bit of melee too as a treat.

Anyways, to conclude, pretty solid game. Amazing art style, solid movement, great guns, a ton of replayability. Worth full price, definitely grab on sale.

On the rogue lite scale of skill to luck, this leans more on the skill side of things. Weapons and upgrades are delivered based on RNG but getting undesirable drops doesn't screw the run. Each class adds flavor to the retro shooter game-play, the soundtrack is god tier, and every weapon is unique aesthetically and practically. The balance is excellent; I found every item, class, weapon, and upgrade to synergize in some way without anything feeling objectively terrible.

Surprisingly satisfying game loop with enough satisfying loadouts, secrets, and solid metaprogression to keep me engaged.

This game isn't very "rogue", the maps follow a somewhat similar structure, with the enemy variety and placement being the biggest changes (but also not always), however, the combat is so satisfying and the multiple classes and unlockables at your disposal are so fun and diverse it more than makes up for it. 

It's also important to note the slightly standard patterns of the maps are for good reason: The game has a huge focus on exploration and secrets. While it doesn't seem like it at first, there is actually a lot past the surface, and I personally found the experience of exploration to be very pleasing. 

There is a story, mostly found on secrets, but it's not the focus and isn't very memorable. 

Boss fights are something I value a lot and I believe most of them are very fun to fight. Sometimes I feel I got overtuned on later stages and thus made the bosses a bit too easy, but they are still very well designed and, should you be unlucky or play on a higher difficulty, you'll quickly notice how they are a true test of skill in using your arsenal on most cases. 

Because the "rogue" elements of the game are mostly tied to meta progression, it can get stale for some, but I personally enjoyed it so much that I went out of my way to do as many optional challenges, collecting and achievements as possible. The soundtrack is superb and playing the multiplayer feels nice and with a proper dose of challenge, it's not one of those games where multiplayer makes the gameplay trivial.

Your character, who is a bulky but adorable robot named a "Guardian", has a similar variety for its classes, Recon lets you have a more Doom Eternal approach, Engineer lets you be more passive with your gameplay, and Commando is focused purely on dealing the most damage in the shortest amount of time.
As of writing this review, it's still in Early Access, but I think it's still worth it, considering ULTRAKILL is as amazing for an Early Access game, and I do wish to see this game and ULTRAKILL have some sort of collaboration
This game has since left Early Access, the game is still worth every cent, even at full price

Are you missing the good old times when Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem and other fps games were popular?
Do you keep searching for games which can remind you of the good old Doom game or FPS in general?
Do you want to feel cool like the new kids who play Call of Duty or Fortnite?
Wanna see the action from John Wick's perspective? 

Then this game is just for you my friend. 

Roboquest is a game where you can feel like John Wick, explore like Lara Croft and keep trying like Rocky Balboa.
It shows you the old school + new school style of FPS games, which is "Run and Shoot".
Roboquest has different difficulties, but if you are veteran fps gamer or just trying to make your game challenging, then there is only one difficulty for you my friend ( Which is also recommended from the game itself) and that is "Hard" difficulty. 
Just like the game"Hades", you have hard start, learning the basic stuff, learning the weapons and learning the zones.
However, the more you play, the easier it can become for you, as you keep getting yourself upgrades.

"I still find this game hard though". Well sir, then i recommend you the" 2 players Co-Op" option. That's right - you can play with a friend, so you can reach the game's end.
Either playing alone or with a friend,  you will find that this game can be very satisfying for the challenges that it brings.

After many tries, i can gladly say that i finished the game with a smile on my face, knowing not only that i reached the end, but also the fact that i found this game.

Next on the list will be the game called "Ultrakill" and oh man, i am ready for it.

Short version - if you like tight FPS combat with great feeling guns, give this game a spin.

The soundtrack is amazing and the multiple paths/classes encourage exploration and replayability. My only real gripe is that they do that thing where you are rewarded for exploring, but you are also rewarded for going fast. It feels like you either have to dedicate a run to speedrunning OR exploring, not both.
This comes down to taste, but I also feel like unlocks matter A LOT, not just for flavor but for getting further in runs. The permanent upgrade tree is very important and while I guess it's POSSIBLE to blaze through the game on your first run, this isn't a game where skillful play is all you need. A lot of handy gadgets are locked away behind mini quests which I find fun and engaging, but it also means that you aren't free to express yourself fully as a player until at least 10 or so runs in - most quests take many runs to complete.

With that said, the game has one of the most potent "just one more run" feelings I've come across lately, the soundtrack contains exactly 0 duds and the gameplay is smooth as anything.

[The good]

complicated.
-  The levels look and feel vibrant, which is supported with a bit of lighthearted comedy.
-  story is acceptable. It's nothing special, but it does add a lot of life to the world and characters.

[The could improve]
-   A thing I miss a little bit is a victory run option. To be able to keep restarting with all the upgrades intact [without it helping with game progression]. I often end a run wishing I had 1 or 2 more levels. Not because the game is too easy, but because I am so close to a fun and ridiculous build I just want to try out.

-   The city maps can get a little confusing. Perhaps a marker on the mini-map showing spawn or the end goal [once found] would help me better understand my location

-   Basecamp seems to develop over time, but I don't know what tigers it or if there is any left to upgrade. [Maybe I just could not find the UI for it]

[The bad ish]
First view runs with the v1.0 reset were a little annoying as so many features essential to the game like vendors were locked behind upgrades, this made we want to rush through the start rather than take time to enjoy some initial runs.

[Summary]
As a game designer myself, I can see that every feature was put in with a clear goal and purpose which encourages variety while not enforcing it, allowing you to truly just play the game how you want.
This is the type of game you keep coming back too even when finished because of the smooth CCC and replayable nature of the mechanics.
Want an extremely fun and addicting FPS rogue-like? Get roboquest, your expectations will be wildly entertained

I don't understand why "developers" think they can put anything they want into a video game because it's a Roguelike.

I've seen many cases of this now and here's what happens. 
Most of the content, creativity, thinking, weaponry, time, money, everything that goes into "games like these" just shouldn't be in the game to start with because you have ONE FACTOR THAT RULES ALL and, ultimately, should be the only thing in your game because everyone knows you d*mn sure aren't going to take it out. Rule #1 to not being stupid, [i] You naturally get more value when you work with something that is better than what you had. [/i] Lots of developers can't see this and it's mind blowing. To think driving a car is faster than walking. Insane to think something that simple is so hard to comprehend.

This games biggest problem is movement speed increase buffs. The A.I. are clearly scripted to have their bullets and attacks be slow because of the player having set ground movement speed. There's perks you get mid-run and "mutations" to enable before the run that make you move faster. Also, there's a Jet-Pack class you can play that just lets you fly and a lot of A.I. can't even react correctly because you're in the air with best type of movement you can possibly have (also gains movement speed increase buffs). Out of Topic, Ark Survival Evolved has movement speeds buffs but in their "remastered" version they took movement speed buffs out because it ruined more than half the game.

Most of the guns are extremely trash or useless. There's roughly around 100 guns and literally 90 of them are just useless. Most of them are missing a lot of detail to make them feel like an actual gun or your level 1 weapon is "magically" somehow better than this level 7 weapon.

Some/most of the level design is very boring and not enjoyable. The first zone in the game is easily the most fun and best looking. The rest of the game, having it not change for over a year, is kind of disgusting. Bunch of empty, lonely areas and pretty poorly built for a game that is supposed to be designed for having "fight areas". You can get on top of a lot of buildings in the city and there's literally nothing up there and this is in almost (basically) every level of the game. A lot of core understanding of keeping the player busy is just not there (while the game is also giving you score for beating the level as fast as possible too [Yep. They want you to explore and beat it as fast as possible. I don't understand.]).

The most the game has for it is the movement, surprisingly. Crouch-Slide into Double Jump, shooting your gun mid-air back into Crouch-Slide, shooting your gun, repeat, is really fun and THE GAME IS BUILT FOR THAT... BUT when there's movement speed increase buffs and then you introduce "the" Jet-Pack class it gets rid of the whole point to play the game and the true difficulty it provides so people are unlocking end-game content by not even playing the game correctly and the hardest difficulties are developed/intended to be cheated by playing in this pathetic way because of the developers decision to put A.I. that shoot slow and the ability for the player to fly plus movement speed increase buffs together and that's the EXACT REASON why you shouldn't play it. It was heavily advertised so that's why it has more sales than it should have. Games that have flawed concepts should be free. It's not worth $1.

It's fast, it's colourful and it's a lot of fun.

If you're a fan of the mechanics and movement of Doom, the shooting like any arena shooter, the artstyle of Borderlands, and the roguelike elements of Enter the Gungeon, then you'll love this game.

The guns feel good to shoot, the movement and gameplay is smooth, and i have yet to experience any bugs. There are tons of levels with secrets scattered without, and a multitude of enemies/bosses. There is co-op in the game although it is only 2 player co-op, but it works well and each player gets their own loot. 

My only negative so far, is the map generation isn't too deep, so most runs do tend to run together a bit, though the gun variety still keeps it feeling different enough each time. Great game and i highly recommend, and i hope to see more updates in the future and what new content they decide to add.

Some minor things i dont like:
-you need a guide for the secret stuff, check the official roboquest discord it has one for all of the things, but its not very intuitive to find things and i would have not found 50% of the secrets without the internet.
-you sometimes have to take a bad upgrade to get cool and good upgrades later. Its kinda unintuitive and should probably just tell you that that upgrade unlocks more in the upgrade tree because for a while i missed out on cool things because i tool the obvious choice over "10% more melee damage"
-Some scrolls or whatever they are called need a bit of balance,  stuff like "15% more damage but will stun you and get you killed" is honestly just not worth in any scenario, even with the stun reduction.

But still a very good game that i can recommend and those are just minor nitpicks that i hope the devs fix.

Also make sure to EXIT out of the game normally, dont alt f4! the game saves your progress when you close, meaning should you crash or alt f4 you will lose this sessions progress.

I want to start this review off with: RyseUp has been fantastic to the community.
Ignoring how awesome this game is, I would recommend it just by virtue of their dev team being great and constantly looking out for the community. I'm leaving this review after they made an update following the 1.0 release.

Their 1.0 release completely reset your progress. You lose everything, and it wasn't optional. This was very frustrating to have to grind through all of the meta-progression again. I play this with my wife, and we both started to get away from playing the game because we felt robbed. We left feedback via the in-game option stating our disappointment with the direction the game took. Turns out the change to revert all your progress was received very poorly. It's barely been a week, and RyseUp released an update and apology for forcing it. It seems small, but it was a frustration shared by many. Knowing RyseUp listens to feedback is more than enough to get me to publish a positive review. As a customer, I feel respected and listened-to.

Oh also, there's a game here. It's awesome. Fast paced gun robots shoot stuff to good music. Buy it.

Very underappreciated game that is just really fun to play.
Gameplay is chaotic and very fast, with game encouraging for vertical movement as well. Art style is nothing special, yea, but it fits the game realy well.. Soundtrack is fantastic and goes perfectly fast combat. Guns are all fun to use, and game doesn't force RNG on you and making your "run ruined", because you didn't get "THE BEST GUN" as they all are viable because of game's stats system and unlimited ammo. 
I've seen it often compared to Gunfire Reborn, but these are nothing alike. Gunfire relies a lot on RNG and puts loot above actual player skill, and much slower. 
Overall I put this game above all of it's kind.

I have always loved Rogue-Like or Rogue-Lite games. Not only that, but I enjoy myself a fast paced FPS. This takes a lot of the aspects that I love out of those genre and puts them into a cell-shaded and beautiful world. Not only does it have a lot of the things that I love and can play to relax, but you can also run through the game with a buddy. Roboquest deserves a lot of praise for making something that is this polished and fun for a 1.0 release. I really look forward to seeing what else this game has in store. As of the time of writing this review, I have gotten majority of the the game complete with collectibles and achievements. I am surprised by the detail and effort it takes to obtain a lot of the upgrades or collectibles. Even then with each new item or perk gained, it feels like it changes the game pretty drastically. I'm ready to break the game some more with overpowered builds and continuous fun! I hope everybody who plays Roboquest enjoys the game as much as I do!

What a pleasure this was to play.  Punishing progression early on just like many rougelikes.  There are so many "????" moments in this game when you see an area you have no idea what it does or how to access it.  The game doesn't give you a lot of hints on how to do really anything but relies on your die hard FPS experience to get you there.  Investigating the verticality of areas to find hidden data logs was something I didn't expect to do but the desire to unlock additional areas keeps me starting up another round.  I like the fast-paced flow of the combat and the music makes everything feel awesome.  The anime-style onomatopoeia text for all the gun sounds is such a nifty little touch and adds to the overall fun of the FPS gameplay.  Highly recommend to those looking for a different FPS rougelike

This is an absolutely awesome Roguelite game. It has a very straightforward and very fun 100%, even though you might initially be intimidated by having to S Rank the hardest difficulty in the game, and possibly even do it again but in Co-op. But I promise you that it's not nearly as hard as you might think. #buddybot

Regardless of that, this sits right up there in some of the most legendary games in my top 10 list, up there with Borderlands 2 for example... simply from it's style both in gameplay and just graphically, it's not by any means some intense graphically demanding game, it just runs and looks immaculately smooth and that comic book style is incredibly desirable. 
The story isn't pushy or drawn out, it's simply animated and just all round perfect for the first time playthrough, that lets you then get on with future runs now that you've seen it.

The weapons are pretty well designed, even though they might not be mechanically viable, here's to you Splasher Rifle, but I found myself clicking with the Bandito Gun specifically and seeking that in most of my runs.

Between Noisecream's outstanding soundtrack work, the high octane gunplay, the fun you can have with class selection, and endearing art style, RoboQuest is a hell of a fun experience. The recent release and update has been long awaited for, coming from someone that started playing shortly after it's release on steam during it's Early Access Period.

Each class is viable, each gun is viable, RNG doesn't jab you too much, and the beat keeps you coming back with each run. I keep finding myself coming back to this game over and over again because it's addictingly fun to take on bots with different combinations of guns changing up the strategy each time, swapping my route each time. The bosses make for a good speed bump on speed runs. 

Overall, the beats and gameplay mix so well that it's criminal. I hope the devs do not stop working on this game as it can add more branches for levels, new classes, hell even a few more weapons would be nice. A solid 8/10.

After finally receiving the 1.0 update, it is clear as day that this game has so much love and care put into it. The developers have really outdone themselves with the attention to detail and response to the community. I recommend wholeheartedly Roboquest to anyone who is a fan of movement shooters, roguelikes, doomlikes or co-op games.

The game has now left early access and I feel confident in saying that it is absolutely one of the best indie games in my library. Gameplay is fun as hell, the music is great, the art style is great, and it feels rewarding to actually win a run.

Updating this as the full release is now out.

Having now played most of what Roboquest's full has to offer, beating the game twice and so on, I can say with full confidence that this is a game definitely worth looking at. The fun comic book artstyle, the excellent "gunfeel" and gameplay, the masterpiece of a soundtrack, it's all there. 

The game's really replayable with tons of stuff to collect such as weapon, enemy, and story logs, unlockables including crystals, classes, and the entire upgrade tree of the basecamp. 

In addition to unlocks and collectibles there are so many different perk builds to try with each of the classes. Want endless explosions on the commando, or would you rather play into the fury mechanics? Want your elementalist to throw all sorts of elemental attacks constantly, or focus on only one element and make it broken?

Hell, the game has a demo right there, install it and give it a whirl, see if you like it. If you do, definitely grab this gem!

Let's get that soundtrack of the year nomination!

Release update: 
This is it! They've tuned the difficulty, they've made it fun to find things, they've added new weapons! Dope, more recommended than ever!

Original review:
It's just so good. Even in its current early access form, every update provides me with hours of new content.

5 different classes (and counting!) with vastly different abilities that each come with a unique set of perks that allow you to create even more unique builds that focus on different things!
Weapon variety is huge and increasing in every major update, all are fun to use and perks change these up AGAIN.

Really just a straightforward, satisfying fast paced FPS roguelite with tons of of variety and replayability. Oh also it has co-op as if it wasn't perfect enough as it was???

A must have. Just get it now.

Fluid Game play
Hard Sound Track
Satisfying Gun play
Fast paced Action

Really great game

A really solid experience that you can jump into at a whim and find yourself staying for hours. 

A bumpin soundtrack by Noisecream and a really well put together art direction that can be a bit cluttered at times. 

Some weapons don't feel useful in many of the more difficult scenarios, such as the locked arena rooms.  The long range weapons being sub par since most of the game takes place at speed and close range is unfortunate since they do well elsewhere, but aren't as versatile. 

These things aside, the overall experience is very positive. 

I hope to see more from the Devs, what we have so far is more than worth the 20 bucks.

The game overall has good gameplay and good art. However, the difficulty scaling of the game increasing way too fast, the 2 area (3 level) of the game ramps up the difficulty from challenging but fun to unfair and dumb, you can be hit by 20 attacks in 2 seconds and 1 hit can take away 1/10 of your health. If they were to just adjust the difficulty ramp or give you some way to mitigate damage consistently the game would be way more enjoyable. Haven't been able to get past second area even with a friend.
Game is good, with competent developers, they just really need to work on balancing.

Very fun and fast-paced roguelite fps with cool comic-like art. So far each class have distinct skills and 'melee' which makes the gameplay quite unique from each other. However, the skill trees for each classes have quite similar upgrade to their skills such as "Use ability, fire rate goes up" which if I remember correctly, is available to all classes. Some of the upgrades are unique enough to me but it won't hurt to have more creativity would it? 
Other than that, the weapons feels good and each of them have interesting playstyle which will also change accordingly with their perks.  
The movement is also very fluid which I think makes up for the gameplay variety. 
Currently, I have two wins both of which I use legendary buddybots to carry me. I think that weapon is quite OP compared to the others as it made the runs all too easy for me whereas when I don't use it I struggle to win a run. Hope more balancing can be done. Overall, it's a very good game.

roboquest is an arena shooter rouge like game that plays a little like borderlands with better movement... if you aren't interested just by that line alone you either have a problem or you touch grass and i hope it's the latter.

  so for the people who touch grass here is my review:

Movement:  
 the game has great movement simple at first but as you play the game it begins to become more complex basically growing with you as you play the game. it goes from jump, slide, and run. to slide jumping, and rocket jumping. to a jet pack, a triple jump, and grapple hook... the first two sets are learnable no upgrades required to pull them off just learn the mechanics. the last set are upgrades you can get in a variety of fun ways (i will not say how as you really should find that out yourself by playing the game)

Guns:
  the gun play is also fantastic, it's a quick and twitchy mess in all the best ways possible. the guns range from shotguns to sniper rifles to a shovel and god damn laser guns! that's not even half the list... need less to say if you like a certain type of weapon it's in the game somewhere, and all the weapons in the game feel unique giving the game a lot of replay-ability.

Classes/Builds
  the classes are awesome as well with each of the six having entirely different play-styles, as well as each having different ways to play each class. this combined with the guns, and the item upgrades, and the level up perks leads to a massive array of ways to play the game. aggressive, defensive, long range, close range, you name it it's possible. the only constant is movement, you have to be on the move constantly or you will die. 

 Other stuff:
   that's not even mentioning the music or the art style of the game which are both just as premium as the game itself. the only issue i have with the game is that it's not longer i would love more areas to go to, but that could come as a DLC or a free update you never know. honestly though i would be fine even if that never came to pass. i mean i have put in about 30 or 40 hours when the game released not to mention the 60+ hours in early access. i got my moneys worth and then some! 



                                                                                      10/10
                                                                            would quest again

Remember when games were supposed to be fun? Roboquest brought me back to those simple, whimsical times when you would get completely engrossed in a game, when your muscle memory would take over during the intense gameplay and you have fun in one of its purest forms. Roboquest is just that: FUN. Incredibly fun. Something to enjoy, to savor, to appreciate.

The graphic style is super stylish with a comic book aesthetic (it even has little cute onomatopoeias for everything you do), the music is energetic and exciting and the gameplay... Oh boy the gameplay. It is simply just too good. It's fun, it's fast, it's addictive. I was playing Roboquest since early access and the devs really took their time to cook and deliver with this 1.0 update: everything clicks into place. All weapons have a niche, all items have a use, all clases have multiple builds that feel strong and fun, all the exploration you can do has a reward, all mechanics serve a purpose.
If you haven't played Roboquest yet then do yourself a favor and get into it, it's simply FANTASTIC. I really hope this game gets more attention and the devs release more updates, more content. just more of this, please.

Roboquest is the absolute pinnacle of rouguelites and level-based shooters of both solo and co-op varieties. Constantly evolving gameplay has you coming back again and again. Unlockable upgrades guarantee your early runs evolve naturally with your skill. Combat, movement and weapon choice is deliberate yet constantly thrilling. And best of all, the game is fresh out of 1.0 with plenty of places to go with updates. I suspect coming back after every fresh content drop will be a refreshing and exciting experience. For 15 bucks, it's an absolute steal.

Roboquest is a pretty solid roguelike FPS. There's really smooth movement and shooting, a lot of fun secrets to discover, great music that doesn't wear out its welcome, and most importantly replayability. At the time of this review the game had just recently released out of early access. There's some great content there for the price, though I wish there were more variations of routes to take or other classes/perks/starting areas. But when the chief complaint is that one wishes there were MORE of a game, that's a pretty great game.

This game is a perfect blend of rougelite, arena shooter, with quirky and fun art style.
First thing that struck me was the music, it's easily a 9/10 when it comes to game OSTs and I'm obsessed.
It's really easy to pick up and put down and almost any time.
There are some obvious notes taken from Gunfire Reborn, but in my opinion it executes almost all of them better (minus character diversity, it could be expanded later for sure.)
The guns are a blast and all feel very unique but still strangely viable. 
The art style and cutscenes are phenomenal but I understand if the art style isn't your cup of tea. The game is still VERY enjoyable even if you skip them all. 
There are a ton of secrets to find, hidden rooms, hidden NPC's, weird quirks and just fun activities that you can make as mini-goals during your runs.
The Co-op while only 2 player (I wish it was 4) is seamless and works incredibly well. 
You can't just instantly carry a friend to places they don't have access to, but you can guide them on getting they keys/unlockables to get there. 

TL:DR if you like Gunfire, Doom, and Borderlands, chances are you'll like this. 
Easily 9/10 for me.

The only cons so far is that you kinda get penalise for taking your time. But if you kill more, u get rewarded as well.

Not so much for people who wants to take it slow like gunfire reborn.

Highly recommend to try the demo first. You get to keep your progress!

Overall, I'm enjoying the game and would highly recommend.

I've been playing this game since early access, and I have to say it's only gotten better with each update. The movement and gunplay are fluid and responsive, you really feel the mobility in this game with the slide-jump momentum and the grindrail speed, and every gun feels amazing to use and has very good potential with each run. The builds for each class have a lot of variety and can get WACKY. One run you might have an immortal hammer lord and the next you might be spewing so many rockets you look like the US military, or an extremely mobile shotgun hitman with a laser knife. And MY GOD THE SOUNDTRACK. This OST is my favorite of all time, and has solidified Noisecream as my favorite music creator. Each track is a banger and feels great to play with. GET THIS GAME.

From humble beginnings with very strange itemization and low-impact boring perks, but a solid movement system and tight gunplay with a lot of soul. Bought it a while ago before 1.0 released and was so thoroughly impressed by it. Completed the base camp, completed the game on the hardest available difficulties, and put it down.

Then, 1.0 released. 1.0 is the perfect distillation of everything that made the game great in early access. The movement is fast and frantic, the guns all feel excellent (even if they do not appear to be so on first blush), the playable character variety is amazing (in EA i would play pretty much just Commando cuz you know, rocket) and each one has their own individual playstyle and upgrade trees. I haven't even mentioned how some gadgets completely change the way you play. 
The more you are willing to explore the map, the more you are rewarded, both in terms of collectibles [initially] and upgrades. 

Overall, quite frankly, it's like the devs were reading my mind with this game. My criteria nowadays for whether or not I will play your game is if I can sprint into a slide and jump. In this game, I don't even have to sprint to slide. Movement is hugely important to me in video games, and on the basis of how good the movement in this game is alone I wholeheartedly recommend (ESPECIALLY if I include the gadgets). There are so many weapons that there are some I don't see for multiple runs at a time, and I kinda really like that; I'm the type to do the same thing over and over again because I like how it feels, so being forced out of my comfort zone into using something new is always fun.

After just a short introduction to the game, I can already tell I'm going to enjoy Roboquest a lot.

I'm also looking forward to unlocking the other 3 classes, as they all have different traits for me to try out. Acquiring a new weapon or upgrading one with great affixes on it feels meaningful. The AI is very good at tracking you so you need to keep moving. The soundtrack is awesome, very upbeat.

Roboquest is a fast FPS roguelite except you actually need skill instead of dumb luck.
The game is hard, but it rewards accuracy and moving around like a madman.

The things it does well :
- Movements are smooth and you have a lot of tools to move around
- No "you one hit enemies and they one hit you" bullsh*t
- A horde game with bullet hell elements where the ennemies slowly drain your health instead of killing you in one hit
- A LOT of weapons and almost all of them are good. On top of that, you are encouraged to swap weapons often
- No ammo reserve, you can reload as often as you want
- POCKET RELOAD (you have 2 weapon slots and the weapon you aren't using is slowly reloading itself)
- No dumb experience orbs to collect around
- You are punished for not paying attention to the enemies or for not dealing with certain enemies in priority
- Lots of funny builds to play with

The bad stuff :
- The meta upgrades are a bit too strong, or rather, it feels like they nerfed a lot of things just so you can unlock meta upgrades to boost these things back to normal. 
- Some levels are unique, but some of them really feel identical.

The difficulty settings are good and bad at the same time :
Enemies get more health and deal more damage, but they're also more aggressive and some of them are replaced with more advanced enemies.

No comment on the story, I'm just not playing for the story.

One of the best action roguelikes I've played, up there with Enter the Gungeon and Hades. The gameplay feels incredible and the music is great, perfectly fitting the flow of the game. Each class feels fun and different, with each one having several different types of build available. Lots of unlocks and secret levels to help make every run feel fresh, and the meta-progression system works well to increase power (usually in the form of finding better weapons) and complexity over time without feeling like you have to grind until you get enough stats to win. Took about 10 hours to beat the final boss for the first time with still a lot unlocks and secrets to find, and the gameplay is strong enough alone to warrant more replayability even after unlocking everything. Overall 10/10, hoping for more content in the future.

FPS Roguelike isnt a unique genre, there's plenty of contenders, but Roboquest stands near the top. Its outstanding visual style, fantastic soundtrack, robust movement system and slew of interesting weapons and skill to cause carnage are all things that make it stand out from the crowd.

Its not the best FPS roguelike out there at the moment. Right now that award goes to Gunfire, but its a close thing. Both are similar experiences, but they come to the action from different ends. For the most part Gunfire encourages cautious play where every minor wound can stack to leave you near deaths door. Roboquest however encourages and in fact revels in a reckless rush to the finish of a level, swapping weapons frequently and taking hits knowing healing comes from every defeated enemy. Its a manic, and highly cathartic experience and a blast to play co-op.

Probably one of the best FPS roguelite there is, just pure fun.

[h2]DOOM? Borderlands? Do these names ring a bell to you? [/h2]
[b]A loot-shooter with roguelike elements, emphasizing precise movement.[/b] The lowered crosshair is simply overpowered; the developers brilliantly and simply solved the problem with flying enemies ‚Äì applause! The weapons are interesting: with projectiles, beams, additional attacks, throwable, melee; abilities, elemental damage ‚Äì all of this provides limitless potential for replays. The developers also went the extra mile and added small secrets where you're allowed to "step out" of the map, find journals, or discover hidden levels. Highly recommended to play only on the highest difficulty. Definitely worth the purchase ‚Äì 10/10!

Good roguelite shooter, pretty much on par with Gunfire Reborn and Risk of Rain 2. Just wish you could play with more than 2 in co-op.

Lot of build variety. You can go elemental, crit, melee, etc. Wish there was more defense/support options though as health is a rarity in this game and some rooms are a bullet hell. Maybe just a damage cooldown, like once you take damage you can be damaged for 0.5 seconds. Just enough to prevent insta-death.

Huge variety of guns, perks, and level ups that make every run different. Various paths that make every run feel a bit different but gives you full control of where you go. Interesting boss fights too. 

Fun hunting for secrets and upgrading your base. Base progression is really slow though, a full run gets you 1-2 upgrades out of a few dozen. Takes maybe 10 runs before you can reasonably select Hard difficulty.

Roboquest is one of the best FPS roguelites to release somewhat recently. While the genre is somewhat niche and has rare releases, Roboquest is absolutely a hit. The game is not infinite and does not have multiple modes, which is somewhat unfortunate, but it does have branching pathways to the end, all of which are fun and have some secret levels. There are a wide variety of weapons available for you to use, and an extremely wide variety of perks for each of the classes to allow for each run to feel unique and different from every other. I am very excited for the future of Roboquest, and I hope to see many content updates in the future bringing new modes, or paths, or weapons, or classes

This is an amazing game I would recommend to anyone. It feels super polished, has Doom esque fast paced movement action, and a nice variety of classes, perks, and weapons. The cell shading style makes me feel like i'm playing some old favorites like Borderlands, but with fun replacing the gear grind. 
If you like roguelites, do yourself a favor and pick this one up, you won't be dissapointed!

A well polished shooter with responsive movement, a lot of weapons, fair amount of replayability, great soundtrack, and plenty of secrets to find. This game is nothing but action and can even feel like a first person bullet hell at times, especially on harder difficulties. There's also an insane amount of perks and items to choose from progressing through each stage. I definitely recommend picking this up even at full price.

if you just want to complete the main quest and unlock items go ahead, the game excels in style, exploration and finding the secrets is fun, the game is enjoyable and you can unlock everything from the main 4 difficulties that will be around 20-30 hours of game.

now if you are looking forward to the whole game and all steam achievements i cannot recommend.
starting with the difficulties easy is where is most of the fun is, being able to do what you want, there is such a massive gap between easy and standard that hard doesnt even feel different than standard, everything above hard just increases enemy hp and damage feeling very frustrating and not enjoyable, much more when you consider the time limit for rank and enemies becoming bullet sponges.

the game feels fast but when you have to dodge the most shots as possible you will realize you have the mobility of a cannonball, fast but heavy and not really meant to dodge, the weight just makes it slow to change direction feeling uncomfortable.

rogues get replayability from experimenting with builds but we dont have it here, there is some stuff that make a noticeable difference but it never feels consistent, never feels the same, the same weapon that just easily cleared the room could struggle in the next run, sometimes even in the next room.
i should be able to know what makes it better or worse after S ranking the highest difficulty but i dont have the slightest clue, between bot level, bot upgrades, items, weapon level, weapon rarity, weapon affix there are too many little things making the run inconsistent and not really have a build you can think and want to make, just hoping the enemy dies when you shoot them before something shoots you outside your view.

Though short at the moment the bones of an amazingly fun rogue-like that has smooth movement and an entertaining mix of weapons and abilities.

UPDATE: Still a great game, not nearly as short as it was originally. Love the new class and areas.

Update for release: Great game, I like how diverse the unlocks are for Gadgets, Crystals, and some of the classes. I hope there will be more classes and gadgets coming down the line just to expand options.

All'n'all its a great game, recomend to those who liked Gunfire Reborn, Borderlands, etc.

Rougelikes are probably my favourite genre of games and Roboquest definitely does it right. Unlockable characters, multiple paths to the final level, fast and fun combat system that's easy to pickup and hard to learn, multiple different build options for each class in terms of abilities and then a whole slew of gun options to choose from. Not to mention the secrets and collectables. if you enjoy collecting stuff this game is definitely for you, collect cards for all enemies, bosses and weapons, find new secrets and data logs throughout the game. Honestly 10/10. The only thing that would change my opinion would be if the devs did not give it a proper post release. One of my favourite roguelikes is Hades but with no post launch content updates i didn't see much reason to return back once i had beaten the game. All i ask if for some new characters, guns and maybe a new level or two, obviously easier said than done. Overall great game.

after multiple playthroughs, one almost an entire run with just the shovel and buddy bot surprisingly making it pretty far on normal, there still is alot of charm, the unlocks over time do get better, though i feel the skill tree feels like you dont unlock as much as youd think a whole tree slot would. the classes feel abit better balanced than before, and some of the old op weapons def feel more balanced now. there is some fun paths to unlock, especially using certain items to unlock extra areas. some weapons def feel out of place slightly still, but you can just ignore them most times.

i still really really hate the hack bot enemies, please remove them or nerf them.


old negative 1.0 review:
full release is pretty disappointing in places, it had alot of promise, and charm, and the devs seemed to actively listen to their fans, but with this idk man, like as a game its ok, the mechanics are fine enough, but it just doesn't mix well with how they changed the rouge-like elements. the really awful enemies that make you press inputs to escape are still the worst enemy ive ever seen for a game where your long run can be ended in a few hits. that thing needs to be dumped in the trash. the music can either be a bop, or its super grading, the first few areas i have my headset  on full to get pumped to it, mission 3 i think it is i mute the game cause the track sucks, its just loud repetitive noise trying to be "we got roller mobster at home".
guns feel overall weaker, animations feels mismatched as some have a floaty borderlands janky feel (which i think is perfectly fine) and then others have this weighty mw19 almost attempt to them (which mind you, i also think is fine), and you can tell what guns were added when. they just dont feel like they belong together though. builds being changed around and class items getting changed/scrapped is abit rough, havent really enjoyed what has been done, granted some things i do like.
the hub feels super last minute slapped together, i think there were some EA versions i liked better. its not even like the place builds with you anymore (at least that i noticed)
theres some stinky frame rate issues in the final area that bumped me from a super solid 60, down to 40 for no reason, unless you animated the entire planet, then ive no idea why its so tanky there.






old early access review:

I really enjoy this game, its been a treat seeing it evolve over time,  the game play is pretty solid
A mix of roguelike mixed with borderlands 2 is a good combination.

Solid fun FPS game for a quite low price. Despite the negatives listed below, the game is still very fun. 
The museum/card system gives you a reason to try out the various weapons and items, the shooting feels good, most weapons are unique and fun to play with, enemies have enough variety in attacks to keep me engaged in dodging etc. I'm just someone who tends to focus a lot on the negatives, and in this game the negatives mainly pertain to the "roguelite" element. As a PvE FPS, it is still very good.

The negatives (in my eyes) are:
1) Co-op has some bugs - most common one is occasionally an enemy will not display its HP to the non-host player, and the final boss sometimes glitches and is stuck in the ground during Phase 2, only to suddenly pop-up mid animation when it attacks. This also means that there's an attack it can do (the one where it spins 3 lasers rapidly around the arena) that lasts a long time but during which the non-host player cannot damage it, as it sinks under the map on their screen.

2) Endgame is distinctly lacking. If I hadn't committed to collecting all achievements (specifically the one for beating Guardian 4 w/ S rank) I would have no reason to play after beating Guardian 1. Wrenches in particular are pointless after buying out the workshop, and the one place to spend them post-workshop only requires 30 per run if you even want the achievement for clearing the Museum, which is easily obtained if playing on Hard or higher.

3) A lot of items are bad. I ignore the majority at this point and only look for certain ones. A few have seemingly unnecessary downsides that make me never want to use them as the positive is far outweighed by the negative, even if it's chance-based. Also, despite the game only giving you maybe 12 or so items per run, each item's effect is generally so miniscule that I barely notice it. More often than not, I only remember I have certain items on when the downside hits, like reducing my fire rate w/ a junk beam equipped makes it spam noise as if I'm clicking repeatedly instead of holding it down, or suddenly getting frozen because of a chance based downside.

If you've played Risk of Rain, Gunfire Reborn, or Deadlink and liked them, this game is for you. It strikes a unique balance between relying on good gunplay, engaging upgrading, and interesting metaprogression that make each run unique. Even after beating the game on the hardest difficulty on all characters I still find new viable and exciting builds every run. Additionally, the game is FULL of secrets, new paths to take, and new items/characters to discover. Expect each run to affect the next as you unlock new paths and get hints at things you might have passed earlier on each attempt. I really can't stress enough how there really is something hidden no matter where you turn. The comic book art style is also really cool-it is clear the team chose an idea and stuck with it, and it works perfectly. The movement is great, the guns feel awesome, and runs always feel fresh. I've watched this game grow since the first open beta, and I'm super happy with how it turned out. You can really see how much love the crew put into the game and I can't wait for potential expansions/DLC/whatever RyseUp does next. TLDR: 100% worth buying if you like rougelikes
this is the best fps of the year its 1. amazing looking 2. its carter robots and outdoors looks and fells great so yes i think you should buy this game and have fun.

The biggest selling point for me was the movement. Fast paced bullet-hell dodging, environmental parkour, and good verticality of terrain and combat. The demo provides a good feel of the starting movement options which gets expanded upon by unlockable upgrades later on. Gunplay feels consistent and responsive which compliments the speedy strafing and aerial maneuvers nicely.

I have a few complaints particularly with the amount of content. There's decent weapon variety but most of them fall into the same 5 or so archetypes and feel very samey. The game could use more areas and bosses which will hopefully come in future updates or DLC. I unlocked and beat the highest difficulty with full S-rank within roughly 20 in-game hours so I would like to see higher ascending difficulties personally.

Overall, I highly recommend Roboquest for the smooth and satisfying gameplay above all else. I find that the build variety and roguelite meta-progression are a bit lacking but the combat alone could easily keep me playing for hundreds of hours.

TLDR, It was way better back in early access (Which is where 40 of my hours are coming from), pre-elite-enemy update (which is where they made everything tankier and annoying to deal with).

The main loop will see you taking punishing damage from waves upon waves of bullets as everything fires all the time and the hp orbs drop directly below the enemy you killed, last for like 5 seconds, and then dissappear, which would make you think you need to play close-range constantly, but that's how you take even more damage, so, I don't know. This was a problem in early access too and clearly did not get resolved in 1.0. At least XP orbs that function the same way don't exist anymore, but the extra powercores do, so, get ready to feel like you're always playing wrong even though you're not.

You now HAVE to grind wrenches pretty hard, as an entire 1.0 hour-and-a-half run will only net you 55 wrenches (2 upgrade's worth) and everything "run" (the rougelike bits) is locked in said grind... which is not fun to do when everything is now a twitchy, dodging bullet sponge that shoots aoes at you in constant swarms. It used to not be like that, but I guess the dev was displeased by people enjoying the game and running it on Heroes +2 for fun before the elite update happened and now we're all suffering for it... for some reason.

Gadgets got absolutely hemmoraged horribly for 1.0 . They're now locked behind random quests, and those quests are hidden away or are just obnoxious, with pieces placed behind other pieces, doors, and requirements, and I just wish they were all set back to being one-time-purchased, really. You'll probably be stuck with 3 or 4 gadgets that do nothing for your playstyle and wonder where the other 6 are.

The... I guess I'll call them Roguelike Pickups as they don't have a specific name, they're the upgrade chips with images of random, unrelated items on them, are now pretty bland or dumb as opposed to interesting or useful, AND if you don't have all the meta, they're a powercell sink that's not a good idea to invest in.

Weapons got weird names that no longer tell you what they are, so a lot of the time you'll probably pick up guns you don't need just to find out what they are and how they work, but not use them because they feel weak, hit nothing, don't have fast enough projectiles, or just don't fit your style of play, which is a shame when there's so many weapons, but with the aforementioned twitchy bullet hell of the enemies in 1.0.... Yyyeah there was gonna be no other fate for a lot of the weapons due to that.

The same could be said of a lot of the perks that made it to 1.0, they're just kinda... Obsolete or required. Obsolete ones do pretty much nothing or are gimmicky (hitting bots with melee for more orbs even though doing that will get you hit for more damage, weapon gets a random element every 4 seconds, which can actually hurt your dps with the resistant enemies, and does not boost elemental damage), and necessary ones are your usual, generic, damage up, fire rate up, reload up, etc.

Classes are... No. Just play Guardian, the game's a bullet hell now and you'll wish you were playing them for the invuln bubble so you can actually live longer and do more damage, which is funny if you were here for Early Access, where it was fun and technically better to play anyone BUT Guardian.

The final area and boss are just a headache. The concept of the crystals would be neat if they weren't tucked away in random areas with random challenges that are the worst things in the game, that also add the worst enemies to normal runs for... Not that much benefit, honestly. All they do is augment the final two arenas and, if I remember right, a tiny portion of one phase of IRIS's health, while she has 2 phases that are full bullet hells that I absolutely loathe. Judge Ball was bad enough, but then the devs took their concept, replaced some attacks, then said "yay final boss done!" ... Is it any wonder that it's the worst part of the game when preceeded by two horrid arenas...

In the end, I'm just dissappointed. It WAS fine, but the chaotic nature of these devs seems to have won out for 1.0, lots of the changes from EA just before elites were added to Elites being added to 1.0 just made the game worse, not better. 2/10.

[h1]An amazing FPS, only an ok roguelite[/h1]


The best thing about Roboquest is its pure FPS gameplay. It's brutally simple but fun- Passive pocket reloading is very powerful to encourage constant weapon swaps, all enemies drop healing orbs so you're encouraged to get up close, headstomping enemies deals big damage and lets you carry on fluid momentum, and a ranking system that encourages you to clear out levels quickly, and it all feels gorgeous. As a plus, I also really like the presentation, the PG-rated Borderlands schtick actually becomes very endearing and I love Noisecream's work on the OST.

So, if you want a great FPS action game, you don't need to read the rest of this review, just buy this game, it's a hidden gem. If you're a roguelite fan, you will probably buy this game anyway, but you would benefit from reading the rest of this review.


I do think Roboquest is dragged down [b]slightly[/b] by its implementation of roguelite mechanics. An extra element like it was necessary as the FPS gameplay loop was probably too simplistic to make a particularly big game out of it, but as a big fan of both FPS and roguelites/likes I will say the former itch was much better scratched by this game than the latter.


Roboquest leans towards unlocks being [b]upgrades,[/b] lots and lots of upgrades. It's not as bad as Rogue Legacy, but it does get to the point where you start to think winning won't be realistically possible until you get X or Y upgrade and begin to perform runs not on the earnest hope this will be the one, but more just to reach so and so upgrade. In particular, I feel like the [spoiler]Jetpack[/spoiler] should've been a Class specific mechanic rather than a permanent upgrade applied to everyone, as it makes other upgrades and mechanics feel redundant unless you go out of your way to turn it off.

I acknowledge that this being a negative is mostly personal preference. Roughly judging based on sales, it appears most people prefer the assurance of permanent power unlocks in roguelites to keep them motivated.

In terms of keeping runs varied, I think Roboquest does an okay, but not great job. It has different characters (Classes) which change the properties of your melee attack (sometimes to become an extra gun instead of a melee attack!) and your cooldown-limited special ability. The Classes also have several unique upgrade lines with related sub-upgrades, like how the assassin can either turn into a melee god or focus on upgrading the properties of their teleport. Tying so much of run uniqueness to Classes though does feel like it limits run variation a bit though as your runs will be mostly defined by which of these Class upgrades you pick, not much else. Unlike say, Hades, which has a similar Weapons system and their unique Hammer upgrades, but also has an extra layer with the God upgrades and their focuses mostly defining runs.

Roboquest does have alternate level routes; The first level splits off into 3 different options, those options narrow to two level variations to act as the midgame, then the game narrows to a linear set of 3 levels for endgame, with secret levels dotted around all those. However Roboquest does not have an optional superboss or etc, and this level routing mostly exists to hide secrets as opposed to strategising in your run, so I think it might get a bit stale over time.

The guns system will be hit or miss for some people. Personally, I like the weapons/affix system as it essentially serves as a soft way to encourage you to use different guns on different runs- You can invest currency into upgrading whatever gun you want, but searching for god rolls and going with whatever gun gets lucky is overall best, encouraging using different guns every run. I could however see some people being disappointed gun effects don't get quite as crazy as they perhaps could, most affixes are pretty tame.


Roboquest is absolutely worth it as is, but doesn't quite hit the "one more run" addiction the best kind of roguelites do. However, it's mostly a matter of small changes that could alter this, so I am [b]very[/b] excited to see what updates or even expansions this game could get- One really good DLC expansion could change this from an 8/10 hidden gem to a genuine competitor as one of the best roguelites of all time.

Clearly, the devs have poured lots of love and effort into this game. However, I don‚Äôt enjoy this game. The reason is simple: I have played something that is better.

Firstly, the classes in Roboquest feel samey in terms of how they move and how they engage enemies. Class abilities do exist, but they fail to differentiate classes to a meaningful degree. 

Secondly, the weapons in Roboquest feel samey. There are more than 70 weapons in this game. I would argue that they are just unimaginative derivatives of around 10 archetypes. The affix system does not feel impactful either. 

Thirdly, the maps in Roboquest feel‚Ä¶. , yes, you guessed it, samey. The ‚Äúrandomly generated maps‚Äù are passable at most. The bigger failure is that the biomes (ruins, energy center, etc.) do not have enough characteristics of their own. They all follow the ‚Äúsmall corridors and big rooms‚Äù formula and the rooms are not that different. 

If you enjoy this game, great. I am glad you do. But if you are like me, I would make a recommendation: Deadlink. Deadlink is a FPS with roguelite elements. While it does not have as many weapons or ‚Äúrandomly generated maps‚Äù as in Roboquest, it has a surprisingly huge amount of replayability. Each class, each weapon, and each biome plays and feels differently. The degree of polishing of Deadlink is astonishing. Without knowing it, I have spent 100 hours on it and beaten it on the highest difficulty (only 1% of players achieved it). But I still want to play it more and master all the classes. With all my heart, I recommend Deadlink if you are a fan of FPS roguelite.
Addicting.

One of the better roguelites and thus I can warmly recommend it. Though it can get pretty bullet helly, so if you're not into that type of thing, you might wanna pass on this game.

Positives:
-No real performance issues. And that's nice nowadays, since I have a 1060 and find myself saying that less and less.
-Fast and fun combat. You can snipe around corners, weave through combat with melee, shoot explosives down from above(thanks to the verticality of most rooms) or stand your ground and mow down enemies with heavy weapons fire.
-Continuing from that previous point, there's a decent amount of weapon variety too, from hard hitting sniper rifles to dual wielded uzis and summonable weapons like turrets.
-Collecting and comboing perks and items together is my favorite feature in roguelites and I can say that they managed to nail that in this game. For example things like +critical chance become way more interesting when you get a perk that makes your critical hits ricochet to nearby enemies.
-Music is both great and varied. There's a calmer version of the area songs playing in the rest areas and, once you leave those to fight, the music picks up with great hyping effect. I think every area and boss has their own songs and I often found myself bopping my head to the beat.
-Looking for secrets felt fun. And no more on that since they are secrets~
-Levels are visually pleasing and feel somewhat different from each other. Also level design wise, in games like these, it's easy to place the player in a bunch of boring hallways, but the devs managed to improve on that a bit. They are still hallways, but with cover and verticality. Plus mobility increasing mechanics like grind rails and boost pads.

Negatives:
-The way the enemy projectiles look made it so that it's hard to perceive how far they are, and I often didn't notice lone bullets before they hit me. This weirdly made it so that many times I took more damage in the easy first level than in the later levels where I was dodging entire projectile swarms at a time. 
-Picking up data entries automatically opens them on top of your minimap. You can quickly close it, but that kind of thing just seems like a completely unnecessary feature in a fast paced action game like this.
-Slight balance issues. I had some trouble beating the game on hard, until I realized that stacking percentage damage perks and items makes everything melt to slag. Most of the items and perks feel useful, but some things like "Explosions have 20% chance to have a bigger radius or 15% to have a smaller radius" just feel genuinely useless compared to simple things like "Increases all damage by 10% against x". 
Also spending power cells on buying weapons felt wasteful, since you'd have to either spend more power cells to upgrade it's level or swap out to a higher level one later. Saving those cells to buy permanent upgrades instead felt way more useful.

Mehs:
-The game's not terribly long. I had all of the basecamp upgrades purchased before 15 hours. And at 20 hours I'm at the point that the only "major" content left is to try and beat runs faster or with higher difficulties, which don't appeal to me. There are some "minor" things, like getting all the collectibles or using every gun long enough to unlock their data entries, but those kinds of things are fun only if there are "major" things to do them alongside with.
-Basecamp feels kinda lifeless and boring. I understand that the game shows in cutscenes that there's only you and Max traveling together, but oddly enough your base of operations with it's unoccupied booths is more empty than the rest areas inbetween combat zones filled with npc robots. It could pretty easily made more interesting. Like the music in the camp for example. It only plays near the van. Everywhere else is dead quiet. You could build towards making the camp more like the rest of the game's music with having more energetic music near the van hyping you to start a mission and calmer music further away. Or even simply having the music play everywhere.
-In levels there are these small jump puzzle rooms. A large majority of them are super easy and some can annoyingly damage you. Their rewards are mostly very minor too. And later on with some gadgets you can just skip the vast majority of the puzzles straight to the reward. Could have been way better than the "I don't really care for them too much, but I guess I'll go grab the tiny reward"-type of deal that they are.
The ost is like crack but for your ears.

Roboquest is one of the most fun games I have ever played. It is almost hardly a contest. In raw, pure fun, Roboquest is certainly one of the best games ever made at least within its genre. 

Roboquest is oft compared to Gunfire Reborn, mostly for its similarity in format and for the fact that Gunfire Reborn is probably the second best thing in its genre. Seriously, I should stress at the top here, even if you play Roboquest you should also play Gunfire Reborn; if you like one, you'll probably like the other, if not the same amount. You play one of a few classes who gets significant upgrades a couple of times a level through weapons you can find and carry two of at a time, passive items, and perks. You're dropped into a safe zone to prepare, progress through levels full of bad guys with intermittent safe zones, and try to kill everything as fast as possible. 

In raw content, Gunfire Reborn beats Roboquest pretty handily--it has a fairly vast selection of scrolls and weapons, but Roboquest is no slack either. It has a pretty good range of weapons and items, but you will start to see the same ones pretty often. Where Roboquest excels is in its class design; every class is unique, fun and offers a different angle on how to play the game, with a big range of class-specific perks on top of the generic ones to make for a lot of build variety even with the smaller number of classes. In Gunfire it often feels like you're just pumping stats into specific things, but Roboquest gives you super varied and interesting upgrades that feel more significant and really make your build feel like it's evolving significantly throughout the run rather than merely keeping up with scaling. 

Roboquest has much more satisfying combat overall. Enemies are more fun to kill, and it's much more frenetic and fast paced. The game encourages you to be aggressive by making a significant source of recovery during fights, healing cells, drop from enemies in the depths of combat, forcing you to go hard if you want to be able to recover much health. It also encourages it through super fun movement mechanics, including jetpacks, grappling hooks and rail grinding, which add a lot to the game. 

It starts out as a healthy challenge and gets pretty brutal at the highest difficulties if you focus on the time challenge aspect, as you have to be very aggressive to meet S-rank requirements for the highest in-run rewards. You can't afford to spend too much time hiding and baiting out enemy AI.

Everything about Roboquest is just supremely fun. For the few minor complaints I have, I think an elemental combo system and just a couple more elements would be interesting, and I would like if Shock did something else as it's kind of redundant; Shock builds up on enemies and stuns them when it fills up, and Impact, which all non-elemental weapons also deal to some extent, does the same thing. I'd like to see more variety in the items, too, so hopefully the devs continue to pump new content into the game after its 1.0. 

Roboquest is great. Everyone who has any interest in roguelite FPSes should flock straight to this game.

Roboquest is an amazing FPS Roguelite which combines roguelike mechanics with gameplay straight out of DOOM, aesthetics from Borderlands and a hunger for more that only roguelikes can provide.

I originally bought the game back when it was still in early access, not expecting much from it. In less than 30 minutes, it had me hooked. I thought to myself "this game didn't have the right to be this good, wtf is going on?", the gameplay was fast and intense, with gunplay I had only experienced back when playing Doom Eternal, I was quickswitching guns, bouncing off enemies' heads and throwing fucking rockets at their faces all in the span of 3 seconds, it was epic and I loved it.

But then, the fuckers decided that it wasn't enough to make a good game, so they made it even better. Boom, complete rework of the weapon and item system, new class, new upgrades, new guns, new everything
AND THEN, they released 1.0, which made the game EVEN BETTER. They finished the story, added ANOTHER class, MORE guns, MORE items, and even MORE secrets for us to find. I mean, the amount of stuff that was added on release is ridiculous, the game is just so full of stuff it's hard to keep track of everything
I picked it up and played it for the good part of a week and I was hooked all over again, looking for every secret, exploring every part of every area, mastering each class (still working on that part), I even dabbled into some coop gameplay and I gotta say it was really fun

This is a simple game that connects a bunch of game concepts and puts them together into a mix that can only be described as fucking masterful. They did great at EVERYTHING. I mean, the guns even have "visual" sounds so when you shoot the gun goes BRRR or TATATATA and then you reload and it's like CLACK, CLICK which is SO MUCH LIKE BORDELANDS, they didn't need to put that in, but they still did, if that's not fucking dedication I don't know what is.

If you like FPS games, if you like roguelikes, if you just like a simply good game, get this bad boy. It's fun, it's addicting and it's gonna keep you interested for a while. Also, good luck to whoever tries the 100% for this one, I haven't even unlocked G4 and I'm already shitting myself, this is gonna be a tough one

10/10 (also if you guys could buff elementalist that would be pretty poggers)

[h1] 9/10 [/h1]
Takes the best parts of Doom Eternal's combat, carves off the unnecessary bits (glory kills, downtime between fights, etc.) while expertly bolting-on dense robo-roguelite build diversity that should satisfy nearly every player's approach to the genre. The enemies are tough, varied, and interesting in both design and mechanics; none of them useless, nor too strong. The difficulty options are good, and it recommends one based on tutorial performance, which is a nice way to build confidence in the player's abilities (or lack there-of)

The music is incredible and dynamic, so heart-pounding you'll be desperate for another run, and setting up that run is easy and fast, as you'd expect for a roguelite nowadays.

Only one crash/freeze/failure to load; during a Co-op run, the load screen did not finish and we had to abandon the run and restart the game. Otherwise, a bug free experience that is incredibly satisfying to play.

I highly recommend Roboquest! Might be my indie GOTY!

If you like the genre and support indie studios, I strongly recommend it.

Gotta take back everything that I said. Something happened between January 2023 (the last time I dove into the game) and release. Movement feels slower and less frantic, the difficulty has been ramped up mostly by nerfing the player character and increasing enemy spam, and I don't understand why any of it was done. They had a good thing, but they just like... poured glue all over it.

I put another 20 hours into the game, hoping that after unlocking everything (a tedious and obtuse process) it would get better, but while you unlock a lot more mobility, the key problem of the game punishing you for getting up close and personal, where before it was rewarded, has not changed.

The game's easy as long as you sit back and hide behind corners. The second you try to engage aggressively, you get smacked down. It didn't used to be this way, but now it is, and that's a real shame.

====

If you're looking for a fast-paced FPS with a big variety of guns and playstyles, this is your jam. Play defensively, stealthily, with helper drones, or just be a walking arsenal without picking up a gun in the first place. And each class has a variety of perks to make each playthrough feel just different enough.

Great soundtrack. Solid graphics (these are the most "work in progress" feeling at the moment but the game still looks damn pretty). Amazing, fast, fluid movement. The devs appear to be actively listening to their playerbase and implementing sensible changes based on feedback.

A few minor gripes here and there, but nothing worth mentioning besides that ONE of the boss fights is REALLY unintuitive. Once you know the trick, it's a snap, but until then it's pretty murky how to win. Most likely this will be regarded in a future update anyway, and it's already been adjusted. Also I personally hate the enemies that stop your movement and can sometimes blindside you from around corners, but if you pay attention for the most part those guys won't be too bad.

All of this and it's not even close to done, with the projection for 1.0 being August of 2022. This is how to do early access games. Can't wait to see how this turns out and would love to see even more added to the game down the line. I'd happily shell out some extra money for DLC stuff and/or the devs' next game.

Edit: So 1.0 ended up coming out November 2023 but it was worth the wait. Everything I said above still applies other than the graphics have been upgraded, the game is polished and complete, and it's still a lot of fun. It's amazingly well-optimized, I'm running it on Ultra with a 2070 Super and it doesn't overheat my GPU like a lot of other games. Infinite thumbs up.

I bought Roboquest 47 hours ago and I've already played it for 24 hours, half of that time in one session.

If you enjoyed playing Gunfire Reborn then playing Roboquest is a no-brainer, it shares themes from other games too but nothing as close as Gunfire Reborn. The gunplay is as expected with fluid movement reminiscent of Apex Legends, It's quite well polished and overall very enjoyable to play.

However, at the start you wont notice but there isn't much variety in terms of enemies / bosses. You will probably fight the same five robot types every stage with one or two different unique ones thrown in every so often. The areas also aren't random so you'll find yourself going through the same path over and over with the potential to go through other paths if you find the right keys, though these are pointless as the are often ''secret'' areas which just provide you with unlockables so going through them more than once isn't beneficial. Both the lack of variety from the stages / enemies does take away from the replayability factor but I'm sure more content will come in the future.

The multiplayer is fine with just some minor issues that don't suit me as much, I don't like how pathways and doors are locked if you're playing with someone who hasn't got that key or seen that path yet but I understand why it was done that way. I dislike that reviving your teammate drains your own hitpoints in half, you should only be punished that way if the other teammate ''auto revives'', I know there is an item that stops the HP drain from reviving but you aren't going to get that every run. In my opinion it's a mechanic that needs reworking.

Despite these issues I still think it's a great game and if you want to try a new first person shooter it's definitely  worth your time and money.
