Very fast paced game with satisfying mechanics and abilities. The generous hitboxes make you feel like an aim god but the enemy density and variations in tile-sets keep you on your toes and prevent the game from getting too easy and stale. You are rewarded for going fast but methodical gameplay isn't punished. All of the classes feel viable and strong with very distinct playstyles and varying possibilities for upgrades within a run. The out-of-run progression feels incremental but meaningful and provides motivation to keep coming back for more. The progress that this game has seen from early access through to now is very impressive and makes me very excited for the future of Roboquest and any other titles made by RyseUp. Any DLC for Roboquest would be an instant-buy from me.

65 hours in, 3 achievements left for 100% completion. Yeah no it's not great.

Jokes aside, if you like games that reward skilled movement and good aim, get Roboquest. Sure, it has roguelike elements which come in the form of buffs you can choose from after every level up, however most of your runs are going to rely on you identifying which threat is the most important, where and when you should reposition, and proper knowledge of your guns and items. There are builds, but not one is more broken than the other. If you tend to get hit often, play the Guardian and build around the bubble. Prefer heavy combat and enjoy technical movement with rocket jumping, then pick the Commando. Want to spam crap at enemies? Go Elementalist. This game is truly a great time through and through, and the co-op is really fun as well. Best part though is the fact that the whole game as well as the ending lend themselves to expansions in the future, which the devs have confirmed will happen, so really pick up this game if you can, it's a real blast!

This game is very fun but has some features that hamper the enjoyment. 

Things I can't stand that this game contains:
TAKES CONTROL AWAY FROM YOU. (Literally makes you complete a QTE to stop being stunned. It's ridiculous, especially for how fast you die when the enemies get easy shots. Also, enemies will "hack" your character, and it reverses all the controls. Pretty annoying, especially on the final boss.)
Teleporting enemies (nothing better than an enemy just appearing in front of you and already hit you (sarcasm))
Melee (as essential for at least 2 characters) in a FPS. (all the enemies shoot projectiles, I won't be fighting them hand to hand)
Collecting collectibles. 
Poorly hidden enemies (they are nearly impossible to see at moments, only by a small black wire poking out of a patch of grass...you'll see what I mean when you get there). 
Most of the guns are not worth using. 
Most of the upgrades have negative traits. (i really don't get this, just make it weaker without the negative, same problem returnal had). 
Some rooms can be a bit small. 
Character upgrades really take a long time to understand, (you have to do it so that things balance or work in tandem, but some of the upgrades are unclear or you just aren't sure of their effectiveness...and the runs can get long).
Extremely bullet spongey (that is until you get a 25% damage bonus, one of the reasons I had a hard time finishing it without doing any gadget unlocks or crystals is that I couldn't do enough damage quick enough)

I'm sure there are more, but that is enough. As for the good,

The enemies are already in their spots when you enter the rooms. They do end up teleporting the reinforcements in, but I was at least pleased to see that initial part. (usually these games just teleport all the enemies)
The movement feels good, I switched crouch to shift, and just put always run on. I am not sure why this wasn't default. I did have a problem with the rails though. You are waaay to fast on the rails, because it is basically holding down sprint the whole time. So, I had to counter and hold control (my new sprint key) while I was on the rails, but it definitely makes it a little more difficult when fighting the rail boss (and some of the platforming puzzles). 
When you get the randomizer to give you what you want, it is real fun, can get pretty powerful. Problem is there are those times where it just refuses to give you anything good. After you get the 25% damage boost though it kind of alleviates the bad rolls. 
The perk tree was nice. It was one of the better ones in this game type. It gives you something to keep pushing towards, and each time I unlocked something I wanted to do a new run to see if I could try it out. 

Other notes:
I really only liked the commando, and maybe the engineer, but I really didn't like the others. 
I was really stubborn when I played this. I only ran the default character and didn't unlock much of anything for a long time. I just kept playing through and getting slightly further and unlocking the skill tree, but. I was really struggling to get past the final boss...and man, it sucks when you keep getting an hour and fifteen minutes in just to die and have to start over again. Well, if I wasn't so stubborn, and went down some of the side paths or interacted with the NPCs I probably would have completed the run much earlier. Those unlocks are important because they make the last level much more manageable. It's pretty chaotic when you go in with no crystals or gadgets (and with a character I loathe, the melee default one). So, ya, do yourself a favor and try and complete the side paths, and talk to the NPCs. The map really isn't as confusing as it seems (you can see it in the museum...again, stubborn, never looked at it...plus I thought it was all randomly generated for a couple runs). 

I should mention that this game starts you off with only a double jump, but you will unlock other methods of gaining height, to the point where it makes the platforming puzzles obsolete (and the final boss much easier). Also, spec into the abilities over the guns, Commando gets nuts (but gotta find that special combo). Just so ya know. 

So, this game is good, I enjoyed it, especially with the commando. It is not as good as crab champions but much better than deadlink, IMO.

At the most basic level, it's Gunfire Reborn if it actually had a personality, good movement, mechanics, good music, and good aesthetics. 

But I feel that simply calling it a better version of an existing game doesn't do it justice considering how much care, polish, and personality is injected into the final product, and how well it distincts itself from Gunfire. 

Everything you do feels great:
Jumping, shooting, reloading, dodging, sliding, grinding, grappling, melee'ing. 

The already kickass soundtrack combined, with the dynamic music system (while simple in it's implementation), adds so much to the soundscape of the game. Opening the safe room and unleashing a barrage of minigun fire as the bass drops just feels... Good!

If you enjoy any FPS roguelites, then you owe it to these devs to give this game a shot.

V1.0 EDIT:

Gonna start this review fresh, this is a good shooter early on and a FANTASTIC one toward the end of the meta-game. The movement is good, there's a lot of potential for vertical movement which is always fun, the gunplay is good and there are so many guns, almost to many because I still have trouble remembering how a gun plays from it's name and model in a shop. And while I'm mentioning guns, this game is one does the trait/affix mechanic very very well. They do matter and they do change gameplay significantly, especially for the Blue ones, you're not always gonna re-roll for +damage traits like in most games with this mechanic.

I think the unlock mechanism is very fun. It's very exploration and secrets based but you can figure out everything on your own. It's just fun brain-teasers, not something you'll need to look up a guide to find most of the solutions. The only things that might be a little over-tuned are the timed challenges in some areas but with some practice and better-suited characters, it's manageable.

The other nice thing about the unlock system is how it unlocks alternative levels a little like Dead Cells does. Even tho you *could* beat the game from your first run, it's fun to know there's still new areas with new enemies to explore. The enemies design is also pretty cool. There's very few "direct upgrades" and usually every area brings a couple of new enemies with unique shooting patterns and a lot of "remixes" who combine together mechanics introduced earlier enemies. There is a large roster of robots which are very well distributed among areas, making each one very unique, not only by the scenery but also their gameplay.

The boss design is also pretty good, with only a couple of boring ones in my opinion. Some of the later ones also have great level embracing the vertical movement.

I haven't played much of co-op but I really like that 1: each players can have their own individual progression and 2: doors and some other features are only unlocked if both players unlocked them. It sounds basic but so many games don't bother with these two (especially the second one). These two things make it so you can jump in with someone at any point in the game and not have everything spoiled for you. And because the unlocks are pretty much all side-path, experienced players don't even care much about spoiling stuff because they can still play forward to try to finish the game. Of course there's gonna be some skill and unlock-gaps but it's not like experienced players are gonna start with a lot of levels and damage over new players. (Although the starting hp upgrades feel like the ones that makes the biggest stats difference.)

The only thing i'm not the biggest fans of is unlocking cards for weapons. It takes forever and kinda discourage me from playing guns I actually enjoy because there's so many to unlock. But in the end, it's not very important to unlock them and there is a way to slightly accelerate that way latter in the game.

Some negative reviews are a disappointed that there's not enough upgrades to build around but that's not really an issue to me. The strength of the game is the fps gameplay and i'm very happy they played into that instead of making winning the game be about building a stupid combo. And that being said, there's still a LOT of synergies to build around with the character upgrades, they just don't overshadow the regular gameplay.

Ok, I'll compare this game to Gunfire Reborn a lot. They both are executions of the same formula.

First of all, the core gameplay of of Roboquest is much stronger. You run faster, you jump higher, you can slide on ramps and bounce on robot's heads. Lots of fun.

Second, there is less combos to make in this game. Level up upgrades are well designed for each character and work well with each-other. However, you won't get much going at the beginning because you need a couple of upgrades to get more than 2 choices per levels. Also, it's pretty much the only part where you make a build in the game. Gun affixes are fun but I almost haven't seen any that would synergize in a relevant way. Also there are no "artefacts" or "scrolls" or whatever to give you extra effects to play with. Instead you get stats which definitely help and create fun choices but it's mostly more damage on the colour of guns you like the most.

Now all of that isn't too much of an issue. In my opinion, Roboquest is more about being a shooter. You get choices but you can quickly choose "yeah, sure this looks fun" and get back to shooting. You don't spend too much time looking at every single gun you find and go "oh I could build like this, or like that if i'm luck". Again, neither a pro or a cons, just a difference.

Third, Roboquest don't have lots of content yet. It has enough that I wouldn't feel bad suggesting to buy it full price but there are a lot of "under construction" areas and probably not much more than 10 guns that I love playing. It's an early access game, the content is coming but it's only fair to warn you.

Lastly, no idea how the multiplayer is. I haven't convinced friends to buy it yet. I'm under the impression that, like Gunfire Reborn, it's a good game singleplayer that also has multiplayer. The cooperation will probably be "we're all on the same team and shooting at the same things" and won't go much deeper than that.

Anyway, I love the game. It's a very fun shooter. Don't let the girl guilt-trip you into using her crosshair. Seeing the floor is much more important than the sky, especially in boss battles.

I've been following this game for a while. In early access, this game showed so much promise, despite the obvious lack of content for a good while. And now that it's finally out, I can be safe to say that the developers definitely delivered! During early access the developers accepted a lot of feedback and it really shows. From them changing entire systems, to balance changes, they weren't afraid to listen to what people had to say. Though even from the start, it was still a pretty fun game to pick up every so often. It had pretty consistent quality updates throughout it's EA, each time a new one would come out I'd hop on and have a blast. Between the constant dev support and community feedback, I think Roboquest is a perfect example of early access done right.

Roboquest is a great game. It takes a lot of inspiration from the Borderlands series, however, it very clearly has it's own identity which is great. The amazing visuals, topped with smooth movement and great gun play make this game a wonder to play. The designs for the robots are awesome, a lot of names for things are fun or cute (they have a robot vendor called Heisenbot). Like there's so many little guys, I LOVE IT. The music is also great for what it is. The roguelike is a lot less RNG dependent than other games in the genre. There are runs that are clearly better than others, however you can win any run if you have the skills to which I really enjoy. There's a ton of fun weapons, upgrades, and secrets to keep you engaged for quite a while.

The new 1.0 update is honestly a lot bigger than I thought it was going to be. When they said that the next update would be 1.0 I thought the game was going to have missing areas since there were like 8 places labeled "under construction", but nope! They added like 20 new npcs too, like it feels like I'm in completely new areas even though I have played through them many times in EA. It's very good that the update didn't feel like it was just slapped onto the previous version, it makes the final version of the game feel complete and connected.

Overall, the devs did great handling the early access and released a very solid roguelike. Would recommend.

Love this game.

Very smooth, very optimised. Great combat, great mobility, nice weapon feedback, overall sound design, and great style. 

Bosses are fun and fast-paced and don't feel samey. 

The perks in particular are thoughtful and progress well and stack without feeling too overpowered. You definitely feel the impact of a great set of perks but it's still best to play optimally and tactically. Same goes for items. 

The classes are very competitively balanced and each offer interesting ways to build without compromising a familiar flow of play. I often swap between at least 3. Sometimes what you have a mind to do suggests a different class! 

Progress feels very unique, with the mission flow being the standard, but choosing your path in real time can lead to new unlocks and fun challenges. Runs aren't too long and it's rewarding to try tp collect the perks and guns you want.

My ONLY suggestion is that the automatic weapons feel a little undertuned. As someone who doesn't go crazy over the more meme guns, weapons like the SMGs, LMGs and ARs could use a little love! But I still get plenty kick out of the rifles, pistols, and shotguns.

OLD PRE-1.0 REVIEW:
[h1] This game has: [/h1]

Gameplay somewhere between Doom, Gunfire Reborn, Arena Shooters such as Quake, garnished with Ghostrunner in music and pace

Movement third only to Ghostrunner and Warframe

Clean, responsive, and fast shooting

Variety of classes and builds/subclasses

Variety of weapons

Variety of styles of level, though not level concepts/designs

A well tuned (IMHO) difficulty ramp per-run

Good optimization

Ability to bonk robots back to horny jail

[h1] This game could use [/h1]

A few weapon buffs (Fire gun, MINE GUN, to name a couple)

An ending or endless continuation system (seeing as the game is in early access however, this is likely already in progress)

Greater sense of overall progression (if you've played loot based games before and/or check weapons frequently, this is less prevalent, however for most people the game will feel largely the same from fresh to completion as of now)

Re-balancing of gadgets (initial/constant skills chosen before a run). Currently IMHO the gadgets are pretty cut and dry on which ones are the best.)

And more, but these are the ones I find to be the most self-evident and agreeable.

Overall I HIGHLY recommend this game, personally, if you like fast paced shooters. Notice I did not add rogue-likes/lites there. Unless you are used to making body pillows of every gun you pick up in other games, I think most will find this game's approach a wonderful time. Speaking for myself, I had tried Hades last year and stopped playing after ~7-8 hours as it hadn't quite hooked me. Roboquest made me want to revisit pretty much every rogue-like/lite in my library, and made me fall in love with the rogue-like formula again. 

[u] State-Mandated """Numeric""" Appraisal (SMNA): [/u]

[b] A Baja-Blast-Chugging robot wielding a minigun out of 10 [/b]
Sent me to the fucking moon

I've seen a few people compare this Roboquest to Gunfire Reborn. Lemme start by saying I'm not gonna do that. 
They're both roguelite shooters where you can play as different characters (or use different classes in Roboquest) that have unique abilities. Every weapon you find will have modifiers that go from changing their stats around to adding mini-mechanics to them (particularly in Gunfire Reborn).
That's it. They don't have anything else in common outside of their base idea. The 2 games aren't interchangeable at all.

Roboquest doesn't shower you in resources during your runs. Its a fast paced game with a heavy focus on clearing a level as fast as possible and as well as efficently as possible to gain better rewards. Said rewards are robo-batteries, the money of this game. Its required for upgrading the guns you have, buy new guns and items, etc. So you'll really want to be fast and efficient for the best rewards.

In terms of movement, Roboquest is really good. You can run, double jump and slide. There's also rail-grinding, jump pads and stage hazards that shake up a lot of the arenas. If you're good at schmooving you can find yourself at the top of these arenas where there's often collectibles hidden up there. I'll touch on that later.

Enemies in this game are also pretty agressive. Even the first stage enemies are good at aiming and have multiple projectiles (a mine and their regular gun). There's also a lot of them in every arena. Not a comical ammount, but enough that even at your best your gonna be hit a few times. And they only get harder with each stage by shooting more bullets at once, gaining different elements (Burn, freeze and shock) adnd even adding new mechanics like flying, having smoke bombs and even teleporting.
Enemy variety is pretty good, but they are all a variantion of one of the few type of enemies in the game. You have turrets, small puntable robots, your standard grunts, drones, etc. There's also bosses obviously, which are all locked to a certain area and never get switched around.

Okay, now for the combat. It is BEAUTY. The combat is as fast paced as the race of the game is. There's no remaining ammo to worry about, all you have to worry about is if you gun is reloading/cooling from overheating. And its all done quickly, with some great ammo, sound and visual flair. Like, you know how gunfire is shown on comic books? Yeah they do that while they shoot, its great.
Outside of reloading, all the weapons fire quickly and accurately too. It all keeps the flow of the game quick, even if you decide to stomp every enemy you encounter.
There's not that many weapons though. Each are unique in how they feel but each are part of one of the larger weapon type (rifles, automatics, shotguns, explosives, etc). Depending on the class you play, you'll end up using a certain type, since all classes (minus the Guardian, the default class) cater to one or two specific ones.

One thing that makes Roboquest stand out from other roguelite shooters is the level up mechanic. Murking robots actually gives EXP, and EXP allows you to choose a perk for the whoel run. It seems you can get up to lvl 15 max. EXP gain is actually the second thing you're graded on for your final rank when clearing a level
Outside of that, you can still buy object that boost some things, like how powerful an element is or by causing an explosion when reloading.

And finally, progression. Doing multiple runs back to back in this game won't make them repetitive, at least for 4/7 levels. There's different paths you can take in the first 3 levels, each leading to different zones. There's even paths to "corrupted" zones, where the enmies will just murder you.
Each of these zones have collectible and mini-sidequests. Each level has data journals that give you a glimpse in the lore of the game. There's keys to collect that give you access to other zones. Some doors even require a code, or a certain ammount of batteries, or even a specific upgrade. Theres also some old robots you can find that require certain items to give you something.

All in all, if you like roguelite shooters, or just fast shooters in general, this game is an absolute MUST.
It's absolutely worth its 25$.

Roboquest is an amazing FPS with rogue-lite elements and fast paced action. In this game you play as a guardian robot, tasked with reclaiming a city that has been overrun by evil robots. 
The game features an intense gameplay focusing on movement and gunplay. Movement in this game feels amazing, it is very fluid and has many different options to choose from. You can chain these moevement patterns together for maximum speed. Dash across the map, then slide for a quick speed boost, jump directly afterwards on an enemy head and use the momentum to launch even higher to get on a platform. It's really cool how well these fit together and how fluid the gameplay feels thanks to that.
Maintaining a high speed is very important since at the end of each level you get a rating based on how many enemies you have killed and how fast you were, so to get the best rating you have to kill most enemies as fast as possible. Getting a high rating isn't just for show, you get a currency at the end that you can use to pay at shops.

The gunplay is also fantastic. The game has  alot of different guns and the developers made sure that each one feels unique and impactful. You have basic weaponry like handguns, assault rifles and shotguns but you also get some crazy guns like a lightning assault rifle or a cannon that fires massive, exploding snowballs. These weapons have all their own abilities but additionally they can also get randomized abilities. Weapons with higher rarity have more special effects and in some cases they may even have a secondary firing mechanic. Weapons also have levels, which decide how strong the damage of the weapon is. The level of a weapon is defined by the level it drops in, so you will switch out weapons often to stay on an even level. You can also upgrade your weapon in a shop if you had a very good weapon drop that you don't want to lose. By default you can carry only two weapons and the game has a unqiue mechanic to encourage player using both weapons frequently. When you use a weapon during combat, the other weapon in your backpack automatically reloads. Speaking of ammo, ammo is unlimited, so you never run out.

Additionally to weapons, the game also uses a character class and perk system. There are six different classes in the game and each class has their own upgrade perks as well as a few common perks that all classes share. The class perks can even be upgraded further with two different upgrades. During your run you get experience for killing enemies and every time you level up you can select one perk of a random selection from your aviable perks. All perks stack with each other and the generic perks can even be obtained multiple times. Perks generally affect eoither your ability, your weapons or your character in general. Choosing your perks carefully defines what kind of build you will be going for.

During your runs you can also get some items, either from chests or from the shop. You won't get many items during a run but they provide nice passive boosts to your character. They also stack with your perks, which means you can improve your build even further. 

The game has a few metaprogression elements as well. Enemies have a chance to drop wrenches, which can be used to buy permanent upgrades at the base between runs. These upgrades generally increase the amount choices in chests and in stores and also increase the chances for stores appearing. There are also a few upgrades that apply directly for your character, like extra health for example.  There are also sectret levels in the game and beating those unlocks crystals, which, when activated from your base, provide a passive bonus but also increase the amount of elite enemies you will face during your run. And you can find some friendly robots during your runs, usually at some secret locations, which will give you a quest. If you finish those quests, you get a gadget in return, which is a permanent item that you can activate or deactivate at your base. 

The games art design mirrors the looks of a comic book, even the cutscenes are designed in that way. Character models use cell-shading and sound effects are written out on the screen. It is a cool look that I personally like.
The soundtrack, done by Noisescream, features heavy metal music and electronic sounds, a fitting choice for a futuristic action game full of robots and metal violence. It's an absolute banger to listen to.

Overall I would recommend this game to people who love shooters with fast and intense action and also like rogue-lite elements. I want to point out at the end, this is a FPS first and a rogue-lite second. You have more focus on the action part of the game  and your actual skill in shooting and dodging than creating a broken build that carries your weak ass. There are some broken builds in this game but it's not the main focus. If that sounds like fun to you, go ahead and buy this, you won't regret it.

Arguably one of the best, if not THE best fps roguelites on the market right now.
Incredible gunplay, great variety in the different classes and weapons/items.
Very nice music, though it does get a bit repetitive at times, but that's normal given that it's a roguelite and you're bound to be listening to the same tracks over and over.
The visuals are top notch too, I really like the cell shaded artstyle overall.
Really the only particularly negative thing I can say about this game is that it kind of... lacks character.
As the title makes clear, this game's about robots on a quest, and that's all it really is about. Robots.
You play as a generic looking robot, with your color depending on the class you picked and you fight enemy robots which are all some sort of variation of what you would see in one of the Portal games.
You fight and make your way through generic looking arenas, which are all basically somewhere on the Ruins-High Tech Facility scale, with the latter levels basically just being High Tech Facility + purple boxes everywhere.
The robots you play as all look exactly the same save for your color, the robots you fight against are, again, almost all just a generic white robot with a red eye in the middle that signals "shoot here for critical damage!"
Its definitely something nitpicky and if this doesn't bother you at all then great, the game is basically perfect. 
But when there's so many games like this that all have their own unique aesthetic and vibe which stand out from each other a lot, Roboquest just kind of feels generic.
Either way, the game plays great, feels great and looks great(being generic looking aside) and if you like roguelites or FPS', it's definitely a great pick

Pros: Roguelite FPS with a variety of weapons. Really appreciate the easy modes for casuals, relaxing with a podcast and for introducing friends; If you want more of a challenge you can turn the difficulty right up.

Cons: Common weapons and common modifiers flood the drop pools, meaning one play through will be very similar to the next. You don't find enough variety or legendary drops or items to make runs significantly different. There's no explanation or hints for unlocking gadgets. When looking at modifiers there's no telling if it applies to your weapon or what difference it would make. 

Multiple times I've wanted to know where I was in a run but the map is only accessible from the home base leaving me wishing it would show in the tab menu. The music loops and sudden stops can get to you but I just turned the music down and put a podcast on in the background.

[h3] My Dream FPS Rogue-Lite [/h3] 
Despite sinking tons of hours into the early access release on Xbox Gamepass this game still surprises and delights! It's been an absolute joy to see the game progress over the years and the 1.0 release exceeded my expectations ten fold. 
[b] If you're new to shooters, this game is for you. If you love movement shooters, this game is also for you. [/b] 
The rogue lite structure caters to losers like me who are looking to sink hours of their time into a mastering a well crafted challenge while also being stuffed with puzzle based secrets and mechanically unique quests/stages that give casual players a nice sense of progression without jeopardising the "true gamer experience". 
All of which is complimented by some boppin' tunes, uniquely beautiful visuals, entertaining writing, and great optimisation:
It looks and runs great on my GTX 1070 at 1440p 144hz -- just needed to knock shadows down to "high" and disable AA (the comic-book art style hides a lot of the aliasing).
So what the heck are ya waiting for? 
Pick it up with a friend or go in alone -- you won't be disappointed :)

Fun roguelite shooter with a huge gun variety which makes it very replayable, there are various classes with their own playstyle and a bunch of perk paths to go through too, which makes every run unique and allows you to spice it up every time.
The artstyle is dope, and the music fits great!

The roguelite element does mean you will not get much further than the first 2~3 levels in your first few runs, and then later you will blow through those first few levels like it's nothing, but with the solid shooting mechanics it's still loads of fun.

Upgrading the central hub also changes up the visuals to really reinforce the feeling of progression, which is a really neat touch.

All in all, I would definitely recommend this for anyone looking for a nice replayable shooting game (bonus: you can play with your partner/friend).

It's very refreshing to see a game led by a small team so fleshed out.  Every step of the way, Roboquest thinks about the player experience; from a tutorial which asks you your preferred sprint type and crosshair position, to failsafe systems for the 1 bug I encountered in 24 hours which was a non-issue due to anti-softlock features.
And to top it all off, it's a complete game.  Scaling difficulties, achievements, secrets, and a banging dynamic music track.

If you like roguelike/lites, you should already own this game. It also has the rare bonus of having GREAT online co-op multiplayer that ISN'T local! Progression makes sense for both players, and there's tons of stuff to find. 

Runs can be a bit long, and the game urges you to play like an optimal maniac, so I'll tell you up front to separate your runs into two categories: 

A) Beating the game being as strong as possible 
B) Missing out on clear rewards to find secrets. (And there are a lot of secrets)

IMO, the game does need some improvements to the UI to help make things a bit easier to navigate (please let me use my cursor in the tab menu), and some kind of run saving function would be amazing. It actually takes quite a bit of time to get to the ending area of the game, and it would be really nice to have a way to pause the run if I need to jet, and bonus points if I can do that during CO-OP play! 

Normally with games that hit their 1.0 release coming out of early access, there's an underwhelming groan in fear of not having enough content, but I can confidently say that the game is fully worth it's release, AND sale price, and I'm honestly surprised it's not extremely popular right now. 

Plus, due to the game selling a bunch and getting achievements added late, they're all rare. [b]Every single one of them.[/b]

I was on the fence for buying this game for the longest time, though having enjoyed games similar (Gunfire Reborn and Deadlink) I decided to buy it when I saw it was released. 

And HOLY SHIT it did not disappoint. In fact, it might be my favorite of the three now. The movement system is incredibly freeform, fun, and you can stomp on enemies like you're mario but you have guns like you're doomguy.  

The classes all have a lot of fun and unique ways to build them, play them, and synergize in weird ways, and exploring the levels for secrets is a ton of fun too. 

Just don't let Billy Boom's funny yellow bar fill up. That's very bad.

If the idea of a roguelike FPS even remotely appeals to you just buy it. Blows Gunfire: Reborn out of the water in my opinion. Soundtrack is incredible, and there isn't that much BS to kill you unlike some roguelikes. Co=op is a massive selling point for me and this game does it very well

Played more than my share of roguelikes over the years, another review comparing this as a cross between Gunfire Reborn & Borderlands is spot on. Incredibly fun gameplay loop if you enjoy FPS titles, and each of the classes I've played so far enable unique tactics.

There's a lot of replayability through unlocking base upgrades (permanent buffs for your character), new routes to take during a run and gadgets (passive abilities that persist between runs). The variety in abilities/skills for each class also allows for a lot of experimentation which I enjoy.

My singular only gripe with the game is that multiplayer only supports 2 players, but that's if i'm being fussy. Can't really criticise this game beyond that, looking forward to future content updates.

Playing on Hard. Three classes unlocked, about 20 runs in. The game is moderately fun and runs well. Unfortunately there are some design choices that just make this below average for me. 

Enemy density is very high. It not because there are too many enemies, its because the space to fight them is too small. You are packed into relatively narrow corridors, and the arena sections, with up to 20 enemies spawned simultaneously, which are aggressive and follow you around corners, feel like you are supposed to stay mobile and side strafe around every projectile. Up to 20 simultaneous projectiles is a lot to ask the player to dodge, and arenas are so small that you are bumping into enemies constantly if you are on the move.

The comparison to gunfire reborn is fair, these are very similar games and it is hard not to compare the two. The graphics are better. The art is worse.  The shooting feels better. The balance is worse. 

Ultimately this game is most hampered by the map design. The environments are small, at least half as large as the previously mentioned game while also containing a larger amount of more aggressive enemies. There is a middle ground between needlessly large maps and feeling like you are wading through a crowd. Arenas need to be larger. 

Alternatively, spawn enemies from pre-determined points or entrances. The idea of enemies spawning in randomly and evenly spaced throughout the arena, including behind you, without notice, adds to the frustration of the enemy density.

If the devs' idea of balance is to simply make the player characters so overpowered that they can clear rooms instantaneously, then ultimately that is not as fun an experience as other games I have played in the same genre. Not there yet power-wise, but I can see the direction the player power is going. A few more perks, a little more gun progression, and these arenas will likely not feel like such a slog. But overall, I'm not a fan of countering poor design with overwhelming, time gated, player power. There is serious potential for a fun, movement and momentum based game, but the realities of the design choices actively hamper that playstyle. Doesn't feel tactical, doesn't feel skill based. The correct option is to hang back and hope you have a strong enough weapon to clear enemies quickly as they round the corner for you.  Eventually I'll just get an elemental minigun that mows down enemies, and that is the solution to the maps and arenas being designed for ants.

Overall, meh.

-Unlockable upgrades feel powerful and useful which I don't experience often in rogues

An excellent roguelike shooter, you should stop reading and download the demo right now. You'll buy the game.

The guns feel great with a wide variety of styles, the maps create fantastic combat areas you can maneuver around in, the soundtrack is killer, and the bosses are creative and each of them feels unique. The shooter gameplay is up there with Doom 2016 and your skill as a player always feels like it is at the forefront. The levels have a branching system with secrets allowing you to make choices multiple times in each run. Plus the choices start pretty early so runs continue to feel fresh. The speed bonuses, the side rooms, and the extermination bonuses manage to make both speed runner and completionist play styles feel rewarding while subtly pushing you to improve so you can achieve both.

The only downside I can think of is that co-op caps at 2 players. It was designed for 2, so it plays very tight in co-op. However, if a crew of 3-4 come together you'll have to play something else that night. 

It is worth the full price of $25.

I can't wait to see what kind of support the devs carry on to provide, or what they go on to next after roboquest once they decide to finish supporting RQ.

0.12 review
Probably one of the best FPS games I have played in years, the game does you want a fast paced FPS rogue lite to do. The movement is so fun and clean in this game that I could spend hours just running around maps if I wanted to without shooting mobs. the rogue lite elements are fun and rarely feel to over the top  or like you are flat being carried. Every death is normally your fault so if you are prepared to step back and take a look at your self and your play style you can learn how to overcome each challenge with out feeling purely carried by 1 item or build. Not only this but the game is doing EA right, it is trying things, when the updates are bad for what ever reason the devs listen to the community so well, and fix things either in the next path or with in days. To the point they even delayed one of their bigger updates because on a public test people did not like a few mechanics, and they flat scrapped it and remade it for the better. The devs are making a game of passion with this one. I've never seen devs who care more about putting out a good game for people to enjoy.

100% recommend. Buy it

now that 1.0 is out you need to buy this game

Play if you like:
- Boomer and Arena Shooters (Doom, Unreal Tournament, etc.)
- Roguelikes (kind of obvious)
- Not needing a beefy PC to play it (My main rig is pretty new, but I can't wait to try it on Steam Deck!)

Combat: Fast paced fights at a variety of ranges. Tons of weapons available at the start of the game, and more of them appear after a certain point in a run. Guns all feel good and many have clear inspiration from other games. I was pleasantly surprised to see both the Shock Rifle and Flak Cannon have expies here, as well as some weapons I can't really make a comparison for. Weapons drop at a decent pace and the power level of them increases per area. Comparing loot is fast and not a drag. Character skills and loadouts look simple on paper, but what you can do with them is a lot more in practice, particularly when character specific skill upgrades appear in a run. I like how the game helps keep the chaos manageable by giving you warning arrows for enemies that are nearby, so you don't get completely screwed by enemies you don't hear or when you forget to check your minimap.

Sights and Sounds: This game's artstyle instantly reminds me of Atlas Reactor/Rogues and comic book text accompanies every weapon when it's fired. Enemies are robots, you're a robot. In fact, I think the only character that isn't a robot is your story companion, who gives dialogue before each level and in rest areas. Sound effects are satisfying and punchy. The music is electronic with a variety of sounds from genres all over the past 20 years or so. Driving beats are common throughout, with nearly any kind of synth you can imagine from the height of industrial to anything that sounds akin to Pendulum's latest releases. Certified bangers throughout!

Performance: My rig is high end, with an i5 13600KF CPU, RX 6800XT GPU, and 32 GB of RAM. Loading time between levels is only a few seconds on a hard drive. The game defaulted to Ultra and I haven't had to glance at the settings. It runs perfect on my 144hz monitor at 8x AA and with everything turned up. In fact, my previous PC is 9 years old and was mid-high range back then, and it is still above the system requirements. If you have a potato, try the demo.

Progression: Good surprises throughout. I appreciate having a lot of guns to begin with, since bad roguelikes will make you throw yourself at the wall a hundred times before you see something fresh. My only gripe is after hours of me and a friend getting stuck around the same point to unlock another character. We were blazing through earlier zones but making 0 progress to beating a level. I turned the difficulty down to unlock the character myself, turned the difficulty back up, then played with my friend once more. We got to the final area the first time, but not because this character is OP or anything like that, but because it just suited my playstyle a lot more. Permanent upgrades affect your weapon drops, extra passive effects for your character, and the frequency that vendor/upgrade encounters happen in rest areas. Even if you fail a run, you still get a good amount of wrenches, the main currency for these upgrades.

Randomness: I really like the tiles in this game. None of them are squares and all take on interesting layouts for encounters and can string together interesting upper sections if your character can reach them. You will also encounter optional zones and platforming puzzles for extra rewards that vary greatly in difficulty, but will never kill you in one mistake if you decide to back out of one. I enjoy the guns to begin with, but the random upgrades take it a step farther. Of course, there are your expected passive bonuses. But what I appreciate are extra elements like random secondary fire modes that make guns feel even more distinct than games like Borderlands or Gunfire Reborn (Gunfire's guns are highly creative and can have unique random properties, but always have the same fire modes.). I've never felt like runs have a "make or break" build path to get far except the previously mentioned instance when I had to lower the difficulty to unlock a character I meshed well with. Finally, when you start getting character specific upgrades during a run, the game will make related upgrades appear more often so you can realize a build based on those upgrades on pretty much every run.

Multiplayer: Although the game is limited to 2 players, I appreciate this decision. The tiles are at a good size and making them bigger would either make 1 and 2 player runs feel too large for the enemy count or force the dev to make entirely new tiles for extra players. As for the experience itself, I've had no issues with connecting to games, staying connected, or any cases of lag. My internet is proper crap and this game can run on it a-ok. There isn't much that any character can do to interact with one another but you can at least share dropped weapons. Pickups are per player, so if an enemy dies and drops health for you, you don't have to worry about stealing potential healing from your friend. This is very much a single player kind of experience, but I appreciate the dev putting enough thought and care into the two player mode to not deviate from the original experience.

1.0.0 feels incredible and is a great take on a fast paced, rogue-like arcade shooter.  8/10

Pros:
A lot of the weapons have impact and interesting to play with, builds are diverse and easy to riff on a play-style you enjoy, secrets are interesting and rewarding, meta upgrades aren't extremely power defining and mostly open up options to play with.  The difficulty curve is steep at first but levels off nicely once you learn the enemies patterns.  Bosses are fun and offer very unique challenges to most of the game.  A ton of the perks and upgrades feel "build-defining" while easily slotting into whatever play-style you enjoy.

Cons:
Some of the weapons feel extremely under-tuned, even with good affixes and a build that should play to their strengths; this is especially true of some of the snipers which have extremely long between shot animations which make them feel clunky and slow in an otherwise fast-pace environment.  Damage from explosions and "aoe projectiles" stacks up ~maybe slightly too fast when you get cornered and easily leave you feeling helpless.  Some of the terrain and pipes is a bit sticky can leave you feeling a bit out of control.
If you're specifically looking for an FPS action roguelite, then look no further. At the time of writing (November '23), this is the best one on the market right now. And its not even close.

Great co-op roguelite fps. Nice clean art style, fun and interesting guns and an easy to learn upgrade system.

Movement is snappy, double jump, grind and slide your way through random gen levels.

Enemy types are a bit lacking at time of writing but they're functional and fun to shoot regardless.

Edit: Game is now released out of early access and folks it is a certified banger. Buttery smooth movement shooting at it's best. This game will effortlessly activate your flow state and with a wealth of progression you have many hours of solo or coop blasting ahead of you.

Music is pretty good with a few stand out tracks but it does get repetitive. That said the game play does not and there are a lot of fun play styles to experiment with.

10/10 this is one to get.

Had this game on my radar for quite a while, even added it like two times to my steam wishlist but kept removing it during the early access times because i thought i'd never play it anyways. I already had Gunfire Reborn as my go-to FPS roguelite game. But after watching Ccrypto (a Borderlands YouTuber) cover this game I was convinced to buy it as soon as it leaves early access. And as it turned out, not getting this game earlier was a mistake because oh boi is this game good. alright, first off, i want to say something to the devs (if they read this that is.) i love you guys and your work. this game has been my absolute favorite rouge like game of all time and i love every second of playing it. your dedication to actually pull the game through and out of early access (something that i feel like doesn't happen much these days) while also adding frequent updates, reworks and patches is something that i really admire. anyway that is all, i love you guys, thank you for an amazing game. it has given me many memorable moments of sweating my nuts off and having a blast jamming out to the BANGER of a soundtrack. :)

now that that is over. here is the review part for the consumer... just get it. its amazing. and its also not super expensive (compared to most games out there these days.) here is why you should get it:
1. it has little to no bugs (that I've seen.)
2. it has challenge for all ranges of people.
3. you really can play at whatever play style you want. there is so many combos to use and so many unique things with the classes that you can make the game what you want it to be. do you like sniping? oh boy does it feel good to get good at that in this game. do you like crazy fast firing weapons with a temporarily unlimited and boosted mag? you can do that. do you simply want to blow everything up? go for it. the world is your oyster.
4. the movement is nice and polished feeling and the game requires you to be good at it for the higher difficulties. 
5. it has an amazing soundtrack.

all that being said i do have some small critiques and that would be i wish it could get more difficult. after a while it felt like i hit the ceiling of skill and i couldn't to much more to make it more difficult for myself. however, after i got to that point i proceeded to spice things up by putting challenges on myself and because of the insane amount of customization that kept me entertained for a while. 

so in conclusion the game is amazing and has tons to offer (especially if you are willing to be a bit creative for yourself and make cool new challenges) so you should totally buy it and support the devs. 
for whoever read this i hope you have an amazing day with many more to come :D

I'm saying I would recommend this game but only if you have already played some of the other great Roguelike FPS's that exist.  Gunfire Reborn, Mother Gunship, Tower of Guns, Risk of Rain 2 (though that ones third person) are all much better than this one in my opinion.  It has potential but there is are a couple things that hold it back. 

My big problem is there isn't so much a difficulty curve as a solid brick wall.  I'm fairly experienced with High speed FPS games like this, Gunfire Reborn is very similar and I can fairly reliably beat high level reincarnation runs in that so I have some experience.  I started playing on hard mode and my first run got through the first boss no problem.  I've had a few runs that I've gone all but hit less through the first boss.  The first level after the boss knocks me down almost every time.  I have gotten through it maybe 4 times and have not once made it to the second boss. There are too may different enemies with too may different attacks that are too fast and even the smallest enemies take a good bit of focus fire to kill.  The game just does not give you the tools to handle it all.

So what is it that makes the game feel that way?

First the slide just feels bad.  It should be your best option for quick dodging but its barley faster than just running, and if you don't jump before its done you loose all momentum, but slide jumping locks you in moving  single direction for too long and allows the AI to get perfectly aimed leading shots on you. I just feel like I do better if I ignore slide exists. 

Second I just don't feel much impact form upgrades. Some of the level up perks are pretty good, i particularly enjoy the min rockets but a lot especially items are barely noticeable.  I went all in on an elemental lightning build but all it really amounted to was doing a bit more damage with guns that deal lightning damage, and the increase was if i remember correctly rather than hitting for 17 i hit for 20 with a full auto weapon.  This may just be because I'm not getting further in but 5 levels and 4+ items and most options just feel like they barely exist. 

Third, while the guns are fun they feel balanced weird.  Long range weapons in general feel a lot better than close range ones.  Whether your talking damage, fire rate, clip size, or reload speed the shortest range weapons just feel so outmatched. Pistols all just feel so slow to reload when you are up close to be in their effective range. Shotguns don't do enough damage, especially considering they all have pretty wide spreads and crit spots are comparatively small.  The slowdown from heavy weapons is especially punishing because as mentioned before you don't have a reliable dodge. Sniper rifles, Arquebus, and Carbine can all 1 or 2 shot average enemies, have good fire rates, more ammo, and decent reloads and the extra range makes it much easier to dodge incoming attacks.  It just feels like closer range weapons should get something to compensate. 

There is a lot of potential here but I just feel like it has some kinks to work out before that potential is realized.
It is an FPS Robot Rogue-lite. Enough said.

Do you ever pick up a new game, and within a few hours, you're just like... 

Oh yeah, this is the one. 

I picked this up early on during the early access period and was waiting for the 1.0 drop to finally leave a review. It's incredible to see how the devs have adapted and continuously improved upon the game as a response to feedback.

If you're a fan of games like Doom, Apex Legends, Borderlands or other shooter roguelites such as Gunfire Reborn, Deadlink and Mothergunship, you'll absolutely love this game. 

Honestly, there's no reason to carry on reading. If you like any of those above, you'll enjoy this. 

But in case you want more info ->

[h2] What Makes Roboquest Stand Out [/h2]

You could throw together a list of roguelite benefits, and it could apply to more than ten games. So, I'll tell you why I like this, and you can see if that jives with what you enjoy:

[list]
[*] A killer soundtrack that adapts to whether you're fighting or in a safe zone. And seriously, the soundtrack is amazing. 
[*] Simple roguelite system that feels meaningful
[*] Snappy, fast and fun gun play 
[*] Game play that is part character & build and part gun play, making it so the guns you use are relevant to your damage and play style
[*] A focus on movement and always being engaged
[/list]

I think a large part of why I enjoy this more than other roguelite options is because you're always engaged. There's no praying to the RNG gods that you get two items that complement each other, and you can just AFK. Nor is there a build-a-giant convoluted deck mechanic back at the base. 

It genuinely feels like a carefully crafted shooter that puts being in the action first, which, for me, is exactly what I want from a shooter - roguelite or otherwise. 

It also has coop with a friend, and while I understand other games - such as Gunfire Reborn and Risk of Rain, have more coop slots, I think it makes total sense for how this game plays. 

At the heart of it, it feels like a single-player roguelite experience that you just have a blast playing. The fact that they went the extra mile to create room for a friend is a bonus for me. 

[h2] The Roguelite Elements [/h2]

As you progress through each run, you're awarded with Wrenches. You can get these via rare drops from enemies, by finding collectables or from beating areas. 

The amount you receive from beating areas is based on a score. You're scored on your total EXP earned (how many enemies total you beat), the time it took you to complete the level and a small bonus depending on your difficulty. 

You then use these to make permanent upgrades in between each run. These upgrades feel meaningful - not X% to damage or something like that, but actual choices that impact how you play or what you may find in the next run. 

You can also discover new characters, unlock new gadgets (passive items for your runs) and a new crystal mechanic that influences the final area, which has been added for 1.0.

Since the wrenches are tied to finishing levels, they never feel like a grind to get. While you require more for future upgrades, there's a lot in the game, with different routes to keep you engaged. 

[h2] Replayability [/h2]

If you are playing the game normally - meaning you aren't trying to speed run - runs will take at least 30 minutes, which may sound like a fair amount of time when compared to other games. This is, of course, assuming you beat the run. 

The combination of the extremely good soundtrack, large number of unique and fun weapons, and character build differences helps keep each run feeling fresh, even if you run them back to back. 

You have multiple characters, each with their own distinct play style - an engineer that summons minions, stealthy stabby characters, a defensive invulnerable character and so on. 

So there's a lot you can change to freshen up the experience when you feel you need to. 

[h2] Fun Factor [/h2]

The game is a blast. 

Your character and weapon choice definitely impact the way you play the game. You can choose to be quick and blast through things or pick a weapon that suits a more in-the-back, relaxing style. The fast movement limits the downtime between encounters and the other mechanics in place help increase the options you have while making for some incredibly fun moments. 

On top of the standard gun play stuff, there's also:

[list]
[*] Rail grinding to get around/dodge projectiles
[*] Headbouncing on enemies to reset your jump and deal damage
[*] Unlockable doors/alternate routes during runs
[*] Hidden collectables 
[*] Interesting boss mechanics
[/list]

And thought I'd note there's no collision damage either thankfully. 

[h2] Is it worth the buy? [/h2]

100%

Especially so if you have a friend that's open to playing it with you. 

Each run feels quite unique and there's a lot to unlock. Not to mention, the devs are incredible at fine-tuning the experience to make it more enjoyable and listen to feedback. I have no doubt that they'll continue to improve upon this already great 1.0 release in the future.
Super fun and addicting! Gunplay and movement are very satisfying and fun! Lots of different weapons and combos to try out that will keep you playing for hours!

The movement system, weapon variety, gun feel, and the skills/perks/cores all come together to make a fun experience that varies a lot from run to run.	[/strike]

Played Early Access for a good 6-months. I had maxed-out all the upgrades and I collected all the relevant items. This means, I didn't get all the secret data-logs that really didn't seem to serve a purpose. Even after that, I played this game a ton - it's just simply a good Rogue-Like FPS. 

After the 1.0 release; a lot has changed. For the better! There's more to do. What SEEMS like a better balance, from what I've played. I love the game's atmosphere after the stuff that was in Early Access. 

Now, some criticisms. 

There's a level that's about racing the time and the room for error on it is frustratingly small. It also makes you fail a run, which takes about a minute or two of game play (not including loading and restarting, picking level ups, grabbing weapons, etc). It just became very, very frustrating - as I am not good at those kinds of things and I had to spend an hour or two trying to beat that level. 

The classes feel way more restrictive than they used to. In the Early Access I felt like I had more viable choices when playing. Now, it feels like each class requires basically the same choices with minor tweaks. 

And to be honest, some weapons just feel completely worthless because they don't work with any build specifically. 

And one final criticism, there are builds/classes where they're melee based. They largely are just kind of shallow experiences. There's no reason to hunt weapons, which means there's very little reason to get power cells. It becomes extremely linear. Don't get me wrong, you're very powerful but, that's what makes it so formulaic - run towards  the enemy holding down the melee button, occasionally use special. 

Other than those criticisms, I can't praise the game enough.

Been playing Roboquest since early beta times. Game went through many changes, and seem to have landed in a pretty sweet spot. To me it's simply the best Roguelite out there, highly recommend the title.

Edit after Full Launch: Yep, it's still mid. I beat the game on my second run and the final cutscene was glitched. After beating Iris' second phase, I just heard a bunch of noise while staring at a black screen. Great job, devs. Really great work. So glad I lost all my previous progress so I could see this new black screen!

After having beaten the entirety of the (current) game's content, there is sadly an insanely lacking amount of rogue-lite content in this game. If you beat the game four times, you'll have unlocked every last thing, and worst of all, they do almost nothing to make runs different. 

The best thing this game offers is the gunplay, which is amazingly smooth. Almost every gun is punchy and satisfying to use, with some being far, far more fun than others, regardless of effectiveness. The second thing this game has is the aesthetic. The maps are bright and vibrant, even when they're set in grungier environments. 

Sadly, those are the only positives of the game. Though they're the core features, they just aren't enough to make the game currently worth it. 
The leveling up system is absolutely horrendous, as it involves killing enemies and picking up their "cells" before they expire. It takes maybe 6 seconds for them to vanish, meaning you have to fight in close quarters (or get lucky with a weapon that picks them up on crit, but that's supremely rare from my many runs) or risk never leveling up. On top of that, the cells heal you if you get damaged, so they're insanely important for things that just vanish in almost no time at all. 

For endgame content, there is absolutely none. There are absolutely no benefits for beating the game's 8 difficulties. No upgrades, no unlockables, and no advancements. You can get absolutely everything with NG+2 
The difficulties in the game go as follows: Easy, Standard, Heroes, Heroes+1, Heroes+2, Heroes+3, Heroes+4, Heroes+5, Heroes+6)

Furthering this awful design that leaves absolutely no incentive for you to play harder difficulties, you get almost no bonus upgrade components. I got more components from a winning run on the same route through NG+2 than I did on NG+6. Adding onto that, you get the same amount of XP from enemies, meaning you'll always end up being just as strong. Getting every single cell from every single enemy in every run from NG+1 to NG+6, I always ended up at Level 11. I'd hit Level 12 when I beat the final boss, but then the game ends. 

I held onto the hope that SOMETHING would happen when I beat the game on its highest difficulty, in which enemies just do ridiculous damage, and yet there was not a thing. The game just cuts away and ends. 

My favorite part of any game in these genres is getting stronger, even if only incrementally. I'd even take unlocking things that don't make you stronger, so long as there is SOMETHING to make playing the game after completion worth it, especially when you have SIX extra difficulties. How can you justify that level of challenge when you don't even give the players anything extra? 

This is a very unrewarding game to play through, and I was only able to muddle through each difficulty because the gunplay is satisfying and smooth. There are currently 3 bosses I could find in this game (It seems they removed one of the boss's from a few months ago), and the final boss of the game is just...the worst thing ever. The first two bosses are the peak of passable. They're just grindy, but so long as you just don't stop moving, and occassionally jump, you really can't lose. Then you reach the final boss, at which point the developers seem to have given up and decided to make the most poorly designed boss they could think of. It's essentially the game throwing a non stop series of attacks at you from an enemy that can kill you in 3 hits, but survive 3 minutes of unending gunfire from insanely powerful weapons. Add to this 3-5 invincibility phases (they're brief if you act quickly, but are still annoying) and something that automatically locks you in place and you just have the least fun final boss in almost any shooter. 

Though I hate to make comparisons due to the games being somewhat different at their core, this game doesn't hold even a match to Gunfire Reborn. At their cores, the games are similar, but at a glance, RoboQuest has far superior gunplay. Outside of that though, everything else falls short. Roboquest has no endgame content, and nothing to reward the player for beating the game at any point, or at any difficulty. The map design is great until you hit the final level, in which they just make a horribly unoptimized mess of a map that begins draining any fun out of the experience, then finish it off with a boss that removes any traces of a smile from your face. 

This is a game that is at its best when you're playing for the first 3 hours. After that, you've seen everything it has to offer. The game is done. There is nothing more for you aside from the mere ability to say "I did it. I beat Heroes+6 and got nothing for it."

I owned Roboquest long before the 1.0 release, and I can confidently say it is one of the best run 'n gun games I have ever played. Just like everyone says, this game mixes the smooth movement of Apex with the high intensity action of Doom. All this is nicely paired with some wonderful rougelite elements to mix up every run. 

You can play the game however you want. The wide variety of weapons, perks, and upgrades allow you to fashion every run to your own preferred playstyle. Wanna keep your distance and snipe enemies? Go for it. Wanna punch enemies in the face and blast them with a shotgun? Jump right in. Whether you're speedrunning or just going for a chill completion, Roboquest has plenty of options for both.

My ONLY complaint about this game comes from the performance. I usually run on HIGH settings, and even my 32GB of ram and 4070 can struggle to keep up. I don't often notice the drops in framerate, but it's enough that I don't dare play on ULTRA. Granted, you can easily reduce the graphics of this game without many consequences. It's not beautiful, but nicely stylized. I only hope that as the game continues to grow (the developers are amazing), it will receive a few optimization updates to improve performance.

Overall, I love Roboquest, and I'm sure you will to. Turn on some breakcore and go shoot some bots.

I was really waiting for the 1.0 to be release after years of early access. The final result is great.

It's a very fun and engaging rogue lite fps. The gunfight feels INCREDIBLE. Every attack as oomph, every weapon is unique and it's simply a good combo between shooting and movement. The build diversity is a bit less deep than a game like Gunfire Reborn but the production quality of the game makes up for it. It's feels GOOD.

You have multiple classes that have all their passives, active abilities but also their own perks that you chose by leveling up. You can be a hunter that becomes invisible and get different bonus when using his javelins to take down enemies or you can be an engineer that uses drones to help him destroys his foes or even a melee assassin.

Lots of weapons as well, from pistol, smg and shotguns to miniguns, mortar and bows. There is every type of weapons you can hope for. Weapons also have affixes to change their behaviour  (firerate, recoil, elemental damage, crit chance etc) 

The only mid element of the game I would say is the level design. More specifically  the lack of real variety. But Hades also had that and the game is still a masterpiece, so it's not a deal breaker at all in Roboquest, just something you notice quickly after several runs.

Overall it's a great experience, lots of variety in its gameplay, secrets to find, upgrades to get, builds to try and tons of enemies and bosses to kill.

After playing many runs of the 1.0.0 full launch of Roboquest, this has turned out to be one of the most addictive game out there of all time for a Roguelike shooter game. It is such an improvement compared to when it was in Early Access, lots to do. I Highly recommend Roboquest. The music is absolutely epic, there's new levels, there's NPC's etc. You simply must get this game, it's so good. I'll explain how to unlock the Ranger, buddy bot and Elementalist class in Roboquest...

SPOILER ALERT ON HOW TO UNLOCK THE RANGER, BUDDY BOT AND ELEMENTALIST CLASS:

RANGER CLASS: To unlock the Ranger, you must find the lost javelin in one of the levels. It is located in the Oasis level. When you are within the level, it is behind a waterfall on the orange colour of your mini map. Once you have claimed the lost javelin, you will automatically unlock the Ranger class.

BUDDY BOT: Now this one confused me to the point where I made a discussion on how to unlock the Buddy Bot. In the very first level, it is an enemy robot that has a different paint job than the rest and has a green eye for it's critical spot as a weakness. Do not kill him for that is the Buddy Bot you are looking for, simply run up to him and interact with it to permanently unlock it for future runs. Once you have unlocked the Buddy Bot, you will no longer encounter him.

ELEMENTALIST CLASS: This one is a tricky one, you need to do several runs and make it to the energy center. At the very start of the energy center, instead of starting your run right away, look behind you, you will notice a locked door with a code on it. To unlock this door, you must reach the first safe zone (green zones are safe zones on your mini map, checkpoints). You will notice that there is a locked door as you enter the safe zone to your left, stick to the left of that room, there is see through glass, through the glass is the very code you need to unlock the door to get the Elementalist class. However, this is the bad news, you will only see 2 of those numbers per run that change randomly each time. For example, my first run when I noticed it (NOTE: The code is completely different for each player but here is an example), X3X4XX, then on my 2nd run, 6XXX2X. You get the picture anyway. Keep restarting your run and get up to the energy center to eventually get your full 6 digit code to unlock the door to get the Elementalist. He is the most overpowered class in the game, it is totally worth doing.

The rest of getting everything in the game, spoiling the rest, I will not say, those 3 things are vital to know. The rest is up to you to discover. 

5/5

Before, the game was rather expensive for what content was in the game and the game did feel rather easy to complete (I had completed an entire run in less than 30 minutes several times in a row) but those issue have since been addressed. The game is properly difficult now, forcing you to focus on position as well as the weapons you carry and your cooldowns as well as the game having tons of secrets and unlockables including 6 classes! My only gripe is the rooms that lock you in until you complete a "boss" of waves of enemies. The rooms can feel very clustery and can end up ruining what could be a good run.

Overall, the game is a blast and I find myself actually enjoying video games again. The concept is very simple but the game feels great to play and advance in. Each run has me wanting to push the earlier levels faster and the later levels further until the run reaches its summit.

TL;DR - Good game, buy. Especially on sale.

Initially, I had enough fun playing this like a standard FPS: strafe, duck, shoot, reload. But after a few hours, I started getting into the more unique elements of the game, such as the Mario-inspired headbonk, the weapon swapping (your weapons automatically reload when not in your hand), and the rail-riding. Really, the game is meant to be played at a fast and chaotic pace, and once you get comfortable with it, it becomes downright addicting.

Most of my hours so far have been during early access, and I can say the official 1.0 release is nothing but improvements on an already solid, well-made game. 

In short, this is one of my all time favorites.

The guns feel like Borderlands meets Overwatch. The movement is fluid and the abilities grow in the exact direction you want them to. They also have actual impact. I haven't found an ability yet that made me feel bad for choosing it. I cannot wait to see what kinds of builds you can get to. The fights are intense and fast paced, the bosses are fun and interesting. Every time I progress further in this game, I find more and more I love.

I can see where this game took inspiration from so many other great roguelikes and after even a short time playing this you realize that it belongs up there with some of the best of them. 

Buy this game, buy it now, do yourself the favor.

Let me just say, this game is awesome. I have very few issues with this game and the music is even great. If you enjoyed Doom Eternal and like Rogue-likes, this game is perfect for that itch. You can compare this game to a lot of things (gunfire reborn especially) but once you get the flow of it, it really feels like you're just culling robots, and that's peak. I played most of my hours in the Pre-release so my progress is all gone now (saj) but I am honestly enjoying the large amount of guns they added. A scout never felt so good. 

As for my issues, it's all small stuff. Like lack of levels and enemies. They are all robots sure, but most do the same thing. Like there is this really annoying turret that will chain you, pulling you to it... and then there is this small robot enemy who can chain you... pulling you to it... and there are only like 10 bosses on like 3 or 4 different boss waves. They added some super secret paths but those seem to be for end game builds, so I am not sure co-op pathing there will ever make sense. So, my route remains mostly the same since I started playing so my grind will be largely the same, which is disappointing. Also I have to find all the data logs again... kill me pls.

I really do recommend this game! I am just worried by how slow developments have been. I am not one that understands any of that or claims to, but having a title screen be a christmas theme for about a year is a bit much (pre-release). Like how can you tell a game is dead? It's christmas update is live during halloween 11 months later. I was aching for at least that to be changed in an update so it didn't feel like a dead game. That being said I held out hope, and the improvements made in the past year have been great, bar them making Max look wayyy weirder. Definitely worth it on sale, probably fun with friends (if you have any). I just would not expect this to be your new 2k hour game because of the lack of enemy variety, that being said there are tons of enemies considering it's all just turrets, drones, and robots and 6 overwatch style hero robots you can play as.

Roboquest is easily my favourite rogue-lite of all time:
[list]
[*] This game has the most responsive, satisfying, and smoothest movement that's ever graced an FPS.
[*] Almost all weapons, abilities, perks, etc. fill out their own relatively distinct and entertaining niche.
[*] Builds may lack the Issac-style zaniness, but still perfectly manage to balance player agency, variety, and viability.
[*] Content is unlocked at a fairly consistent and satisfying pace, and the difficulty curve feels [i]just-right[/i].
[*] Multiplayer support is fantastic, even if its limited to two players, and doesn't feel like it's mandatory to progress.
[*] The art style is fantastic, was implemented really well, and always keeps the game state very clear.
[/list]

I do have a few complaints, but thankfully none of them are about the core game-play:
[list]
[*] Chapter 3 just isn't optimised properly, as looking towards the centre of the map can drop my frame-rate by up to 75%.
[*] Unreal's vague anti-aliasing settings are here with a vengeance, with higher values smearing Vaseline over my screen.
[*] Epic Online Services and Starbreeze are tied to this game, but everything seems incredibly smooth at launch.
[/list]

The developers should be [i]very[/i] proud of their work here: this game aught to shine in the spotlight like Pizza Tower.

*UPDATE 30-06-2022:*
Oh heck I'm back! I'm still playing, and the 0.9 playtest has me more hyped than ever before! With the removal of Weapon Categories and a complete visual overhaul for the perk screen. weapon drops and a large visual improvement too all environments since my last review update, this game just keeps getting better. This is by far the most play time I've put into a 16 euro game, and that 200 hour that I'm at right now will

*UPDATE 29-01-2021:*
I feel like updating my review periodically (2-3 months), because the game probably has one of the most involved (and social) communities that I've ever been in. And I absolutely love it.

Let's start with stating the obvious: The game has some REAL potential. This is created by the insanely fine DOOM-esque gun-play, together with the great movement, even mid-air. 
Refined with the perk system, it really doesn't matter if you want to go insanely fast and guns blazing, or take it slow and methodically. Weapon affixes contribute to this as well, making it viable to sit back with snipers and not getting any of "dem sweet cellz" (XP) go to waste. (Snipers work a good deal in close quarters as well, because of nearly perfect hipfire accuracy!) 

The base system was greatly improved upon with both the Autumn and Winter 2020 updates. With the addition of more ways to spend your gears, earned by clearing zones and getting good ranks, it feels good to grind for the upgrades again. Al (Not that I really need to, I've got over 1100 spare gears as of writing, but ahhh it's just so fun to do and see that S rank xD)

Overall, if this update pace and patch size keeps up, together with the minor tweaks and bugfixes, this game WILL be good. The only minor criticism that there is, is the performance of a certain zone (called Fields), that gives substantial frame drops on the minimum spec. If you have anything above a GTX 660/750, you will likely not having any drops in frame rate.

Conclusion:
Keep up the amazing work, RyseUp. This is a gem which can only be polished further.



*Base review as of 25-8-2020*
So this is the kind of games you rarely find in Early Access or even as an indie title.
This, this is a hidden gem. The gameplay does remind me of Quake/Doom because it's you can choose to play INSANELY FAST and get rewarded with a sick S-rank at the end of a stage + gears for upgrading your hub-base. 
The base is a place where you upgrade your structures, this is where more content will be added in the future and is quite necessary as I already maxed everything out in 3 hours of time.
The gameplay loop of this game is just "aaaaaaahhhhh it's so GOOD". There is a random selection of guns that you start with, and get a core to upgrade your ability or buff your weapon(s). In every level there is a mini-dungeom where you can get more weapons and better cores!

For an early access title, I'm rating this a 9/10. I can't wait what more content will be added in the future, I am HYPED
