Iv'e only played maybe... 20, 30 minutes? But I think the biggest thing for me, and what will keep people coming back let alone try it in the first place with FPS are the 'feel'. Clunky, slow, low mobility? All BAD imo. But Roboquest is the opposite of that. It feels... Smooth. I feel in control. I have a double jump, a crouch/slide, i can toggle sprint, i can get multiple weapon types and abilities, theres a (imo) quite good melee ability that can be upgraded...

Overall, take my review with a grain of salt as it's early times but the feel, the flow of combat is the #1 thing for me and Roboquest does that in spades.

Roboquest is a roguelike shooter you should buy if you are really into fast paced action and build diversity.
Personally, the game reminds me of Dead Cells of all games. The game is fast, and you‚Äôre encouraged to meet such expectations.  The better you get at a game, the more enjoyment you get from playing it. Levels are ‚Äúsemi‚Äù-random ‚Äì they have pre-defined structure but random room composition. There‚Äôs a great emphasis on your tools of destruction - a ton of unique weapons with unique core features gimmicks, not just a number of ‚Äúgun‚Äù-sticks with variable stats attached/

The game has a variety of classes. What exactly is the class? In fact, it‚Äôs your core abilities (‚Äúgrenade‚Äù and ‚Äúultimate‚Äù kinda) and upgrade path - a set of bonuses you get for the run. Once again, unlike most rougeulites, they are not stat sticks and actually have a meaningful impact on how you play and what you choose to upgrade next, providing build variety even on the hardest difficulty.

I want to say a special thanks for a very fast metaprogression - it takes around 8-12 hours to unlock all content and enjoy the game at its full potential. It might look like a downside for some, but I'm really tired of worthless grind for 30 hours just to get a whooping +5% to crit my ass.

Never had a chance to play in multiplayer, so can‚Äôt say anything about it.

So, some downsides-controversies:

1. The levels are kinda samy as room diversecity is not that good, but the gameplay is so fast i wasn‚Äôt bothered by it in my 130 hours
2. (Not my point but  a complaint from a friend of mine) ‚ÄùNot enough enemy variety‚Äù (mind you, he compares it to Ultrakill enemy variety). All your enemies are robots, flying robots and turrets. The only thing that changes is a pattern of attack (some shoot lasers, some shoot grenades, some go for melee, annoying you do death). Though one must admit bosses are unique and fun to fight against.

And that‚Äôs kinda it. You should buy it if you like to check your reflexes

Edit: forgot to mention how well made prefix system is. Prefixes are actually have impact on what this particular weapon can do

Pre-release impressions:
NOTE: I have A LOT more than 25 hours in game, mainly due to playing GoG versions.

Roboquest is a great feeling FPS shooter with some rougelike elements that keeps each run feeling fresh and a progressive unlock system that keeps you playing for hours.

Typical runs average around 20 minutes depending on how far you are in the game.

Graphics have a charming comic book aesthetic, and if the onomatopoeia annoys you, it can be turned off.

It runs really well on a variety of systems.

Transparent developers, vibrant community.

I participated in the pre-release 1.0 test and from what I was able to experience, which was very little, it fixed a lot of the issues I have with the current Early Access version.
Can't wait for 1.0 and to craft a full review.

All that being said, I went back and played an old/legacy version again recently (via GoG) and I must say I miss directly upgrading the basecamp, I ask the that the developers re-implement it going into the future, like maybe in 2.0.

It's Gun: Game: The Gun Game.

Jokes aside, this is a solid FPS entry outside of the rouge-like mechanics (which are very good in providing that incremental power creep and playtime goals to strive towards)

If you like the frenetic pace from DOOM 2016 and many ways to play a specific build, you'll absolutely love this game.

All in all, I'd say...if you have someone to play co-op with, take the $24.99 plunge. Otherwise, for all the solo players, wait to catch this one on sale unless you're a big fan of FPS rogue-likes as is.

yes - for multiple reasons. The developer is extremely good at listening to and involving community, for a shooter rogue-like this is one of the keys to greatness, and they set a bar I have not seen from any other project lately or possibly ever with extensive playtesting and allowing player input to not only be received, but respected and considered. The Gameplay is beyond smooth, and it scratches an itch Borderlands introduced with randomized weapons and takes it to new heights with sharp gunplay and the freedom of knowing you can try anything in a run with no repercussions beyond getting to play another. The story is cute and provides a healthy humanization to what could otherwise feel like robot carnage with little purpose. Overall I would buy and recommend this game at $60USD, 25 is a steal any way you shake it. I cannot wait for 1.0 to go live :)

Its not a balanced game currently, but that can change at release.   Its still fun and for the price worth picking up.  There isn't that much variety in guns or builds, and getting one of the few good guns (or hitscan mod) is necessary to finish a run.  I've beat it a few times and I enjoy it still.   The classes aren't balanced, but are still fun.

Movement and gunplay is very crisp, roguelike elements are fantastic giving different approaches that all feel powerful.   The progression systems feel good to work towards without taking too long to get to a strong state. As a Gunfire Reborn fanboy I think the replayability of Roboquest after maxing progress is a bit weaker due to a lack of variance in gameplay experience depending on weapon finds during a run and how those interact with your character selection and build. Finding cool weapons tends to just make you generally "better" instead of opening new ways to approach fights. 

Also the music goes incredibly hard.

Overall I would highly recommend the game. I thought the price was well justified in much earlier stages of the game and 
updates along the way have given me confidence in the dev team both to execute on 1.0 well and continue support beyond.
Its Combat is fluid, its music SLAPS, and its arsenal is large. Roboquest is not only a great shooter, its a great rougelike, and a great Coop game. absolutely worth it.

Listen, I don't usually do steam reviews, but...this game is worth every penny. When you start you'll feel that is not much but once you get into it, it gets sooooooo much better. Fast-paced, dynamic combat, huge variety of weapons, the feel of the game is amazing and most important of all...it's FUN as hell, which is one of the most important points a lot of AAA companies don't pay attention to these days. In such an overpopulated market of triple A games is good to find gems like this. I cannot recommend this game enough if you are looking for a FUN experience to spend some time on without the worry to lose track of story or anything else. Games should be like this (from my point of view); get in, play a game, have fun, get out. This game manages to do this perfectly. This is an Early Access FPS roguelite banger.
The good:
Best moment-to-moment pew-pew gameplay I've experienced outside of the Doom reboots. Smooth as silk and zone-inducing. And the guns feel great to shoot.
The music is an awesome mix of synthwave and drum n' bass. Pulse-pounding and despite the limited selection of tracks, they never got old.
The aesthetic is cheerful without being too goofy.
Difficulty is perfectly reasonable. I only got to the final boss once in almost 40 hours (on Normal difficulty), but I never felt like I'd been robbed. There are lots of opportunities to switch out and level up in different ways during the course of a run.
I loved the different robots, but once I unlocked the drone-keeper guy, he was my go to.

The meh:
I still don't understand what that little Robo-buddy is good for that you rather early on get access to in the starting area. It never once came in handy and was so big it kind of got in the way.
The story and cut scenes are ok, but really just a step-above placeholders.
Why on earth is it called Roboquest?  Despite it being a dumb name (imho), there's not a whole lot of "quest" involved.
After the first purple bonus area, I never felt compelled to hit up any others, as the risk vs. reward ratio never warranted it. Some better rewards in those areas might have been tempted me more often.

The verdict:
I love this game. I maxed out my skill tree in 40 hours on Normal difficulty, and I will definitely reinstall it once the game gets an official, polished release.  When this goes on sale, it's a very easy recommendation, even for those of you (like myself) who felt that their twitch-gaming days were behind them.
Little short on content, but the gameplay and roguelite bits have been awesome. Borderlands-esque, touch of overwatch.

[b] The game is still in early access so far, so it obviously needs to be ironed out. I can't wait to see how far the game goes when its released. [/b]

First of all, the positives: the gameplay is really fun. I plays a lot like Doom Eternal with Borderlands elements, but in some surprisingly good procedurally generated levels that have a lot of verticality.
I think this is the only game that I have played so far that does rocket-jumping like this. I always take an explosive type weapon with me just for the extra mobility.

And the best part of the game for me, is the soundtrack. Noisecream did a fantastic job here.

And the arsenal is pretty decent. But I think some guns are a bit weak.
Some weapons, like the Blast SMG, Blast Rifle and the Bubble Splasher feel weak to use.

I don't have a lot of things that I dislike about the game. Most of it boils down to early access balancing problems.
[list]
[*]Like the Recon being a lot more powerful than the other classes to the point where you can just use the laser cutlass and ignore your guns. Although it is fun, I would like for the guns to be stronger to counterbalance the cutlass.
[*]And the Engineer not being very fun to play, since his turrets have a tendency to either die before they get useful, or they just kill everything for you until the late game, where they become useless again. Though, this might just be me not preferring the Engineer's play-style, since I don't have many suggestions for him.
[/list]

And the game needs a lot more content. I hope they add it before it releases. Because the game right now is a well built scaffold with a lot of potential for a good game.

And another issue people have been having with this game, high CPU temps. I thought it was  an issue with Proton at first, but it seems like it's still a problem. It's partially fixed by undervolting my CPU, but you should keep it in mind before buying.

Was a big fan of this at first and for awhile, but eventually it lost it's luster. I'm not even sure if it's something fixable, ***for us***, sadly. To preface, this is coming from the perspective of myself and my buddy who are both around a low-plat level of skill for most competitive shooters we play. Not amazing by any means, but we're halfway decent shooter players.


TL;DR - It's got solid rogue-lite bones but the balancing is just not good enough, and is far enough off I'll take a pass from now and play Gunfire Reborn instead. Multiplayer works solid, if that's a concern.


The big reason I say for us specifically is I understand this bit is heavily opinionated -- The game is *too* hard at it's current state, but I think it'd take an entire redesign to make it work. The easy difficulty is too easy, the enemies hardly engage you by the time you've killed them. But the medium/default difficulty it feels like you're constantly chasing health globes, having to dive well past enemies to even make an attempt to survive because there's so many mobs around, and each hit is doing ~20% of your health or more. In enough rooms, you just simply do not have the amount of cover required to dodge the 15-20 enemies shooting at you at once.

I'd like to see the entire game rebalanced - Less damage from mobs, but harder to heal yourself. I don't want to feel like taking a couple hits has just completely ruined a run. I jump on to play a rogue-lite game to play casually, not sweaty, and that's how I've felt playing this.

There's other smaller issues, like a bug that the devs know about but has been incredibly difficult to track down. Sometimes  when I click to shoot, the gun just doesn't shoot. My buddy is not having the issue. That one is incredibly frustrating, and I hope they can track it down to fix. We've found the guns to be a bit boring just because since it's so difficult to dodge so much, feel like we have to have a medium range weapon at all times. Can't just nab a melee weapon or a flamethrower etc because we've just kinda died with em. But then, the power curve seems to jump significantly on the mobs. One section we're doing reasonable damage, the next, if we haven't had a chance to upgrade the weapon, feels like a wet noodle. The jumps are too big. Not to mention, as some other reviews have mentioned, the bosses often just feel like unneeded bullet sponges.

The base-level skill tree that you level feels medium-level impactful, mostly focusing on giving you more gun drops and chances they'll be upgraded with things like an alt-fire (maybe it'll be a zoom, or a charged shot, whatever). The multiplayer works well, had no issues. I wish there was more chances to grab some of the in-run card upgrades, something should come out of the vaults except for a weapon which basically never feels impactful.

The game is, at it's core, a traditional rogue-lite, and I do like it for that. But honestly? I'd rather just play Gunfire Reborn if I want a shooter rogue-lite, this doesn't bring anything new to my desires to play. We'll keep looking for others to try out and revisit this in a year or so and see what they've done with it.

I'd like to preface this by saying that this game is very much still an Early Access game, so if somewhat minimal content bothers you? You'll want to hold off on this one for a few months until 1.0.

With that said, I can very confidently say that with the current state of things that Roboquest is very confidently shaping up to potentially become one of my favourite games this year with very little competition against it. This game thus far, even in its Early Access state very much feels like a labour of love from the dev team with a refreshing player-first mindset behind each of the current development decisions. Every aspect of the game from the gunplay to the movement to the varying class abilities to (most) enemy designs feel absolutely flawless. There's enough weapon variety at the time of writing this to benefit more or less any type of play style you may want to explore; even up to and including close range melee options such as chainsaws or exploding fists. 
My only real complaint with the current weapons would be that LMG type weapons feel VERY bad to use as they tend to slow you down while firing without doing enough damage to accommodate for the need to burst fire them, dodge, burst fire and then spend around two to three seconds reloading them.

Level design for the first six hours has been relatively pleasant to work through with the environments themselves being very pleasing to look at, if a little bit samey after enough back-to-back subsequent playthroughs, but if you don't no-life the game like I have over the past 24 hours then that may very well end up being a non-issue!

On the topic of classes, I truthfully can't comment all too much because I came into this game wanting to try out all of them only to end up falling in love with the Recon on account of its extremely satisfying fast-paced gameplay loop of teleporting into a group of enemies, stunning them, delivering quick and decisive (also very powerful) melee attacks to high-risk enemies and then using the fluid movement system to dodge the attacks of the recovering and surrounding enemies. It creates a very Doom-like method of play which compliments the necessity to kill enemies to regenerate any health and the bonuses to that health gain you get from using melee to kill enemies. Hell, six hours in I still haven't even unlocked the current final class of the game which only leaves me wondering how capable they are...

Not that they'll ever replace my beloved Recon if they don't have anywhere near as intoxicatingly smooth movement.

Anyway, mindless rambling aside -
 If you aren't a broke BITCH and like fast-paced, highly promising FPS roguelikes and are willing to place a little bit of faith in some devs who so far have only shown promise and love for their game? I sincerely could not recommend Roboquest enough. We're looking at 1.0 releasing at latest by the end of September hopefully, which leaves plenty of time to get into the game, familarize yourself with the systems, get your camp upgraded and your robots unlocked in preparation for the huge patch that's coming soon. Personally, I can't wait to see what they have in store for us.

The core is really fun, tight gunplay, snappy movement and momentum, soundtrack that has no right to be as good as it is. However, it is marred by poor enemy design that runs counter to its strength.
Overuse of invulnerability mechanic from like the second level onward, every fight half of the enemy on screen will be invulnerable until you shoot a small little drone which sometime can even hide around corner.
There's way, way too many aoe for a game which such a fun movement mechanic, because every fight half of your space to move is cut off by a giant laser that last a loong time, or just covered in mines and bombs. 
It's mechanics incentivize agressive, fast movement focuses agression to get in there, slide and jump on enemy head and pick up health, but the enemy design makes this frustrating as your agression is stymmied by your shots bouncing off enemy unless you find the shield drone, and your fast movement is coralled by half of the area being covered in aoe.
Scratches the looter shooter itch without making you bankrupt.

A true hidden gem, and probably an instant classic if the devs keep up the amazing work. The movement mechanics are simple but very fluid: you have a double jump, slide, and some characters have special movement abilities to add on top. The combat is super crisp, each weapon so far feels great to handle, and there are a huge variety of them. Melee weapons are not only viable, but extremely fun, which was a very welcome surprise since FPSs tend to make them very boring, but in this game, dashing around with a huge chainsaw or knuckles is waaay too fun. 
The music also slaps SO hard, it's got that very DOOM style of instrumental metal, it's great. 9/10, buy at standard price, very reasonable

*The game IS on early access, so I wouldn't be surprised to find some bugs, but so far it's been very very clean, I'll update this review if I find any that lower the gameplay value/experience tho

Does a lot of things right. Satisfying gameplay loop, decent amount of meta-progression, enough enemy variety to keep you entertained as you run through, enough weapon variety and great enough gunplay along with perks that make each run feel unique. Levels are deceptively simple, corridors at first glance, arenas at second glance, and verticality is revealed on third glance. Exploration is encouraged to discover progression items. The only thing I could ask from this game is more, but as-is, it's more than worth the time and money. 

What's there that is good:
-cool classes
-satisfying challenge
-exploration of levels encouraged
-interesting boss fights
-enemy variety
-gunplay good
-meta-prog matters

No real complaints from an early access perspective. 

Things I'd like more of/like to see:
-areas, arenas, locations 
simply put, what;s there is great, more would be better
-bigger basecamp
a DRG-style basecamp is the standard imo, this comes close, but could be exceeded wildly if there were meta-progression installations that do certain things during runs. there's some of that in a skill tree but imo its massively advantaged if you "see" the upgrades. if the camp got more visually interesting as you built it, it would make the game perfect. maybe add friendly robots to find throughout the levels that can be added to your base, even if they are just cosmetic. make it modular possibly and it adds to the replayability.
-game modes
the wave rooms are cool, so maybe a mode where each room-clear gets bigger/harder, and goes infinite for certain kinds of rewards? maybe specially-designed arenas for wave modes? buttons or other interactables that change the areas? king of the hill in certain areas?

and that's all really, tldr: only thing this game really needs is more of the same.

TL;DR Game would have had potential but falls flat on being inviting for new players. 

It is one thing to say you made the game for the hardcore base but sadly that is not the core of any game in this era. You have to make it friendly for newer players otherwise you have an abysmal player base. The game has good fundamentals but that quickly is overshadowed by the simple issues that one would think would be simple to adjust... But with it being almost 3 years since releasing in early access it is doubtful they will make the changes.

Pros:
-Weapons feel amazing, are varied and fun to use.
-Graphics are clean and crisp, very good art style.
-Controls are customizable.
-Jumping into Coop isn't difficult.
-Classes when unlocked feel different and not clones of each other.


Cons:
-The trailer is misleading on how the gameplay is not the same. 
-For a bulleth@ll type of game their push for you to melee doesn't make sense.
-Health orbs heal sparingly, for only a few points, less than 10hp. Orbs also have a short time limit.
-The ramp up is non existent, you will walk into ANY room(that goes for the 1st room as well) and mobs are spawned and pointed at the door.
-Melee is pointless and makes no sense.
-There are rails, for sliding, added to the game that have no point whatsoever, they either traverse you 10 feet or they are used specifically for a certain mob.
-You can trigger mobs from another section of the map and there is no indicator as to what triggered it. Ex: Was in a menu after clearing a room and suddenly got attacked. Where did they come from? From the next section that wasn't walked into... 
-After you beat the first boss there is a rest room but has the healing locked off... How do you unlock it? Who knows the game doesn't tell you anything. 
-Other than to challenge yourself there is no real reason to change from the first class(invincibility shield) you start with. Not because it is good but because it can block all the bullets you are about to walk into once you step out the base room.


It is weird to say that the game has potential when it's been almost 3 years and they are about to fully release the game and some of these issues more than likely won't be fixed. Unless the point of the game is to just have a small number of people play and that's it than I guess. 

Even from Steamcharts the game had a peak of 800 players and now average of 200 daily. It's just not inviting for new players that would love to invest their money in indie games.

Really good! My experience of this game in terms of games I've played is: You're Scout from TF2 (with Apex Legends slide hopping but in every direction all the time) in Binding of Isaac... with Dark Souls enemies... and a Dota 2 sized kit of abilities...

Like Scout from TF2, you move fast and hit hard and hate getting hit. Like Binding of Isaac, the run is different every time and you sometimes get wacky combinations of properties (albeit nowhere near as wacky as BOI's). Like Dark Souls, you really need to pay attention to enemy attacks in a specific and focused way instead of just mindlessly kiting. And like Dota 2, you have a large bag of meaningful tricks (2-3 guns, each potentially with an alt-fire, and 2 abilities) and it's a big challenge trying to remember all of them and find good opportunities to use each one.

Also depending on your weapons you'll tend to feel a bit like either Scout, Soldier, or Sniper from TF2 (or Tracer from Overwatch, or Genji from Overwatch...)

I haven't made it to the end of the content that's in the game, and there's a really major 1.0.0 release update coming in Q3 2023 that based on the dev blogs is really something to look forward to, but the current state of the game is already very fun and extremely gameplay focused in a great way.

Howdy Folks! I know this may be lost in the ether but here are my 2¬¢

Roboquest is the first game I have ever written a review on! This speaks volumes to me as a gamer who typically is silent in his opinions and grumbles with no outlet other than the echo chamber he exists in on discord. Back on topic!

The first thing that caught my eye while browsing for another rogue-like was its visuals. It's like if Borderlands and your favorite comic book had a baby, and then that baby over-ran the human race and started killing off all the fleshies. I wish more games used cell-shading! The next hook were the noise pop-ups on every gun that you use; the snippets in the vids and screenshots don't do it justice. There is no other way to convey the experience of leaning over your keyboard, FOV at 130, playing the video-game equivalent of Adderall, while constantly moving, swapping out between weapons, and seeing each one go "KAPOW" "BOOmF" "PEWPEW".  Lastly, the color coding of objectives are another small, yet important thing for me visual wise. Countless times I can yell "Purple" to indicate the platforming puzzle, or "orange!" to indicate the secret rootin tootin loot hidden behind a waterfall or coded door. 

The visuals, while great, are not enough for someone to stay around. RyseUp distilled the most addicting part of roguelike's as a whole and infused it into their weapons, tiered progression system, and in-run level up perks. After you acquire the metal-detector gadget/trinket the game morphs into a collection fueled frenzy. Every room or sector I clear is another chance to find another addicting gun to use before I find another one that has just a tad more crit modifier or just a little more damage or-- A MISSILE GATLING WITH CRYO DAMAGE, ALT FIRE, +20% RELOAD SPEED, AND HAS A 15% CHANCE TO LAUNCH A LASER ARC EVERY SHOT FIRED. After you finish a run, or get far enough into a run with nice weapon affixes and die to the robot ninja sneaking up on you or the floor trap robit you forgot to clear, you get access wrenches. Wrenches are used to upgrade your "camp" so to speak which modify your passive abilities. Its nice to see abilities that directly increase the chance to find rarer guns and those that increase passive stats for your robot as well. I am 13 hours in so far and am more than halfway done with the progression tree. Finally, the in-run/in-game perks that you get make each run THAT much more fun to play. Just today I ran a session where I spec'd fully into Cryo damage; my drones did cryo damage, all my weapons by default did cryo, enemies received crit damage once frozen, AND Cryo damage was increased to enemies with resistance to it. 

That is just one of the dozens of perk combinations you can obtain ( my faves are fire drones, cryo and more explosive explosions) while progressing through a run as the final class you can unlock. 

I also haven't even mentioned the different classes, difficulty modifiers, the MUSIC ( the music <3 ), rail surfing, the goofy ah boss fights, the fact that it is COOP, and the overall polish these devs have put into this game. Robotquest is the epitome of what happens when a developer loves what they are working on. Studios that are not controlled or owned by the dollar of some mogul can produce truly great work. I am willing to wait as long as possible for a 1.0 release of this game and will have fun every moment I spend playing it before that happens.

Thank you for reading! I wish you luck on your RoboQuest!

Roboquest is an absolute blast to play! The game's smooth controls and fast-paced action make for an incredibly fun and engaging experience. The graphics and sound design are top-notch, immersing you in a sci-fi world that is both visually stunning and full of character.
The game's unique blend of first-person shooter and rogue-lite elements keep things fresh and exciting, with each run offering a new set of challenges and rewards. The weapon and upgrade systems are well-balanced and allow for a wide variety of playstyles, making each run feel unique.
What really sets Roboquest apart, though, is its co-op mode. Playing with friends adds a whole new layer of strategy and fun to the game, and the seamless matchmaking system makes it easy to jump in and start playing with others.
Overall, Roboquest is an excellent game that is definitely worth your time. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters or rogue-lites, there's something here for everyone. With its engaging gameplay, stunning visuals, and addictive co-op mode, Roboquest is a must-play for any action game fan.

[h1]This game may damage your CPU[/h1]

TL;DR
[i]Game will seriously push your CPU temps. Be wary if you purchase.[/i]

Edit: I have reinstalled Windows and games still stutter. Leads me to believe it's a hardware issue. Stay away from this game until it's fixed.

Right now I'm under the impression it did so to mine. Before I get to the context, you can even look in the discussions to see other people reporting really high temps (some legit, some not, although safe temps do vary a lot depending on CPU) and the devs acknowledging the issue, not denying it's because of the game. My experience while reading these posts is that most of the CPUs listed are Ryzen 5000 series. Maybe my reading experience was skewed though.

So I started playing this game again recently. I also opened CSGO about the same time for the first time in a while. I noticed some stuttering in CSGO and tried a ton of solutions I found online, none of which were working, which is weird because I didn't have these problems before. Also, my hardware specs include a Ryzen 5900x and RTX 3080. Not potato hardware. 

Ever since then, I noticed it also happening in Roboquest and Vermintide 2 consistently (they're the only games I've really been playing lately). I tried rolling back drivers thinking it happened because I updated the drivers during the CSGO shenanigans, among other things. So then I reverted everything I changed during the CSGO fix-attempt. Still nothing.

Downloaded HWInfo hoping to find something that stuck out of place. When running Roboquest, my CPU temps were around 87/88C. And the game had barely been running at that point, barely into a run. Even main menu temps were in the 80s. I assumed this was a cpu issue though, not the game. So I opened up my PC intending to re-apply thermal paste when I noticed the radiator and fans there were quite dusty. Figured it was worth a shot de-dusting and hoping that was enough without having to re-apply thermal paste. 

First opened Vermintide 2 (very cpu-heavy game). Stuttering still existed. But this was my first time checking temps for it. It was sitting in the 60s for a while before going into the 70s. Perfectly acceptable. Opened Roboquest. Temps were nearly as high as before, maybe a couple of degrees lower. I remember seeing 85C quickly into testing. I decided to re-apply thermal paste anyway. No difference.

I've exhausted all solutions I could think of. Only thing that makes sense in my mind for what's going on is that Roboquest initially pushed my CPU temps really high, near shut-down status, during my long sessions, overheating it just enough that something inside isn't working up-to-snuff. If the game isn't to fault, there's been some crazy coincidences along the way. Either way, a game shouldn't be raising temps this much higher than other games, especially when it's CPU usage is a lot less.

I would love to recommend this game because the movement and shooting is actually phenomenal (could use some more content for longevity though (hoping 1.0 brings this)). But people are experiencing dangerous temps on their CPU and this should have been a priority a year ago when these reports were coming in, maybe sooner.
